reviewText:
The single player campaign of Doom has exceeded all of my expectations I initially had toward it. My expectations were that I wanted it to be a great FPS game, and more importantly, a true DOOM title. I started the game on Nightmare difficulty right off the bat.

You will be fighting in the first 10 seconds of the game. Combat is challenging and very fluid with emphasis on speed, which they've certainly cranked up. Stopping is death on nightmare. Glory kills are satisfying, can be a ammo saver, and really don't hinder game flow at all, and can even be upgraded to perform faster (or toggled off in the options).

Level design is absolutely impressive. This was my biggest concern with Doom, and rest assured id FINALLY did it right. Non-linear, lots of exploration, plenty of secrets with hidden guns, secret level unlocks, and equipment.

The monsters are relentless. On nightmare you will get your ♥♥♥ kicked. This is a fact, and there's no way to circumvent this. I honestly felt at times that I was playing Project Brutality on Last Man on Earth" difficulty. Monsters boast a variety of attacks

reviewText:
This planet's population of gamers owe one man eternal gratitude.

His name is Marty Stratton, and with his team he has redefined
the genre that once paved the way for all FPS games to follow.

Marty was put in charge of DooM after Bethesda scrapped the original plans. His job was to make a DooM that goes back to the roots and feels like the classic games.

Not really an easy task, considering DooM is one of the most hyped franchises of all time, and a lot of the fans have incredibly high expectations, some at such levels it almost becomes unhealthy. And when the hype is built into such astronomical dimensions, you might fail to see the game for what it is, leaving you to miss out on the 95% good, and focus on the 5% that is bad or less good.

But even considering what a daunting task it must have been for id to finally resurrect this dearly loved franchise, and even secure the future for themselves as a independent company. I have one simple thing to say.

Oh boy have they succeeded.

Marty and his team of programmers, designers, composers, artists and advanced human beings has managed to revive the magic of the classic games. This game stands far, far, FAR out from basically all other fps games currently on the market.

And what a true relief that is.

I still have some bitter taste regarding the multiplayer though, which designs was outsourced to a company called certain affinity (id made the singleplayer and snapmap), and i can't but wonder if id should have made the multiplayer themselves. The multiplayer in this game feels like a vague impression of the singleplayer, they are really hard to compare. And it might have hurt the game's reputation, as this installments beta was not very well recieved on PC. Those that hated it, might never give the singleplayer the chance it deserves.

Because folks. id has done it. Again!
It would be a damn shame, if id wont make enough money on this game to inspire to produce sequels. The fans have been begging for a new DooM like this for over 20 years, and when it finally arrives, some mental patients complain that pick up items are glowing, or that the game has melee kills, or that doom marine looks like master chief, or that you can have emotes in multiplayer...

Guys please, pick your battles. id has delivered, by a huge margin. They made the game we have all been asking for, and they have done it really well. There were so many things that could have gone wrong with this game, and if you ignore multiplayer, pretty much nothing did. I'm not saying the multiplayer is bad, but it is not on par with the singleplayer.

id took a chance, they went back to their roots, they respected their heritage, and they listened to the fans. This game is FUN! Just like the classic DooM games was/is.

i'm having just as much of a blast playing this.

And i was there, 23 years ago, at the age of 17.

I even remember to this day exactly where i was, in what house, in what city, at what time of day, when i first saw DooM being played on a 486 66mhz with soundblaster. My jaw almost detached from it's foundation. It was 1993, very few people had internet back then, me included. So when i saw DooM at my friend's house that day, it was like something i had never seen before, i was not even aware it existed. The sense of WOW hitting me in the face when i saw it, is something no other game has been able to do, it was so different and so gorgeous, i actually did not believe my own eyes.

The original DooM stands as a monument in gaming history and is even to this day one of the most influentual games of all time. These are not easy shoes to fill. And this DooM can never fill those shoes either, because the first DooM wasn't only fun to play, it was a technical marvel of likes the gaming industry has rarely seen before or after. But what the new DooM can do, is to continue the legacy and keep on walking. And that is what they have achieved.

When you walk through hell, keep on walking.
The game is fast, smooth, awesome, gorgeous and bloody.
The soundtrack is amazing and combined with the sound effects it creates the atmosphere you felt playing the classic games. And combined with the fact that you never break first person view, and that this game has very few cutscenes" you really feel like you are the man passing through hell to make a solid impression.

You feel like a complete badass

reviewText:
Bethesda & id have done it. They've managed to breathe new life into the Doom franchise by keeping true to the series' roots, while injecting it with a healthy dose of  modern design sensibilities. The end result: one of the best shooters on the market, and one of the best shooters of the last 10 years.

Doom is fast-paced, frenetic, and surprisingly challenging. Many gamers will be surprised to learn that the game doesn't really hold their hand through the journey, but that's the beauty of it. With its sprawling maps and challenging battles, Doom will test veteran gamers on the higher difficulty levels--and that's a good thing. In an age where game design is all about accomodating the masses, it's nice to see a publisher take a risk.

And the risk was worth it.

Pros
-----------------
Beautiful graphics
Superb controls
Highly configurable system settings
Lengthy single-player campaign (12-14 hours, and higher as you increase the difficulty)
Incredible replayability (weapon and suit upgrades and rune challenges)
An outstanding musical score
Old school multi-player that will remind you of Quake and Quake 3
Superb weapons
Incredible violence
No weapon reloads
Snapmap

Cons
-----------------
Some people just aren't going to dig the multi-player
Campaign is pretty light on story (I think this is perfectly fine, but others will not appreciate it)
Price of season pass borders on outrageous

reviewText:
No captivating story, no reloading, no regenerating health, no deep characters, no deeper message, and you know what?

It's the best FPS I've played in years.

DOOM is a 'game' in the purest sense like it has always been, it's about nothing more than going in and having a blast, few games have brought me fun like DOOM has as I've already completed the campaign, and I certainly will replay all of it very soon just because the core gameplay is so much fun!

None of your time is wasted, you get a gun in your hand and start killing things literally 10 seconds into the game and it doesn't stop until roughly 12 hours later, and it only gets more fun as you go since you get more weapons and abillities, the whole game feels like a violent rollercoaster that only speeds up the further you go.

Though, despite all this there's still room for exploration, atmosphere and even a bit of story for those who are interested, though the objective may be 'go from A to B and kill everything standing in the way' the levels allow for a great deal of exploration as they are littered with all sorts of secrets, be it suit upgrade points, weapon mods, trail runes, codex entries and even entire levels from the original DOOM.

It's hard to really convey what makes this game so much fun through a review, as on paper the concept of 'go from A to B and shoot the bad guys' sounds a bit dull, but DOOM does it so well that I crave more.

If you've ever played a game where you held a gun and shot a thing, and thought to yourself 'hey this is pretty fun', DOOM is absolutely worth your time.

reviewText:
Summary
With the release of DOOM, ID Software has once again returned to form, bringing new relevance to a franchise that had laid dormant for over ten years aside from spin offs and re-releases. Although many worried that DOOM wouldn't impress upon launch, I can safely say that not only does it impress, but exceeded expectations tenfold.

ID Software has created another instant FPS classic that will leave you wondering why they ever strayed from this formula to begin with. With insanely fast paced action, fluid gameplay and fantastic graphics, DOOM is a nightmare come to life in all the best ways.

Whether you're looking for an immersive single player campaign or an addictive multiplayer component, you'll quickly realize that ID Software and Certain Affinity were both successful in paying their respects to fans of the series by bringing them an experience deserving of its decade long absence.

DOOM without a doubt deserves to be mentioned in the same bredth as its namesake and is a worthy successor to continue its legacy.

Welcome back to hell

Single Player Campaign
Within the first few moments of beginning your DOOM capaign, you'll be thrust into action. Literally seconds after the opening begins, you'll be fragging demons like its 1993 again. No unecessarily legnthly cinematic cut scenes, just DOOM. You'll be immediately immersed naturally, taking on the role of the DOOM Marine and slaying demons on Mars in brutal fashion.

As you traverse the facility and Mars surface, you be engrossed by the incredibly atmospehric surroundings, which are created with intense gameplay in mind. You'll be moving and attacking with forward progression, aggressively destroying hordes of demons and leaving their lifeless remains in your wake.

As the incredibly unforgiving DOOM Marine you'll be ripping and tearing through seemingly impossible odds, growing ever stronger as you upgrade your weapons throughout the campaign. From pistol and shotgun, to the legendary BFG, there are quite a few weapons at your disposal to dispatch your demonic enemies.

In regards to story, it's there, but not in the sense of countless cinematic cutscenes as many of us are accustomed to, but instead naturally by collecting information and reading its contents. This is an incredibly welcome method of immersion that all but a few titles have recently engaged in the use of in game.

Considering DOOM's campaign welcomes the player to return after completing it, to play at a higher difficulty or search for secrets hidden in the world, this is an incredibly smart decision. There's nothing worse than having to wait through a ten minute cutscene when you've already beaten a game and simply want to return to the action. I commend ID Software for not going the cinematic cutscene means of story telling due to this fact and the game benefits greatly from this decision, you'll see.

Back are the beloved DOOM elements such as searching for colored keycards to gain access to different areas of the map as well as searching for hidden areas or easter eggs (Which there are many, but I won't spoil them here). You'll be surprised at exactly how large the DOOM world is, if you decide to attempt to locate everything.

Although some have completed the campaign in roughly 9 hours, they most definitely weren't taking advantage of the entire experience available. DOOM could easily take upwards of 20 hours or more if being played completionist style, searching for everything hidden in its world and that's only if you're playing on Hurt me plenty"

reviewText:
I played thousands of hours of Doom 1, 2 and custom wads over the years, so naturally I was edgy as hell when it came to the new game. I hated it, I joked about it, made passive-aggressive Steam hub posts about it, implying kids did not know what a good Doom game is about.

I thought id Soft had lost it.

In the end, I bought the game to see what the positive reviews were all about first-hand.

I could go into boring minute details about how the new game could be improved and how it's lacking some important aspects of the originals, but I won't.

id Soft has not lost it. The game is tight, fast and fun, the levels are sprawling and fun when you turn off your compass and obj indicators, it even has a bleeding automap! I understand that you cannot ship Doom 2 with updated animations and textures and sell it to a 2016 audience.

Whatever has been changed to make the game work today is made with deliberation and does not ruin the core experience, which I believe is as close as you can get to the adrenaline thrills of the original games.

Good job, Stratton and team!

Considering the game was a few weeks away from launch and that the previous version - a continuation of what Doom 3 started back in 2004 and known simply as Doom 4 - had been scrapped entirely after nearly six years in development hell. It certainly didn't help allay fears when no review copies where shipped out to major gaming sites signalling what possibly looked like a lack of faith in the property. While initially they appear to be very linear -  a little bit of exploring off the beaten track soon reveals that while DOOM may not adhere to the open world design philosophy of today's modern game (something I feel is often more of a curse than a blessing) it does take what players seem to love about them (such as completing rudimentary tasks across a map) and integrates them seamlessly into the game. Rune Challenges (where the player gets to earn a rune that enhances power-ups or certain weapons) are littered across the game world for you to discover and unlock. Essentially nothing more than a series of time trials where you will have to beat the clock against certain enemy types or perform a certain number of tasks in the allocated time frame they actually make perfect sense in a far better way than stopping your questing in Assassin's Creed to suddenly collect thirty flags that have no bearing on the world or story-line or gameplay for that matter.\n\nUsing each weapon you are handed (the game is very good at giving you all the toys to play with right out the box and doesn't waste time drip-feeding you the junk at the start with all the best weaponry locked away near the end) and you can now build up proficiency in certain weapon types depending on how much you use the weapon during your run and/or by completing certain level tasks such eliminating certain enemy types with a specific type of weapon. Once levels are completed you can go back and run through them countless times until you have unlocked all the achievements
commentsCount:
discovered all the level secrets and completed all the level tasks. If I have one complaint it is that some of the levels are just so darn large and go on for what feels like forever especially when you are hit continuously with an ever increasing hoard of enemies. Some of these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s are tough on their own but soon you will be facing up to 4 of them simultaneously and I found it can become quite a chore (and not to mention a challenge) to move past if you just happen to die just before the checkpoint is activated. Graphically the games looks utterly incredible and is very well optimized. Most systems should be able to run DOOM without any issues. The ID Tech 5 quirk of textures taking a while to load when entering new areas is back but it is not as bad as it was when RAGE debuted using the engine. Having said that ID Software needs to look at finally solving this conundrum.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=693219234&tscn=1464523996
The jury is still out on whether there will be anyone still playing the multiplayer component of the game in three months time. Personally I couldn't care for it as Doom was never about multiplayer having always been primarily a singular-focused experience and while some might find this disappointing this new version of DOOM never needed it anyway. Besides that is why ID software has Quake. Seeing as though Bethesda is moving through the ID catalog top-down I am sure it will be just a matter of time before Quake gets the once over.

While ID software may have had great success in the early to late nineties with the likes of Wolfenstein
column16: Doom and Quake the departure of key ID players such as Romero and Carmack (both Adrian and John) has seen the company flounder a bit when compared to its former glory days. Doom 3
column17: while critically and commercially well received

Where Doom 3 had its sights set on revolutionizing the survival horror genre; its thunder and might was completely stolen when Capcom released Resident Evil 4 and RAGE amounted to nothing more than a pretty buggy tech demo for the in-house developed ID Tech 5 engine that saw the game fizzle and fade away faster than a demon with a doomslayer on his ♥♥♥.

reviewText:
DOOM (2016) is an id Software game.
The above statement may seem strange, but it reflects what I thought while I was playing the game. id Software is a company known for kickstarting the FPS genre, and making gorgeous game engines. Sadly, their latest efforts haven't been as successful as the original Doom and its sequel, or the Quake series. Rage, their first new IP in years, had pacing issues, and idTech 5, id's shiny new engine, wasn't as good as one would expect from id. One could argue that the last id Software game that felt right at home with their legacy is either Doom 3 or Quake 3 Arena (Doom 3 lacks the relentless action that made id famous but it delivered in spades if you consider the tech department)
Well, I have good news for you, fans of the FPS genre! id Software is back, and better than ever. DOOM's singleplayer campaign is both modern and old school. It's incredibly good looking, runs amazingly well, and has a beautiful soundtrack.
Gone is the oppressive darkness and slow action that characterized Doom 3. Rage's poor pacing and graphics issues? Gone too. In their place, we can find fast paced action, a well thought upgrade system, intricate maps that remind us of a bygone era, and a tongue in cheek attitude that permeates the whole story mode. Doom Guy is here to kill demons and he won't let silly things like cutscenes get in his way.
Prepare yourself for a journey that will take you to Mars and (spoiler alert, duh!) Hell itself in a quest to blow apart thousands of demons and use their entrails as health or ammo boosts. DOOM adds a new feature called Glory Kills, which lets the player execute wounded demons in exchange for a quick health top up, and believe me, you will learn to love it!
So yeah, id Software is back, baby!
Now that I've relayed the good news, it's time for the bad stuff:
The multiplayer component isn't as good as the campaign, and it wasn't even made by the same team (it was outsourced to the same guys that helped build the latest Halo's online component) Movement is pretty fast, but not as fast as Quake 3. Weapons aren't pickups anymore (with some exceptions) and you build a loadout, similar to Call of Duty or Battlefield, to name a few modern shooters that use the same system.
The SnapMap system is interesting, but a fully featured mod suite would certainly be a better thing for PC owners.

All in all, I think that DOOM is one of the best shooters in decades, and any FPS fan should consider getting it. A botched multiplayer offering can't overshadow the fact that the campaign is a work of art and it can rightfully claim a place in history alongside Doom 1 and 2.

reviewText:
DOOM is a super gory, fast paced action FPS that has an excellent single player campaign, as well as multiplayer.

Check out my Quick Campaign Review here: https://youtu.be/aCy1Hd71tbA
I expected  DOOM to be all about the combat, with little to no story. I was very surprised that the story had so much more depth to it than I had anticipated.

As you progress through the campaign, you find several different weapons, and almost all of them are badass. On top of some already awesome weapons, you can also find weapon mods for each one to upgrade how you want. I found the plasma gun stun mod especially helpful for keeping demons off of my face, and the chainsaw and BFG are crazy fun to use. You will need to switch up your weapons as you run out of different ammo types, and  you will also want to mix in melee finishers as well.

When demons get low on health they stagger for a short period, and when you see it, if you quickly get into range, you can perform a melee execute called a glory kill. The glory kill animations are bloody as hell, and it’s incredibly awesome each and every time. I haven’t been this satisfied ripping things apart since I played The Darkness II. The kill animations are short, and quick, so I never got sick of seeing them, unlike how bored the slow motion kill shots in the Fallout series got after the first few. Performing glory kills also awards bonus health drops, allowing you stay in the fight longer.

The boss fights each had scripted phases with unique mechanics. Bosses did a lot of damage if you failed to react properly, but once you learned the patterns, the fights were much easier. I really enjoyed the boss fights, It was nice to only have to focus on one enemy for a little bit instead of a whole bunch of them chasing after you.

Pros:‘run and gun’ playstyle is very enjoyable, and the combat is really fun and intense - keep moving, running, jumping, climbing, and fend off the hordes of demons spawning all around you!
level designs are done very well, and running and gunning feels very fluid jumping from one place to another while fighting
overall graphics look great (but they aren’t perfect)
amazing soundtrack throughout the entire game; it made the encounters feel like such a rush
voice acting, and other sound effects were on point as well
good story campaign, and there was a lot more to it than just killing demons (but I wasn’t too thrilled by the ending)
several badass different weapons that you can mod, and upgrade how you want
good quick melee executions (glory kills) that are very satisfying
several secrets, various weapons, mods, and upgrade items hidden around each of the levels (and a map to help you find them, once you find the map data)
Cons:some minor texture issues, but the game is so fast paced, that many people might not even notice
expensive season pass if you want to have everything when it first becomes available
You also find power-ups that can give different temporary combat bonuses, such as extra damage, speed, berserk, and invulnerability. You know you’re about to get slammed by demons when you enter a room fully stocked with health, ammo, armor, and power-ups.

I can see some people wanting to replay on the hardest difficult and for achievements, but I don’t feel the need to play again. Multiplayer mode may have a good amount of replay value, but I’m not a big fan of arena or deathmatch, and after seeing the really expensive season pass that was put out after release, so I don’t think I will bother playing multiplayer.

The campaign took me roughly 11.5 hours on normal mode to complete. The game was really fun, and it was an enjoyable campaign, but I feel like everything was too well lit to be scared, so I don’t really think of it as a horror game. I bought DOOM at 25% off, and I was thoroughly entertained for the entire time I played it. I have no regrets with this purchase. I highly recommend this one to any fast paced FPS fans out there.

reviewText:
DOOM is pretty cool, I guess.

Developed by Id software in 1993, DOOM was a revolutionary game that changed the way PC games would be made for the coming ye-
What?
There's a new one!?
What year is it?

DOOM (2016) is pretty cool, I guess.
You play as the Doom Guy, a very angry man who, much like me, battles with demons in strange and horrifying landscapes to stop a demonic invasion of Mars' moon of Phobos and the eventual invasion of Earth. The only difference is that Doom Guy's demons are very real and my demon is crippling drug abuse.

The interesting thing about the new Doom is that it really isn't a reboot per say, but kind of like a sequel to the events that happened at the end of DOOM 64, (By the way, someone ported DOOM 64 to the PC not too long ago, go check it out, it's kind of rad.)

Doom Guy was captured and placed in a sarcophagus by his enemies, but after being retrieved by a team of UAC soldier's led by Samuel Hayden, and a second demonic invasion occurs, Doom Guy is released from his slumber to once again rip and tear.
Rip and Tear.
Like the Doom comic.
See, I'm hip. I know things.

What transpires is a 6 to 10 hour gauntlet of murder as the Doom Guy shoots, punches, chainsaws, cooks, cleans, files taxes, and goes on cute demon dates through the UAC facility that has been over run by...60,000 some demons, I think that was the number. But the story isn't important, even Doom Guy thinks the story isn't important, he just wants to show the imps and hell barons what the inside of their heads look like. I can respect that. So lets get to the good bits.

To say it simply and like a 3rd grader. DOOM is a love letter. Not just to DOOM, but the idea of DOOM and the idea of old-school shooters in general. You don't have to reload, you run surprisingly fast, you can carry all of the weapons at once, you can find power ups, and there are secrets on every level. It doesn't just feel like DOOM, but it almost also feels like QUAKE or even other games like Blood or Daikatana.

I made that last part up. I fooled you.

The levels are wide and open and beg for you to explore to find all of their secrets and easter eggs. Each level has a set amounts of secret collectibles and rooms to find, and you're rewarded for finding them. Sometimes you get stacked up on weapons and ammo, sometimes you get max health, and sometimes you get a little toy to put up on your wall along with your anime figures you ♥♥♥♥ing nerd.

At first, I didn't like the shooting, it felt slow to me and lacked impact. But it grew on me as the game went on and they added more and more weapons to your arsenal. It's like getting one of those budget games for the PS1 back in the day and then realizing that it's actually super good later on. That or finding a burrito with only one bite in it in the trash.

Who only bites once into a burrito? A communist, that's who.

I don't know why, but I think it was just the standard shotgun for me that turned me off at first. But the other weapons all have this amazing “Oomph” every time you pull the trigger. Everything from the assault rifle to the rocket launcher look, sound, and feel like they painful. Which makes sense because they're guns.

The weapons don't only blow off  limbs,  but tear away at flesh and splatter the room with chunky bits you could probably make delicious soup with. It's this crunch behind the guns that a lot of shooters seem to lack, giving them weight and feel to them.

Though I don't know why Doom guy even uses guns, considering the amount of damage he can do with his hands. The guy should look into boxing because he punches like three dump trucks going down hill at the same time.

When you do enough damage to an enemy, you have the option of finishing them off with melee while they're stunned. No, it's not just a little Halo rifle butt or a knife from Call of Duty, get that preschool ♥♥♥♥ out of here. No, instead Doom Guy will dispose of the critter in a plethora of brutal ways from tearing off jaws, ripping off limbs, beating them to death with their own arms, or just flat out punching through their head. It's a nice change in brutality that, at least myself, am use to seeing in modern video games.

And if all else fails you can just go the lumberjack route and slice them to bits with a chainsaw. Groovy.

I will now talk about the multiplayer.




I am done talking about the multiplayer.


Should you play ROOM: The moving in?

If I have any actual complaints about Doom is that it kind of drags on near the end, and as weird as this sounds, maybe it could be a little bit more Brutal? I don't know, I just feel like there could be a bit more blood and gibs flying around, make it something soccer mom's take notice to again. Lets get back to 1999 boys, someone call of Jack Thompson, we old school controversy now.

Other than that, DOOM is a pretty intense experience. It's kind of slow at first as it gets you into the swing of things, but if you stick with it, you're in for one of the most refreshing games in a long time.

DOOM gets 4 comic book references out of a possible 3.

reviewText:
DOOM is a first-person shooter about killing demons, demons, and more demons… and try to save humanity I guess. Much like the original Doom games, not even 5 seconds in and you’re already shooting! There’s no cover system, it’s all about running around like a maniac killing everything in sight. This is what Doom 3 should've been.

+ Executions (“Glory Kills”) with over 30 different animations; similiar to brutal doom.
+ Great level design with large, well designed levels that often freely allow for backtracking.
+ Tons of secrets with early weapon unlocks and other fun things.
+ Nostalgic easter eggs, As expected from ID/Bethesda.
+ Awesome soundtrack that sticks to the roots of the series; a mix of good old metal with electronic elements.
+ Great aesthetic and visual fidelity. Not quite Frostbyte-level, but still very very good.
+ Classic pickup-based health system; no automatic regen.
+ Good enemy variety; at least 15 varieties.
+ Great weapon variety. Returning classics + some new additions, with 2 mods and a set of upgrades for each (like Wolfenstein TNO).
+ Carry all of your weapons at once and quickly switch between them (sadly not in the multiplayer).
+ No weapon reloading. I pressed R anyway for the first 30 minutes out of habit.
+ Fast load times.
+ Suit upgrades as incentive to find all the secrets.
+ Great story for a Doom game; good ending too!
+ Runs smoothly at 60+ fps. Usually held a full 60 at ultra on my R9 380.
+ No bugs, no crashes.
+ Good ol’ power-ups (Quad Damage, Haste, Invicibility, etc).
+ 10-20 Hour Campaign. Largely depending on how much long you hint for secrets.
+ 13 Doom classic levels, filled instead with the new weapons and monsters.

- OpenGL, so Steam broadcasting doesn’t work.
- No soundtrack is available to buy at the time of the review.
- Not enough bosses, though the ones there are well done.
- Functional, fast-paced Multiplayer that’s taken far too much inspiration from the likes of Call of Duty. The full game offers more variety than the beta as well as SnapMap for a touch of creativity, but the core problems and imbalances still stand.
- The Season Pass is said to only expand upon the multiplayer; I’d have loved more single-player content.

A solid addition to the Doom-series and a worthy reboot of the classic titles.
I hope we see a DOOM II!

reviewText:
After a litany of bad unpolished unoriginal games and terrible PC ports, It's fair to say DOOM rises above all the recent PC games' failures.

DOOM is a polished game that is fun, smooth, and original because it is so different from modern shooters. Have fun tearing monsters to pieces without worrying about the ethics of simulated murder because they are demons that would happily kill everyone in their sight!

Single player has a robust upgrade system that constantly gives you new toys to play with. There are challenges in the SP that incentivizes mixing your attacks up. Also, there are great rewards for exploration as well! In DOOM, there is also an automap that is clean, slick, and accessible. When I first saw the automap in one of the gameplay trailers, I knew this game was going to be polished.

Multiplayer is great fun in general. Demon runes and power weapons strike fear into your enemies' heart, you will see them cower in fear as baron of hell charges head first into a fight. Snapmap is a great map tool, you can see that the developers spent time and effort finished the game before relaasing it.

Again, everything is completely polished and well made. I never felt i missed shots because of lag in multiplayer. I have not found a single glitch in single player. Great boss fights and when played on higher difficulty, it has a sort of dark souls feel to it, even though its supposed to be a FPS!

Seriously, i can't undestand why IGN has given this a 7.1. Its simply objectively wrong when you look at what other crappy unpolished unoriginal games you can get for the same price. I have not played a more fun FPS for a long time. I felt my money was well spent on a great product. With an upgrade system, DOOM SP cannot be said to be repetitive because of the variety of attacks and tactical decision you can make in a fight. Multiplayer can be played well after the SP has ended, so the game simply has much more replayability than many SP only games we have today. In DOOM, you can go head to head with a demon horde. There are simply not any game that I can really relate to, DOOM can really stand on its own!

reviewText:
You know you’re getting old when companies try to resell the pop culture of your youth to a new generation. With all the reimaginings, reboots and sequels to stuff two decades old going on lately, you’d have to be a zen master to not experience a certain sense of weariness kicking in. It doesn’t help that those warmed up retellings tend to be utter crap.

The original Doom is the OG of first person shooters. While it wasn’t the first FPS to ever be developed, it certainly was the most influential one, popularizing both the genre and PC as a platform for games. Kids all over the world craved it like it was digital crack. Offices had to ban Doom because it decreased the productivity of the employees drastically. University networks were crippled under the sheer load of people downloading and playing the game. If you were young in the early ‘90s, you had heard of Doom. There was no way around it. And that was long before video games became as popular and common as they are now. Practically overnight, Doom made its creators millionaires.

The creators calling themselves id Software, those were just a handful of nerds fueled by their love for video games and heavy metal, both of which were reflected in their game. In Doom, the player rushed through sci-fi inspired, maze-like levels filled with hellish imagery while gunning down demons left and right. But not only your reflexes were tested: Secrets were sprinkled all over the levels. The game encouraged exploration in order to have an edge over the satanic spawn. Often it was flat-out necessary to advance since the keycards unlocking specific doors were hidden quite well. It was fast, it was gory and it was quite the looker - 3D graphics were still a novelty and Doom achieved visuals never seen before while still being relatively easy on the hardware. In a way, it started the arms race of each new game trying to one up the last one in terms of graphics that lasts to this very day.

Doom’s pop cultural impact was so huge, so undeniable, that the mere idea of a reimagining must seem like blasphemy. Much has changed since the early ‘90s. While Doom defined an entire genre in 1993, it’s just one of many first person shooters now. Other titles such as Call of Duty or Halo are considered the genre standard nowadays. The industry expanded, genre conventions changed a lot and so did the audience - not for the better, some would say. Storytelling is important now and a run and gun shooter like Doom may seem archaic in comparison. Plus, id Software is id Software in name only since none of the founding members are still working at the company. When the new Doom was announced, it had all the telltale signs of a cynical cash grab meant to sell by legacy only. Fans were worried that their holy cow would be turned into yet another generic first person shooter aping the conventions of other titles. But somehow, id Software pulled it off. They managed to do the original's roots justice.

Just so we’re clear here: id Software had some pretty big shoes to fill. So big, in fact, that nobody in his right mind could possibly expect them to make another game as revolutionary as the original Doom. The goal rather seemed to be to introduce the frantic playstyle of classic first person shooters to a new crowd possibly unfamiliar with the original. The speed, the gore, the key hunting - it’s all there. If you grew up playing FPS games in the ‘90s you will feel right at home since the progression is almost identical: You get dropped in a new area, blast every demon in sight into bloody chunks while gracefully dodging projectiles and avoiding melee attacks. Once the last demon has been slain, it’s time to search the area for ammo, health packs and everything else that might give you an edge in upcoming confrontations, or unlock that one door that’s keeping you from advancing. The levels are surprisingly layered due to a high amount of verticality - even if you use the automap frequently, chances are you will miss many secrets regardless. Then you run into the next demon horde and the cycle repeats itself. New are the designated arenas that will shower you with enemies at the push of a button, allowing for some careful planning that is pretty much mandatory at higher difficulties.

What’s in here is just as important as what’s not. There is no regenerating health, no iron sights, no limitation regarding how many weapons you can carry and no excessive amount of cutscenes. The new Doom drops you into the action and pretty much leaves you there for the entire duration of the game. However, the world has kept turning since 1993 and some adjustments are to be expected. For instance, Doom has canned instakill animations performed on stunned enemies that drop ammo and health packs, depending on how urgent you need them. And like every action game these days, it features upgrade mechanics. Most of them influence the weapons’ secondary firing modes, but some work like the bandolier pick ups from the Quake series and increase the maximum amount of health or ammo you can carry. This alone may be enough to scare off purists.

Legitimately underwhelming is the art department, be it enemies or levels. It’s by no means bad, just unremarkable. And for a game dealing with depictions of hell, the new Doom is surprisingly tame - not so much in terms of gore and more regarding disturbing imagery. Even the oh so scolded Doom 3 had twitching, vivisected men hanging from the ceiling. You will find nothing along those lines here. Also, I like to think that music played a part in the original’s success. It set the pace and pumped you up while you blew holes into the minions of hell. The new game’s industrial soundtrack is loud first and foremost and features many throwbacks to the iconic themes, but more often than not it sounds like it was created by discount Trent Reznor and loses itself in trivial creaking that doesn’t go anywhere. Additionally, the multiplayer is straight up deadweight.

So frag it like it’s ‘93? Not quite, but for the vast majority of it. Doom is definitely worth a look, whether you’re starved for a classic first person shooter or not. Apart from a few modern elements, it’s a rather accurate replication of that experience. It won’t leave a mark like the original did and it probably won’t revive oldschool twitch shooters, but it’s a fine game. Double so when taking into account how much worse it could have been.

reviewText: It's going to be fairly difficult to not fanboy the hell out of this review. My very first PC game was the shareware version of Doom, so only played the first episode. Of course, it was so brutal for its time that I became quickly obsessed with it. As soon as I heard about Doom 2 coming out, I had to have it. Played hundreds of hours of that game in both SP and MP with friends. It was a visceral experience unlike anything else of its time.\n\nPlaying this latest game is absolutely nostalgic for me, but not in just wanting it to be a fantastic game, but rather how stellar it turned out to be. The music is incredibly bass-y, shakes my entire room, and pulls me right in. The combat is very arena style: you go into a new area, there's a handful of resident enemies in there that are typically fairly simple to clear out. Then you trigger the waves upon waves of enemies and this will make you go from weapon to weapon to weapon, picking what makes sense for that second before swapping again. reviewText:
This game reminds me why I've been so cynical of many modern shooters, and reaffirmed that older ones in the 90s still have elements worth keeping now.

Doom reminds me level design can still be a thing in AAA shooters, where instead of some expensive hi fidelity walkway with some cover spots and scripted sequences...you can have verticality, jump pads, portals, and multiple paths circulating around a combat arena where I weave my dance of death.

Everything in the game has this aggressive rhythm, even down to the ways you regain health and ammo are you attacking in different ways vs. cowering for some regen.  What it does take smartly from modern shooters is offering a variety of progression, with character abilities,  weapon attachments, and weapon upgrades drip fed to you at a continuous pace.  You end up with this varied set of weapons, each with various firing modes, always accessible at any given point to use against a metric ton of different demon beasties.

Hell, it even has good boss fights, which is an FPS rarity.  I haven't had this much fun with a single-player shooter in literal years.  Play the game on Ultra-Violence difficulty, use a mouse/keyboard, turn up the music higher than any other audio in the game, and rip & tear until nothing is left.

I honestly thought I was over FPS games and haven't been interested in one - save for games like Fallout 4 which I wouldn't count - but it turns out that I was entirely wrong about my disinterest in the genre as a whole.  It wasn’t all FPS games that I was over but drab brown gritty military FPS games that have lost my interest.  Give me a twitch arena shooter like DOOM, set in a world pulled directly from my 13 year old wet dreams, and I am a kid in a candy store once again. I can't stop grinning while playing and every other second I find myself fist pumping - seriously - and saying Holy ♥♥♥♥ that was AWESOME" as I dismember another demon or pass through a portal to what can only be described as a pitch perfect recreation of my childhood fever dreams.

The graphics in this game are top notch. I'm running it on a the following:
i5-3570K (not currently overclocked)
GTX 970
16 gigs DDR3 Ram

I have all of the settings at ultra level - with the adaptive AA enabled - and it's running at 9000+ FPS. I haven't come across a single framerate drop or visual glitch/tear and I've only experienced 2 game crashes in my 16 hour playthrough of the single player campaign. I know that there are people with AMD cards

that are having troubles and my heart goes out to them. I hope that those issues are fixed soon because this is a game that should not be missed.

Graphics are beautiful and there is so much post processing going on that I've often found myself standing in awe at some of the vistas in hell wondering how there is so much smoke and particle effects going on without dropping a single frame. The lighting is perfect for setting the mood and the enemy designs and animation are top notch. Jumping up on a platform only to find an imp scramble up right behind you is a fantastic experience because you truly feel like you're being chased and running for your life.
The gameplay is a breath of fresh air which is ironic since it's due to the stripped down barebones nature of the gunplay. You fun

The versatility in the gun upgrade mechanic is a surprising plus that I did not see coming and the game is constantly dishing out upgrades and new guns to you to keep things fresh.

The sense of pace and urgency that DOOM creates sets a new gold standard for this type of twitch based arena shooter game. I hope we see a lot of copy cat games try to recreate the style of play you see in doom. I would love to have a resurgence of titles like Painkiller et al.

The level design is great in this game too. I was afraid that we'd be running down straight corridors like every other FPS on the market going from set piece to set piece when the levels in the original DOOM game were more like puzzles intricately laid out to always give the player a sense of forward momentum with plenty of progress markers and just enough backtracking to make you feel accomplished when you get that pesky yellow key and can open up a door that was previously inaccessible.

reviewText:
Doom 2016 is the right blend of action, exploration and visceral excitement. A soundtrack that booms during the high moments of combat, and one that fills the atmosphere with tension during it's slower moments. The pacing of the game is exellent, you slowly earn new weapons and meet new enemies nearly the entire game, peaking around three-quarters of the way into the experience where the final chapter lets loose everything at once. The multiplayer component is fun and fresh while still familiar, although it is currently lacking a FFA mode. The creative aspects of snapmap seem plentiful, but the mapper has its own sets of limitations that prevent it from reaching the sky high hopes we had for it in order to compensate for lack of modding tools.

Overall the game has such a well designed Campaign that it stands strong with that aspect alone. The multiplayer and snapmap modes are both fun and add additional content, but lack the same polish of the campaign mode and both are delivered on day one with some dissapointing qualities.

DOOM is back, and its single player mode is worth the price of entry alone.

A+
5 Stars
9.5/10

reviewText:
It's an arena shooter.

I'm not kidding. You basically get locked inside of rooms filled with ammo, health, and usually a powerup or two. Demons spawn in order of ascending difficulty as grungy metal music kicks in, and you have to kill them to unlock the doors so you can walk down some corridors and head to the next arena. The game consists of doing this about 40 times. You very rarely get to navigate hostile terrain and pick off enemies from a distance like in retro Doom, and when you do, it's mostly just zombies.

But hell, this game is fun. It takes what worked from Doom 3, and replaces everything else with solid homages to the original Doom. The crazy colorful environments with cliffs and steep drops are back. The frantic fights with a dozen enemies at once are back.

Interestingly, for the first time in Doom history, none of the enemies are given weapons with bullets (the chaingunners even fire energy spheres), meaning that you never have to hide behind cover and you can stay alive just by your dodging skills alone.

Also, there is no reload button. All your weapons automatically reload themselves and most don’t even have a cooldown, meaning you can just keep firing until you’re out of ammo. That’s about as awesome as it sounds.

Amazingly, someone must have realized that Hell was the best part of Doom 3, and this game sends you there not once, but three times. I especially loved the "Necropolis level which was almost pure fanserivce to classic Doom in ways I don't dare spoil.

But probably best of all

reviewText: Doom is a good shooter comprised of three separate parts. The campaign is an enjoyable trip down memory lane as it replicates the basic formula that was prevalent two decades ago. With good level design, potent weaponry and smoothly-animated demons, its individual action pieces are stellar. Unfortunately the arena encounter formula persists right until the end, becoming too repetitive. Multiplayer is a competent mix of old and new that brings the hell-themed action close to that of other modern shooters. Finally, SnapMap gives players a fairly powerful set of tools to make simple creations in minutes. Doom’s relentless emulation of its predecessors creates the fire that complements its modern-day brimstone.\n\nRead full review[www.newgamenetwork.com]

reviewText:
[THIS IS A SINGLE-PLAYER CAMPAIGN ONLY REVIEW]
DOOM, A.K.A. Doom 4 or Doom 2016; very much like the original Doom that gave birth to the firer-person shooter genre back in 1993 - once again taking old players back to face their nemesis, dragging them into the demonic abyss where not much is spoken as no words would suffice; rather, you're slipped into a whole body armor and grabbed yourself a shotgun. *Rack it* One in the chamber - or was it two? And off your way to prove actions are louder than words.


For relatively new players who're now used to softcore shooter games that allow harms to be avoid entirely courtesy of cover-based mechanic, easy target acquisition courtesy of aiming simulation and helath lost resulted from mistake can be forgiven with overtime health regeneration - DOOM may be the very title to grant you the long awaited refreshing experience by throwing you back to the purest, simplest root of FPS: Shooting & Moving - with some welcomed additions such as collectibles to find, secrets to discover, challenges to complete, progress bars to fill and a whole arsenal to upgrade to add extra layers of depths as well as replayability.


For veteran players out there... there really isn't much to say about this game. I mean, what could I say more? DOOM simply puts you back to the mix where you-know-for-god-damn-sure carnage, demon, gore, fast-paced combat, reloadless firing and powerful metal music are the least expected things to find. The normal difficulty level named 'HURT ME PLENTY' gives you a gentle yet fair taste of these elements whereas the higher difficulties 'ULTRA-VIOLENCE' and 'NIGHTMARE' will force you to flow through the oppressing offensives - or die trying to move your feet, take your aim and utilize up to 20 different means all seamlessly and constantly in order to beat the hostile confrontation.


Verdict: I'd say not only does DOOM fulfils longtime fans' nostalgic desire to feel the classic formula in today's shooter game market that's been decorated miscellaneously with all sorts of gimmicks for the past several years, its latest iteration brought itself to the next level with two decades gap as the industry develops and the technology that powers it advances - to the point where we could never imagine or experience back in the 90s. Just like the first game back then, the gameplay of DOOM is smooth and fast, straightforward and intuitive, and above all an awful lot of fun and engaging as each arena gets increasingly more intense than the last -- yet it may has become even more enjoyable and polished with two decades of advancement in the videogame industry in general.



Footnote: I believe you've watched the E3 reveal gameplay trailer before you're off your way to probing with a review like this. I'm telling you right now - the actual gameplay is faster and more intense by two folds to say the least, given you don't pick the difficutly level named 'I’M TOO YOUNG TO DIE'.

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of the Doom and Quake games and loved this game.  Lately I've avoided FPS games because of what I've been calling 'lack of innovation in the genre'.  It took playing this game for me to realize what I've been missing from modern shooters.  Chaos.  It's been missing the chaos.   The single player is the best single player experience I've had in an FPS since probably the original Doom.  The story is not a super duper unique one but it is not a hindrance to the gameplay and it is pretty cool.

My biggest complaints are the fact that there is no out of the box: Free for all deathmatch mode in the multiplayer, this has been partially addressed with SnapMap as there are several enjoyable FFA maps people have already created, however SnapMap has it's own limitations.

In all honestly, my #1 complaint about this game is that it ended.  The campaign is by no means short, it's actually quite long for a modern FPS (probably around the same time to complete as the original half life), but I wasn't ready for it to be over. I just want more because of how fun it was. I hate the general concept of DLC but if id releases any SP content via expansions or DLC I will buy it immediately.

Definitely pick this game up, the SP is refreshing and the MP is also very enjoyable and is somewhere between Arena Shooter and Modern Shooter.

reviewText:
Id Software have been in a slump, with every game taking years and years to come out, without the same spark they were known for in the 90s. But this Doom gives me hope. They’re on the right track, as this is different from any other action game out there. They’re finally back trying to carve their own path in the FPS space, borrowing elements from every id game that has come before it.

This Doom isn’t just looking back at what made the old Doom games good. It’s borrowing bits and pieces from all the Quake games, and adding the obligatory RPG mechanics present in all shooters today. At a glance the game doesn’t look very exciting, as it looks very similar to Doom 3 and Dead Space. It’s a brand of sci-fi aesthetic that’s way too familiar at this point. But when you get a couple levels into the campaign you start coming across vertical arenas, where combat takes place on multiple levels, with enemies following you everywhere. This is where Doom starts to make sense. And once you get to the good bits, it just keeps getting better. This isn't simply an “old school” game that does the same things as the classics of the genre. It's taking their elements and moving forwards. Calling it old school almost does a disservice for what they've managed to do here.

The level design of Doom displays good variety, with some levels having multi-level vertical arenas that feel like they belong in a multiplayer game, while other levels have simple tight corridors. Not all the levels are great, but they have a high average level of quality, and the truly great levels more than make up for the ones that are just okay. Most importantly, it didn't feel repetitive. Anything good can outstay its welcome, and this game mixes things up enough over the course of the campaign to justify its length.

The biggest problem I had with the game is the audio. It’s primitive and simplistic in a way that isn’t worthy of the quality of game design and animation. In first person shooters, the audio is critical in communicating where enemies are, what weapons they’re using, and how they’re moving. In all games, audio expands your field of view beyond the borders of the screen. In Doom, enemies are too silent, and don’t have enough character. By listening, it’s hard to tell which enemies are in the arena with you, or where they are. This led to me being blindsided by enemies hitting me from behind. It added an unpleasant element of random chance. If you can’t use the sound as a weapon against the enemy, there’s a limit to how good you can get at the game. It creates a skill ceiling that you can never breach. It’s unfortunate, because in so many ways Doom is state of the art, or breaks new ground. It isn’t all bad, as the music is very fitting, with neat touches like guitar riffs that match the pace of your weapon as its firing. But I still found the audio to be a letdown.

Overall, my impression of Doom is overwhelmingly positive. The first two levels were mediocre, and the audio disappointed me. But once the game got going, it won me over. It’s more than good enough to conquer its deficiencies and convince me that it’s a game I should be recommending to people. It proves that id Software know what they’re doing, and makes me excited to see what they do next. It’s easily my favorite FPS released in ages. It reminded me why I like the genre in the first place. It’s easy to forget when all you get every year is co-op RPG hybrids or military shooters. This is the kind of shooter very few people bother to make anymore, and I want to celebrate how well they managed to pull it off. The multiplayer is terrible though, so don’t get the game for that. The developer’s focus was clearly on the singleplayer, and it’s for that the game will be remembered.

reviewText:
You know what I love more than this game? Reading reviews and comments of people that says this isn't like the original, that is repetitive, and not that good of a game. Because everything they say is total BS, this is as loyal to the original games as a 2016 title can get. And this is not that easy of task as you might think.

The pace, the atmosphere, the music, the weapons, the enemy variation, the big levels filled with secrets, almost every aspect of the game just screams Doom. Except maybe from the generous checkpoint system the game is old school in every other way, with no regenerating health, no cover system, no limit in the amount of weapons you can carry.

Even in the lower difficulties (I recommend picking at least the highest available at the beginning) the game never lets you rest during battles, not only you can't take cover, Doom punishes you if you even think about it. Sniping enemies from afar is also a temporary solution since you run out of ammo really fast, especially in the early stages. The game almost forces you to get up and personal with you enemies since the only way to get health and ammo (besides the items scattered around each area) is to either kill them with your bare hands or with your trusty chainsaw. It's a clever mechanism that keeps the action furious and frantic even on the first couple of stages.

The guns in Doom are as fun to use as they were in the first two titles (no more crappy shotty or machine gun as in Doom 3). Most of them really pack a punch and are extremely fun to use (except maybe the pistol, but you only have to rely on it for a couple of minutes before picking a shotgun). Not only that but you can upgrade all of them giving them even more destructive power. But wait... there's more! Not only you can add great secondary attacks on your weapons, you can upgrade them even more, with skill points you gather during each stage either by completing challenges, finding secrets or simply by being awesome at disposing your enemies.

I can keep writing positive things about the game for hours but it's time to talk about the negative stuff as well. Well, mediocre multiplayer aside, the visuals can be a little bland at times (the new engine seems capable of far more eye candy) and... well that's about it. People claiming the game get's repetitive towards the end, probably never played this type of a game before where the meat of the game is the combat and don't rely on cut scenes and set pieces to keep your attention. If you get tired from running and gunning everything in sight while searching for collectibles and secrets, then why on earth did you even bother buying Doom?

I can't recommend the new Doom enough. It shows that an old school title not only can be made without any issues in 2016 but also there is a crowd that really craves for one. Maybe the new Rise of Triad was too old school  and Shadow Warrior not that known to jump start the old school shooter revival, but finally after countless gray, corridor, hold you by your hand"
recommended: we have a game that not only gets what made the old titles great but also adds enough modern touches to make it appealing to people who only knew Doom from the crappy Dwayne Johnson movie."

reviewText:
i've been playing doom since i was four years old in 1994 when my brother showed me the shareware version that came with our new computer. i've been hooked ever since.

at first, i was very cynical of this game, pre-release. why wouldn't i be? doom has had a hellish (heh) dev cycle with multiple versions canned for a variety of reasons, numerous instances of staff leaving id and overall a super bad scene from all evidence that was given. the e3 demo helped a lot to dissuade me from writing this off, but even then i felt uneasy. what if it's super rote? what if there is no soul?

i'm not sure how they did it, but id was able to bring back doom in the best way possible. this is a game that oozes confidence and knows exactly what it wants to be. it's not as groundbreaking for FPS as doom was back in 1993, but as it stands, this is my favorite FPS of 2016. now, it's important to note that this review is based entirely on the singleplayer campaign. i touched snapmap briefly and was left disappointed and the multiplayer felt very...standard and I wasen't impressed. so if you are comfortable with spending $60 on an extremely good single player campaign that lasts for around 10 hours, read on!

now, why is a remake of doom in 2016 possibly my FPS GOTY? let me count the ways:

1. the combat: while a fair chunk of the combat is regulated to closed-off arenas, the gameplay never feels anything less then super good and empowering as hell. doom approaches platinium games-level of fluidity and mobility, and the guns are super satisfying to use and have a, frankly astonishing, level of depth to them. i finished the game not even touching the rocket launcher, for example, only for a friend to tell me how much they used it and the scenarios it was super helpful in, and other friends have told me about other combat strategies they employ and each one of them is super different.

2. the personality and story: if you had told me that doom in 2016 would have lore and story that was legitmately interesting, i would have laughed in your face. but, again, i was proven wrong. while the story is nowhere near as good as something like The New Order was, it's an extremely entertaining and goofy story. i won't spoil anything, but there were moments where i caught myself laughing out loud at how bizarre, terrifying and ludicrous the UAC facility gets the deeper you go. also, the doomguy himself has an astonishing amount of personality just in the way he performs certain actions in the game. he never speaks, but we get a very clear sense of who he is and what he stands for, which is something that i never thought would be an element of a doom game.

3. the music and sound design: mick gordon returns from TNO and Killer Instinct to compose the soundtrack from doom and it is amazing. atmospheric and unsettling during quiet moments, loud and violent during not-so-quiet moments. the moment the soundtrack is released, i'll be getting it immediately. the sound design is also very well done, with super satisfying weapon discharges, grotesque demonic noises and the disturbing ambient hum of the UAC facility itself.

there is also an astonishing amount of replay value, with my 10 hour campaign not even scratching the surface of all the challenges, unlockables and secrets hidden in the game. this is absolutely a game to play through more then once!

this is a game that is worth every penny.

also, this was played on a i5 4670k with a GTX 970 4GB card and 8GB of ram and it was silky smooth on ultra settings except for the occasional hiccup every now and then from the crappy mechanical drive i had it installed on. i encountered very few issues, except for some annoying silent CTD's in Titan's Realm that I'm sure will be patched sooner rather then later.

it brings me great pleasure to tell you that doom in 2016 is extremely good.

reviewText:
DOOM:
~~~~~~

The UAC (Union Aerospace Corporation) created a state of the art research facility on Mars. Unfortunately, this superb establishment has been overrun by an army of ferocious demons! You are the only marine left on the red planet and the UAC has no other option but to activate you with the sole mission to eradicate all demons from the site. Let’s face it, this mission is suicidal . . . it is DOOM!

Doom is an action/first person shooter game where you take control of the last marine on the UAC research centre on Mars. You will wake up chained to what looks like an operating table, and within a few seconds you will realise that you are not the only one in the room. Menacing sounds are coming from your left, your right - actually from all around you! You free yourself, grab a gun on the floor and eliminate all enemies with sheer ferocity. Your next step is to find and equip yourself with a Preator suit - you will need it - it is going to be a brutal ride!

In the campaign mode, you will go through stunning and well-designed levels with plenty of demons to kill. I personally enjoy killing them when they are in the stunned state (glowing orange) with your bare hands - absolutely marvellous!  Each level has secret areas, items to find (check your map for hints) and challenges to meet. If you manage to locate a ruin, you will be able to activate a new challenge to succeed and keep a piece of the ruin.  Make sure to look everywhere, as there are a number of objects to collect:  Preator tokens (which can be found on fallen marines) so you can upgrade your suit, ammunition crates, shield plates (well, that’s what I call them), health icons and, of course, weapons. A little harder to find are the agent cells which can upgrade your character’s following skills – health, armour or ammunition.  The fun really starts when you find a “Gore Nest”- rip its heart out and a wave of demons will appear in the area. Sometimes you might notice an orb - pick it up and you will receive an extra boost in battle. I really like the Berserk Orb - just great to clear the area! If you succeed in eliminating all these nasty creatures you will receive an upgrade point; accumulate enough of these points and you can upgrade your weapons.

The multiplayer mode is also available in DOOM, but I find it really hard to get into a match, which is a bit disappointing. There is good character customization, however.

Graphically the game is superb, with a great voice over as well as a great soundtrack and sound effects. In regards to the controls, I strongly recommend the mouse and keyboard - I find it easier, but it’s always a personal choice.

There are a couple of issues that you might encounter while playing DOOM. The first one is setting your video resolution (bear in mind, I have the latest Nvidia driver installed). The game keeps launching in a window mode for some reason, even after applying full screen on the setting. Then I have to lower the resolution to get back to my full screen and re-apply to a higher resolution. The second issue is the crashes to desktop. You might be able to play for 3 hours without an issue but then the game will crash for no apparent reason. It seems that people have been experiencing the same issue with a wide range of PC setups (crashes).

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Stunning graphics
-	Gore violence (it is DOOM, after all)
-	Well-designed levels with plenty of hidden objects and secret areas
-	Great range of demons and arsenal
-	Fun and fast gameplay
-	Good soundtrack and voice over
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Hard to get into a multiplayer game
-	Frequent crashes to desktop
-	Resolution bug is a pain in the D…

Overall, I really enjoyed the game and all fans of DOOM and FPS should have this game in their library.

8/10

reviewText:
Surprisingly good, played through the whole campaign on nightmare and hunted every secret. While it isn't 100% true to the originals it still manages to remain Doom-esque in level design and enemy/weapon interactions (Preferring to use some weapons against certain enemies but not others, etc). The melee kill animations can fairly safely be ignored (Enemies drop health, but on nightmare the guaranteed health from a melee kill is negligible at 5 points, and the large health drops from kills happen if you're low on health and still happen from ranged kills too) or even smoothed into the gameplay with the rune system, which lets you speed the animations up to practically the point of the Doom 1 and 2 punch animation.

The multiplayer isn't the worst thing ever made but it isn't particularly good or noteworthy. Since you pick which weapons you start with all the weapons have been equalized for balance, there's no frantically running around the map to grab the rocket launcher when everyone can spawn with one and it does piddly damage since it has to be equivalent to everything else.

Snapmap has some cool potential, but since it's based around the MP rather than the SP there's a 2 weapon limit and the players can't pick a difficulty level, the map designer has to specifically set enemy HP, damage, etc. It also has a god-awful search system to try to find maps, so you'll have a hell of a time finding ones that look interesting. Not nearly as powerful as a full editor but some good may come of it at some point.

Overall really damn good. I still enjoyed Doom 3, but this is far closer to Doom 1 and 2 than 3 was. Not really going to be a landmark shooter still regularly played and modded 20+ years later, but what is?

reviewText:
In a word, Fantastic! They have managed to capture the essence of what made Doom great all those years ago, but now with incredible visuals, an amazing soundtrack that fits so well, gameplay upgrades that allow you to customise your character, suit and weapons, and new mechanics that force you to get in close to your enemies to give you back health or ammo.  On top of that there are plenty of heart-racing, frantic, gore-filled sections with tougher enemies progressively getting introduced, many of which are familiar from Doom 1 & 2.

I took about 20 hours to complete the campaign, but that included spending a fair amount of time trying to find all the secrets and additional challenges.  I still have a couple of secrets to find, plus weapon challenges to complete and will definitely be going back in to complete those.

I have only tried the multiplayer deathmatch experience in beta so far, I wasn't that impressed by it and isn't something that I will be spending much time in, as I prefer a more tactical team-based fps such as Counter-Strike or Battlefield.  I will give it another go and try out the new modes and maps however.

I had a quick look at SnapMap which allows you to create your own content for the game, and will be interested to see what the community comes up with which may give extra replayability to come.

To summarise, if you are interested in a heart-pounding, fast-paced single player experience without too much in the way of a storyline, then I would definitely recommend getting this.

reviewText:
aaaahhhh... Doom. The game that made me a PC Gamer for life. There is NOTHING i can say about this game that has not already been said. The single player campaign is for sure the best game that has come out this year, and to be honest its probably the best FPS in recent years hands down. The pace is breakneck, the graphics are astounding, the soundtrack is phenomonal. Nearly everything you remember about Doom is here.

I want to say this now. This review does not reflect my feelings of the multiplayer portion of the game. It feels tacked on, it feels like its a seperate game and to me it doesnt feel like Doom. Two staples of Doom are completely missing from the multiplayer portion of Doom, and if it were a seperate game it is bad enough that i would not buy it. Co-op and free for all deathmatch are completely missing from this game. Doom multiplayer was built on these two modes and them both being missing is a travesty.

That being said, the SP mode is where this game shines, and oh boy does it shine! The story is a bit lacking for sure, but Doom never really had a whole lot of story anyways, so nothing really missing in this catagory. The gameplay is fast and frantic. On harder difficulties if you stop moving you are DEAD. There is a great variety of demons, both old and new, and the models for them all are spectacular. All your favorite Doom weapons have returned, and most of them are upgradeable. The weapon models themselves (like all other models in the game) are fantastic. Though i have not played through the entire game, what i have seen so far of the backgrounds are beautiful, and the textures have alot of variety.

All in all this game is a must purchase for any fan of Doom, any fan of arena shooters or honestly any fan of FPS games in general. There is nothing on the market that compares, and i feel it will be quite awhile before something does compare.

reviewText:
Genre - FPS shooter with some character progression

About me - I was not a massive fan of the original DOOM games. Ifound single player repetitive and was never good enough to compete.

So I purchased this game after reading through various reviews. I have now finished the single player camapign on the easiest mode, attempted to make a snap map but failed, and also been pwned on multiplayer.

I actually think this is the first DOOM game I can say I enjoyed for any length of time. The campaign is simplistic in style. You fight waves of enemies with the resources available and a few puzzles are thrown in along the way (only a few are irritating as I am not a fan of timed jumping). The story is as good as the source material allows and actually had me thinking back to Dead Space, which was a great game.

It looks great and the combat is fluid with finishing moves added for extra coolness. The weapons are what you would expect, but this time around you can upgrade your alternate fire and also pick up a few perks and armour upgrades. I think this sort of stuff is required to add re-playability, and also to allow some degree of customisation depending on your play style. This reminded me of Shadow Warrior, which was another re-boot that was also done very well.

People have complained about the length of the campaign. It took me about 12 hours on the easiest mode and I have been back a bit to look for secrets and missed upgrades.

However, this is only one part of the game. The snap maps have been criticised for being too simplistic. However, I think this is good as levels will be designed within a specific framework. They could maybe add more features if there is high demand though. I did attempt it but realised that I need to read up or watch some videos before doing this properly.

The multiplayer deathmatch seemed fun although I was clearly awful at it. You can choose weapons at the strat and customise your look. You unlock things as you play more. Again this is needed to bring players back for more, even though some purists like a good whinge.

I think the game is another great example like Shadow Warrior before it of how to re-boot early FPS games for the current generation, and those of us from the previous generation who found them a bit dull after a while.

After the MP beta I was ready to scrap DooM from my wishlist - good thing I did not do that! They did it. They actually pulled it off - the Doom is mostly black with even more gore and speed! DooM is back baby.

reviewText:
I regard this new DOOM as a faithful return to the original franchise. Obviously it’s not going to be exactly the same, as the original game is far from perfect. With a lot of reboot franchises, the core of the game is usually lost, but this isn’t the case with DOOM.

Id Software have really poured their heart and soul into making this reboot as amazing as it could be, and then some. It reminds me of the original games, yet introduces new and interesting gameplay features that keep it up to date with modern games. It’s a perfect blend of old school meets new school. The new Id Tech 6 engine is one of the most impressive engines I’ve seen. Both in terms of graphics and performance. Granted my PC is above the recommended specs, but I’ve heard it performs well on a variety of systems. The performance was “unchained” essentially, and my computer could be fully utilized to give the best experience possible. Id clearly haven’t forgotten their roots.

The shooting is enjoyable and punchy. Each gun has 2 distinctly different weapon mods to unlock, which add a decent amount of variety to the combat. 2 weapon mods per gun doesn’t seem like much, but they change the way a weapon behaves in such drastic ways. Each stand out on their own, and by the end of the game I had unlocked all of them, and felt comfortable no matter which I was using.

Glory kills are another new gameplay feature. Fast and fluid melee executions that add serious variety to traditional fps gameplay. Originally I thought these would slow down the pace of the combat, but I can safely say I was wrong. They add brutality and enjoyment to an already brutal and enjoyable game :P

The multiplayer is satisfying to an extent. At first glance people assume it was a tack on, but looking into it further you can tell Id have really put some effort into this area. The amount of customization is insane. From acquiring different armour types, to changing the material and colours of your weapons. The gameplay is pure old-school Quake III, slightly slowed down and missing a few features though. Definitely worth your time if you have any interest in faster paced multiplayer.

The integrated SnapMap tool (used for building your own levels and sharing with others), offers a lot more on top of the single player and multiplayer, but sadly the limitations are far too obvious. Clearly it was a tool built with consoles in mind, hence the limited objects, and options. You can only have 10 demons spawned at once, and the building space is far too small. I really wish they would have removed these limitations on the PC version, but sadly I don’t see it happening any time soon. Still, SnapMap is a fun extra, to an already great game.

Buy DOOM, it’s worth every penny.

reviewText: The game itself is amazeballs, pure no-nonsense fps hell-gore galore, and quite possibly the best Doom game. But after a dozen or so freezes requiring hard reboots and CTDS happening within a few hours in the latter part of the game, I can't recommend it in this state. It's absolutely unacceptable that this has not been addressed and patched properly almost a month after launch. It's happening to many customers, and it's about time we let our complaints affect the ratings negatively. Everybody's slamming Homefront: The Revolution for being a trainwreck of a buggy mess, so it's only fair that somebody speaks truth to power about how having to do hard reboots because load screens freezes, or suddenly suffering a CTD right before you would've killed the last Baron of Hell very much indeed detracts from the experience. I didn't buy this game to fool around with debugging all possible variables that might be causing crashes.
