reviewText:
DOOM is a really legendary franchise, perfecting the First Person Shooter formula back in 1993 when it was released. Being a huge part of my childhood, when the new DOOM game was announced I was bouncing left and right, trying to contain my excitement. When I saw the first trailers and gameplay mechanics, I was kind of skeptical about how the new game will work off with health and ammo drops when you kill enemies, but to my surprise it works amazingly. Let me explain a little bit more.

So the new DOOM is what it tries to be, a new DOOM game for the new gaming generation. Based off the first two games of the franchise, DOOM and DOOM II: Hell on Earth it brings itself to the modern day really well. Gameplay is fast paced and full of action just like its predecessors. You can carry all the guns you pick up along the way and upgrade them through fighting hordes of demons or finding secrets to make your demon slaying even more gorey and effective.

Introduced new into the gameplay is the Glory Kill system, which will allow you to make a gorey kill move against any demon that you have done enough damage to and rip off their head, guts, heart or legs! There's multiple animations for these actions so you won't be seeing the same kill animation over and over again too often. Performing these kill moves on the demons makes them drop health and ammo for you to pick up making the killing smooth and fun with your guns or fists alike.

New enemies are introduced as well and I must say they fit to the DOOM franchise amazingly well and are a welcomed add to the bunch of the old foes that we meet along the way and God, don't get me started on the graphics. The environments in the game look really believable and beautiful to look at. I was in awe of the detail and beauty of the scenery wanting to explore everything you see along the way.

Which brings me to the secrets. They're scattered all over the game for you to find and they usually reward you really well from weapons to powerups, so exploration is always rewarded in multiple ways.

The game is challenging and fun to go through. Every difficulty from the old games are present and a new hardest difficulty Ultra-Nightmare is introduced as well. Never beat nightmare mode on the originals and I bet I won't beat them on this game either!

Even if I give this game a lot of praise, couple of things did bother me.

First off the Cyberdemon's design since the first trailer didn't leave a huge impact on me for being the most iconic DOOM monster in the series. The new redesign of the character makes him look cool, but not intimidating like he was in the originals. Even in DOOM 3 I felt intimidated by him. He was a rewarding boss in the old games, but for some reason I didn't get the same feeling when I beat him in the new DOOM. This is of course a personal opinion and I don't expect people to agree with me, but to me the big badass demon from the old games should have intimidated me and make me feel threatened at least once. This Cyberdemon didn't do it for me.

I love most of the music in the game, but some of the industrial metal setting does get a bit repetetive. There's some nice easter eggs in the music having snips of old DOOM songs here and there, but the industrial sound doesn't bring them out too well. It feels too much like Quake and that is not what DOOM's about. Quake is a great game series, but industrial metal in my opinion doesn't belong in DOOM. Good old rock 'n' roll and old school metal does. Again, my opinion and no one needs to agree with me.

Otherwise I'd say DOOM is a must pick for any DOOM fan out there and I personally would give the game about 8.5/10 rating myself. It's a great reboot of an old classic bringing the good old FPS action to the new gaming generation and who knows, get interested the old games as well.

reviewText:
#### WARNING, LONG REVIEW ####

Title: DOOM
Genre: Action
Developer: id Software
Publisher: Bethesda Softworks
Release Date: 13 May, 2016

Copy was purchased.

---------------------------------------------------------

DOOM is back with all the action and gore that we love, and on a brand new engine!

You had me worried for a second there Bethesda. Not giving out review copies prior to a game's release is normally a sign of a publisher trying to cover up that their game maybe isn't all that great, and they would like to get as many people purchasing before reviews are out. Thankfully, DOOM is everything that I hoped it would be, even if I did doubt that it would be.

DOOM is on a new engine, id Tech 6 and it runs very well. I managed to get a consistent frame rate, and the game looked amazing. id Tech 6 also doesn't have that texture pop-in annoyance that id Tech 5 had, which is always great.

Within seconds of starting the game up, you are straight into the action and shooting hell monsters right in their skulls. DOOM knows it is not a game that will have an award-winning story, and id Software play that to their strengths by making this 100% awesome gameplay. This shows heavily when there are scenes where characters are clearly trying to give the game a story with more in-depth character development, but the protagonist, Doomguy, just doesn't care.  Instead, Doomguy will just choose to ignore character/story progression and conversation by smashing computers giving messages, or by smashing communication units from people telling him what to do. You don't tell Doomguy what to do, his only job is destruction.

Aside from the starting pistol, all weapons feel like they pack a punch. You are given the pistol when you first start the game, and that may lead some people to think negatively of the game as the pistol doesn't feel good to use at all. However, before you can even begin to rage, you  will be given the shotgun. The shotgun feels and sounds wonderful. Weapon customising is big in DOOM, each weapon has two trees that you can unlock and it's not an 'either or choice', you can pick both and all of the upgrades, and even swap between the changes with ease. Want your machine gun to fire rockets? Sure thing. Want to turn your Chaingun into a mobile turret? Of course! As well as giving benefits that change what the gun can do, you also unlock benefits that can improve the stats, e.g. reload faster or decrease ammo cost. To unlock the last upgrade for each weapon, you will need to complete a challenge. The challenge will depend on the gun and the upgrade, but they are generally things such as 'Hit 4 enemies with Micro Missiles in 5 seconds'. This will then unlock the ability to be able to fire as many missiles as you have the ammo for.

The main problem with creating a game like this is that you want it to be modern and fresh, but you also don't want to ♥♥♥♥ off the core players that loved the original game. The enemy design in DOOM (2016) pays homage to the original in a lovely way, they have been heavily updated, changed and modernised, but you still look at them and know exactly what they looked like in the original game. The enemies still look like hell demons, and that is what you want in a DOOM game. They are also all squishy and full of blood, so when you shoot or rip them apart, lots of blood and gibs will splash out like a fountain.

That still doesn't change the fact that lots has been changed in this new version of the game when compared to the original. You can look up and down, you can jump and even double jump! The main issue I had before the game was released was that I was worried that the 'Glory Kills' feature would spoil the 'DOOM-esque' vibe and make it too much like every other FPS we currently have on the market. Luckily, that isn't the case. For all those not familiar with DOOM's 'Glory Kills', this is when an enemy is on low health, you can melee them brutal way with a quick animation. The enemy will then drop more ammo and health. When games generally add animations to things like this, once you have seen it a couple of times then you cannot be bothered to keep seeing them again. For me, I have not grown tired of them. They are extremely quick animations that does not slow down the gameplay or leave you vulnerable to an attack. Even though you will continue seeing the same animation again and again, they still always look great. For those that do not want to see these glory kill animations, you do have the option for turning them off.

Level design has always been a major part of the old school FPS games. Remember that joke picture that showed level design in old FPS games and it being an intricate maze, and then it showed modern FPS games and it was a single corridor filled with cut scenes? DOOM is most definitely the former. The levels have been wonderfully designed, full of secrets and easter eggs such as the ability to jump into and play the original doom but with the new weapons (Like in Wolfenstein The New Order). I hunted high and low for secrets as I was playing, but there were still plenty that I have missed and will need to go back and try to find them. There were also times that I found switches that I turned and I didn't have a clue where the door was that must have opened. Fans of exploration will love the little hidden things you can do and find, and people who do not like this can just choose to run right past it all and continue killing.

Campaign length always comes into question. DOOM took me around 10 hours to complete on 'Hurt me plenty' difficulty, this was with many secrets and other items missed that I will go back and see if I can collect them all. Once the game has been completed once, this will unlock 'Nightmare' and 'Ultra-nightmare' difficulty. Nobody at id Software has completed the game at 'Ultra Nightmare', this is because the enemies pack a serious punch, and I mean that one enemy can easily kill you quicker than you can turn around to say hello. Is that all? No of course not. Once you die, sorry, game over. Yep, this is permadeath, once you die you have to start from the very beginning again. A marker will be placed in the area you died, so you can wave to where you previously died. I tried this difficulty mode. I failed this difficulty mode. I'm not generally one for re-playing games again, but with DOOM, I definitely will. I enjoyed all 10 hours that I put into the campaign that I will not be replaying it dreading a certain part of the game (except for maybe some of the boss fights when at a harder difficulty).

Multiplayer was the part that seemed to have been focused on prior to the release of DOOM. The beta was a multiplayer only beta, that frankly I just didn't really enjoy that much. Now that the full game is out and I put more time into the multiplayer, it is starting to grow on me. I mainly play 'Freeze tag' as I loved that in Quake II, but there is a variety of game modes to suit everyone....

##### Review is too long for Steam, to read the rest, please go to https://www.ordinarygamer.co.uk/2016/05/15/doom-review/ #####

reviewText:
Due to the limitations of Steam review word length, the full review can be found here: DOOM Review[medium.com]

Listen up Marine…it’s time to learn FPS all over

The FPS genre is generously flexible, allowing shooters to have their own distinct identity while essentially being the same concept across a multitude of games. This led to a lot of experimentation, as every developer wanted their game to stand out from the pack. It is more true now than it was ever before as market is fierce. If you don’t stand out, you might as well simply be wasting your time making the game. This experimentation in the early years led to a lot of cool FPS games. However, after a certain point of experimentation, it began to lose its own identity as a genre. It was never more so prevalent since the last console generation. The genre was forced to do too many things at once, the weight upon which was felt by the pillars of the FPS foundation, which sometime after, ultimately collapsed. This is a big reason why I eventually grew fonder of RPG games, but again one can argue the genre is also suffering the same problems as of late. The FPS genre desperately needed some clear perspective of what it should try to accomplish and what it should leave behind. It needed a clean slate… a reboot…enter DOOM.

DOOM of 2016 briskly severs all the ties it had with the previous game and drops every unnecessary alteration and went straight back to the basics. What makes a FPS enjoyable in the first place? -- The shooting mechanics of course, with little to no barrier between you and what you see on screen. For the DOOM reboot the id software guys-- just like another Bethesda studio behind the wonderful reboot of Wolfenstein-- nailed the feel of the first person shooting. It’s a pure delight just shooting whatever monstrosity moves. Here the level design gives players complete freedom to go crazy with their reclaimed ability to shoot, move and jump effortlessly. Movement and shooting were what made FPS a longstanding genre and it is great to see the id software acknowledging it. The shooting feels like smooth as silk. In fact, I’ll use a quote from id artist as it describes it perfectly, it “feel like Bruce Lee with a shotgun on a skateboard.

DOOM doesn't mess around. It literally grabs the narrative and throws it against the corner of the wall. There is a very lose narrative on top of DOOM. Normally I would have used the word ‘tying’ with ‘narrative’

reviewText:
In short, they absolutely nailed it.

I was quite pessimistic over this game. Then I got to play it and holy crap yes! Doom doesn't shove down some BS story down your throat, you wake up and imediately start shooting demons around you. Combat feels quick, you never stand in one place because that get's you killed pretty fast. From first level onwards I found myself running around the level, shooting anything that moves, jumping on higher ground while grabbing health/ammo/armor desperately trying to stay alive.

What was probably the most positive surprise is the level design. You are not just thrown into a linear corridor after linear corridor like in Doom 3, instead you get open large levels quite similar to original games. Also yes, there are numerous secrets to be found, I think I missed 6 in second level alone.

What I thought I would hate were the glory kills, however they are quite quick to pull off and keep the pace up by giving you some extra health (which you will need on higher difficulties). Perhaps the game relies too much on this system, them again whenever you take damage it is 100% your own fault, almost any source of damage can be avoided by a skillfull player. This doesn't make the game easy though, UV is definitely giving me a run for my money.

reviewText: Dev mode.  It needs fixing.  Existing saves need to be un-flagged.  Bethesda and id need to release a patch for this, rather than brazenly advising people to delete their saves and start all over again in the off chance that this will resolve the issue.  Most likely it won't, since the game is also crashing to desktop for a lot of players, leading to corrupted files which apparently are triggering this developer mode without the player doing anything (as if pressing ` should justifiably wreck people's save files, considering it's kind of an id game standby — let alone F12, which is the default screenshot key for players on Steam).  They need to understand that nobody wants to pay $60 for a video game only to waste their own time on this nonsense.  UNTIL THEN, well, I have to give this game a thumbs down — if only to contribute to gaining their attention and ensuring that THEY understand the onus is on them to fix their game.  It is not the responsibility of their customers.\n\nThat said, the single player campaign itself is AMAZING and far better than I had hoped it would be, so this whole fiasco renders it all bittersweet.  If/when these problems are patched up, I'll delete or edit this review and switch to very much recommending Doom 4.  If you're only concerned with playing through the fantastic single player campaign and don't care about the rest (and you shouldn't, really) I would recommend that you DO NOT PAY FOR IT until id and Bethesda show some sign that they're paying attention.  Buyer beware, in any case.

reviewText:
Jesus H Christ is this game amazing. Easily the greatest FPS I've ever played. Fast and fluid combat mechanics, super tense encounters, and wildly satisfying gibs. Hopefully this game marks the end of the uninspired cover shooter, the forced-narrative driven games, and the 10 year long fetish for the Marine Corps.

Onto the details, the difficulty curve is one of the absolutely most linear (that's good) I've ever seen in a game. It's a gradual increase and the game manages to foreshadow the next enemy to be introudced in a very natural way. And speaking of the enemies, they're as well designed as they ever have been. Each enemy has its own unique set of mechanics and weaknesses. They all have special ways of being disembowled as well, so that's a plus.

Encounters usually come in three flavors: hallways, multiplayer-esque arenas, and boss fights, and they all manage to hold their own and be memorable. The boss fights are particularly fantastic though, sporting WoW-like boss mechanics that require you to really be paying attention to the environment as well as shooting the big bad guy in the head.

Any negatives this game has are HEAVILY overcompensated by the positives. If I were to list a few though, it would be that it still indulges in the occassional slightly long cutscene or scripted sequence, the talent trees are neat but kinda boring (armor talents in particular), fairly lengthy load times, and lack of blast beats in the death metal/electronic score.

Note that you do need a pretty good rig to run this properly (this game REALLY needs to be played at 60+ fps) and I had to turn everything to low to keep it around 60 when the ♥♥♥♥ hit the fan. I'm on a GTX760, i7-3400 and 8gigs of RAM for reference.

So if you can run it, you need this game. This ♥♥♥♥ should be as ubiquitous on Steam as Portal and Half-Life 2.

reviewText:
It's Doom.

Fast, gory, fluid action. Jammed with secrets and bonuses. The upgrade system isn't over-complicated like in so many games, and does what it is supposed to - it adds variety to the combat.

Classic Doom, at it's most exhilarating and particularly most exercised in the more excellent community maps over the years, is about overwhelming odds being handled with grace, a combination of movement, awareness and weapon management. Doom 2016 taps into this well, with chaotic set pieces that are breathlessly paced and require the most capable reflexes. It's a modern FPS that is challenging but not excruciating.

The monster design sits somewhere between the colourful aesthetic of the original games and the more contemporary iD tech style of recent years (Doom 3 onwards). The Baron of Hell is very much a beefy, slightly silly looking pink behemoth that leaps around and smashes the ground as if it's having a tantrum. The Hell Knight is a faster, angrier take on the design seen in Doom 3 (which was pretty scary in that incarnation). Imps are fast like in Doom 3, but with added movement dynamics, as they scurry, climb and crawl, throwing fireballs behind them as they run for cover. Catching them  mid-leap is very satisfying.

I'm still playing the game, and haven't played the multiplayer as of yet (beyond the BETA anyway, which I enjoyed), but I have sampled snapmap and I am looking forward to really experimenting with it. There is clearly a lot of potential within the logic system to create some great maps and scenarios. I hope more snappable areas are made available in the future.

I have corrected the review accordingly and hope it helps you during your deliberation if you should buy this game or not.

I played so much of the original game Doom, that I could run levels entirely in reverse without touching any walls or hazards. I would deathmatch friends for hours at a time and got so good at the game that we used play where I would only use my fist but they could use any of the other weapons in the game.  So all of this being said, I am what you would consider a doom professional.

So my Doom professionalism was a bit skeptical with the newly released 2016 Doom. I got flash backs of Doom3 which was horrible and was not Doom at all but more of a Fear meets Quake. Well I can tell you that Bethesda (whom acquired id Software), did a spectacular job of capturing the essence of the original Doom and did the original coders some justice.

reviewText:
It’s been 12 years since Doom 3’s release and now we have a new Doom title that drops the flashlight mechanic and follows its predecessors’ footsteps more closely. The end result is a beautiful fast-paced shooter with large maps, hidden items, and a robust upgrade system. The game is not without its flaws as it does falter a bit towards the end of the game, uses only a checkpoint system without manual saves, and sometimes the large maps can work against it by slowing the game’s pace down severely depending on a player’s obsession with collecting items and finding secrets.

The duration of the single player seems to be at a decent length as I did finish up by the 10.4 hour mark. That time includes around an hour of staring at the different upgrade screens, consulting the fantastic 3D map for collectible locations, and some unfortunate backtracking I did for some secrets. The latter later made me reconsider my desire to have everything and so I started to ignore collectibles that I could not attain easily. That said I did acquire most of the exploration items and unlocked 2 classic Doom maps which can be selected for play from the main menu after selecting campaign. The hidden levers to unlock them seem fairly obnoxious as they don’t show up on the map at all. I found that trying to search for everything bogs the pacing down and prevents you from doing what the game does best, throwing demons at you for slaying. The game has a level select available should you want to hunt any missing items down. You might wonder why I didn’t just skip more of the exploring from the beginning, but exploration equals power for Doom (2016).

The game heavily incentivizes going off the beaten path within its large levels because many of the exploration items grant upgrade points that can be used to acquire passive abilities, increase base stats like health, unlock weapon mods, or enhance unlocked weapon mods. You can also find plenty of Doom lore, a neat collectible that unlocks models for viewing, and an automap console for revealing the entire map. My personality made me take the map related Praetor armor passive skills first, but you could go for enhanced power-ups or faster weapon switching instead. Rune passives have effects such as enemies drop armor shards after a Glory Kill (melee finisher) or more plentiful ammo drops (I never went without these two). The weapon mods are critical to dealing enough damage to survive. They’re also fun and allow for different playstyles. I greatly enjoyed how the Siege Mode mod of the Gauss Cannon, a personal favorite, let me fire off a destructive piercing shot at the cost of staying still. Line ‘em up, put ‘em down.

While I dearly love the Gauss Cannon and the devastation I can cause with it, most of the other weapons can also hold their own and work together with the various enemy types to create a mostly great combat experience. The combat’s fun owes plenty to its fast movement speed, no reloads, the weapon mods you choose after finding a field drone, and how you upgrade them. Weapon upgrade points are plentiful and you should have more than enough to develop the weapons to your specifications. I had a fully upgraded Super Shotgun for pure power, a Heavy Assault Rifle that could fire Micro Rockets until I ran out of ammo, a rocket launcher with remote detonation, and more. The weapons feel, look, and sound powerful; however, I did think the pistol and regular shotgun were weak contenders that didn’t see much use in my weapon rotation later in the game. That sense of power benefits from enemies losing limbs, turning into bloody chunks, and taking visible damage until the final blow is dealt. While weapon mods allow for diverse gunplay, unlocking the final upgrade for weapon mods can sometimes be a pain since some of them have very specific challenges which impacts pacing. I often had to press TAB, mid-combat, to remind myself of the unlock conditions for several different weapons.

The special weapons and melee finishers do their part too. The chainsaw in Doom functions like a panic button and instantly gives any demon a bad day before making them explode into dozens of little ammo pickups. It’s balanced by a limited supply of fuel. Doomguy also has several weapons available for tossing at the demon horde. The thrown items have a recharge rate, but can also be replenished with the appropriate ammo pickup. Despite my preference for shooting, I did engage heavily with the Glory Kill system in order to stay alive due to the health and armor shard (Rune skill) drops. If you’re on the brink of death, a Glory Kill will produce more health drops, making it vital to success if you’re bad at dodging. The finisher animations did make my eyes grow weary after a while due to the repetition despite how fast they are. I regret not finding the Rune Trial that grants faster Glory Kills.

Doom’s combat pacing felt pretty good for most of the experience as it kept adding a new enemy type at appropriate intervals to keep things from becoming stale and has the occasional boss fight. For the most part, the game’s tempo followed a fight, explore, and fight again type of pattern. Most enemy encounters involved demons spawning into existence for you to battle instead of using monster closets. The spawning could cause some issues since the maps make great use of vertical space, making it more difficult to keep track of enemies. Late in the game, the spawns followed a similar pattern – small guys, medium guys, then large guys – which became monotonous. Far too often, fights would end by taking out the same large demon type. They could have done something with unleashing a horde of one or two enemy types, but I didn’t see that happen. Also, there didn’t seem to be a large number of enemies on screen at the same time. It always felt like 8-10 enemies at most. At least the game ended with a decent boss fight to help me forget.

The other two modes don’t seem to add much to the experience for me. SnapMap looks like it’ll need more time before the really good stuff becomes featured. I’m interested in what a co-op experience might look like with friends. The multiplayer has some fun modes, but Freeze Tag is ruined by Vortex Rifles which can one hit kill players with a full charge. It doesn’t help that the mode can end faster than the intermission time limit of 90 seconds between matches. Team Deathmatch made me wish I bought Overwatch because the gameplay just does not feel right with a loadout system. It’s not a good fit for this title. I would have greatly preferred weapon pickups, especially since the Rocket Launcher feels abnormally weak and doesn’t knock players around. War Path caught my attention and is my favorite mode because it’s a bit different, like Freeze Tag. I like the idea of a moving zone that needs to be captured and defended.

Okay, here are some other things I want to touch on before giving a conclusion: the game’s performance is a rock solid 60fps on ultra with a GTX 970, i7 4790K, and 8GBs of RAM; textures will sometimes be slow to load, allowing for a retro feel; scroll bars can be buggy for descriptions/lore; Darin De Paul’s voice gives my ears pleasure; I like this Doom much more than Doom 3; Multiplayer, Campaign, and SnapMap all use different executables and selecting one requires a restart; finally, you can hold down Shift to walk, but I don’t know why anyone would use it.

Doom can easily provide a mostly great experience so long as you don’t caught up with collecting everything in one go and really enjoy shooting demons. Otherwise, the copy/paste enemy spawning during the final areas of the game might annoy certain players. SnapMap has potential. The multiplayer portion doesn’t seem well-thought-out. The single player is the main draw for this game.

reviewText:
So after the whole fiasco with the multiplayer beta, I admit I was feeling a little worried that ID may have dropped the ball with this game and it was going to be one of the biggest dissappointments of the year. But after getting my hands on it and playing through the campaign, I've never been happier to say I was wrong. This is Doom the way it should be: Light on story, very heavy on action, gore and challenging difficulty. Even if you only get it for the single player (like I did), you won't be dissapointed at all. Not only is it insanely fun, it's highly replayable with plenty of secrets to find, upgrades to unlock and loads of demons for you to kill. I especially love all the nods to the original games they've tossed in throughout the campaign.

This is also one of the most well optimized games I've ever played. I was somewhat worried my 970 wouldn't allow me to really push this game's graphics (especially after seeing the gameplay previews) but I was pleasantly surprised when I was able to turn all the settings up to ultra and still achieve a smooth, stable framerate even during seriously intense battles. It's good to see a developer who still cares about their PC players and isn't just giving us a shoddy console port.

So if you loved the original Doom games and wanna get back to killing hordes of demons, quit reading this and just buy the game already.

id has done a fanstastic job on recreating the DOOM franchise. SnapMap and the single player campaign is what truely makes this game. reviewText:
Before this review starts, something I'd like to point out:
I'm a massive Doom fan. I've played Doom 1 and 2 at the age of 6. Doom was the game that got me into becomming a video game programmer and modder. Some of my fondest memories were playing these game and their multiplayer. DeHackEd and ACS were the first coding languages I learned, all thanks to Doom's extensive modding community

With this being said, let's see how my favorite childhood game has got itself rebooted.

Single-PlayerI'll just say it right out of the box that this is, by far, my favorite Single-Player experience by far. The explosions, gore and brutal-ness has activated a lot of adredaline in me. I felt my body all funny when I saw that they put my favorite video game villain (Spoiler) The Spider Mastermind in the game. The Glory Kill System stolen inspired by Brutal Doom was interesting, but it fell flat later on. Especially because some enemies seem to only have 2 different glory kill animations (Cacodemon and Mancubus I'm looking at you). The weapon arsenal and mods are great. There is too much emphasis on explosives though. The rocket launcher and plasma guns felt really flat and powerless. I never used any of the grenades the game gave us because I never found a reason to, and am still confused as to why they're in Doom. Also, one of the weapon mods is the ability to aim down sights. No comment there. The chainsaw... It felt like a cheap weapon and it was boring to use. Speaking of that, I found myself using the glory kill system to cheat out of death, because it gives me invincibility and free health. The music is Gorgeous, as well as the graphics. The story is here, for some reason, and it is forced on you. I hate it. I hate it. I HATE IT. I came to ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ up, not to sit locked in a room while some character talks. The ending left me there, wondering what the hell I had just spent a massive amount of time doing. It would have been so good if they let us blast our way out of those rooms so the doom guy would be like: Pfft
date: I don't give a damn". The ending however... (Spoiler) I've been waiting the entire game to be able to punch Samuel in the face

reviewText:
I had a good feeling about this one.

The single player campaign is the real stand out here and a return to form for those of us missing actual gameplay in our games. There is a story here, but its mostly told through 'codex' entries that pop up as enemies are killed and objectives completed. 'Cutscenes' are very few and far between, minor ones being completely ignorable (just walk away) and major ones not lasting longer than a few minutes (a sparse handful throughout the game with the biggest and the start, middle and ending).

The combat? A glorious dance of death. Anyone who has been following id Software for some time knows they've put a lot of work into animating their enemies. Say what you will about RAGE, for instance, but the enemies 'danced' around the enviornment in wonderful ways, bouncing off walls, dodging, ducking and weaving about. That animation was built upon heavily in Doom 4. Imps leap up onto walls and hurl fireballs, Hell Knights leap through the air hulk smashing the ground and so on. When you have an arena filled with enemies dodging about as you frantically tear through the map dodging and weaving yourself to find better vantage points you'll realize what modern shooters have been missing for years.

About the only negative I can give the single player is the glory kill system. While its not that bad and really doesn't hurt the flow of the game it is a very important component. When your health falls to critical levels in an arena and you have collected all the health pickups? You NEED a glory kill. Completely out of ammo in that arena? Time for a chainsaw kill.

Multiplayer? I'm personally having a lot of fun with it. If you played the Beta and disliked it because of lack of content? You will probably like the full version as there are numerous demons, maps, weapons and customization options available that were not in the Beta. If on the other hand you simply did not like how it played... the full version will not change how you feel. Glad to say that while the game has 'prestiges' (echelons) you do NOT lose any items or customizations so you are looking at 500 levels of customization drops (you get all equipment and weapons by 17)!

SnapMap is a bit disappointing as you can not actually build individual rooms and have to work with presets. There simply is not enough content available and there are questionable assets from single player not given to the player. Why no Cyberdemon or Summoner? Why no Pistol or Chainsaw? Why is only a single tileset available (No Hell tileset!?)? Hopefully as time goes on they add more functionality and content to SnapMap. I am having fun designing a remake of an old Doom campaign but I've had to dramatically lower my expectations for how accurate and true to the original it will be. Forget any sort of accurate remakes of Doom 1 or 2 maps.

All in all a ton of great content in this package. I really dove into the single player and have had an absolute blast with it and can see myself going back and trying on other difficulties (the collectibles took quite a while to find). The mp wont be for everyone but if you vary your loadouts it can offer a lot of fun. SnapMap has potential and already some imaginative and cool scenarios have been released. No regrets for a day one purchase and I hope you enjoy it too!

reviewText:
The Good: Doom's campaign is a blast. While somewhat repetitive the run and gun gameplay is as satisfying and addictive as ever. Lots of collectibles and challenges will certaly make you replay some levels.

The Bad: Snapmap, in concept, is a great idea and in fact it does allow the creation of some interesting maps and mechanics. However, the more you mess with it the more you realize how restricted is the editor. It doesn't, in any way, make up for the lack of mod support.

The Ugly: The MP feel like a completely different game. The mix of a level progression system and loadouts with arena maps and pickups is , in my opinion, one of the worst possible things they could come up with. Demon runes are also terribly unbalanced, specially if you have unlocked the greater demons. It doesn't just feel like a Halo game - it feels like a BAD Halo game.

But, should you play Doom? Yes. Just don't pay full price for it.
For me, the campaign more than makes up for the MP. I can certainly see myself coming back to try the Ultra Nighmare difficulty.

reviewText:
*Note this is for the SP campaign (completed on Ultra-Violence) as I won't be playing MP.

DOOM 4 is a unbelievably WICKED game that not only stands up to the Doom legacy, but also proves itself as a very fun FPS and looks amazing while doing it.

The gameplay definetely has that old-school vibe to it, as instead of sitting in cover waiting for regenerating health, you are moving around really quickly, strafe-jumping and bunny-hopping to try to avoid getting horribly murdered by demons. Just after halfway through the campaign you can expect to be fighting many of the highly tough demons at once (though not as extreme as the Serious Sam games) that will require that you be very skillfull and effecient in the way you approach combat. The glory kill (melee) system, although lamented by many, isn't really a problem as it doesn't really break the flow of gameplay. Powerups make a great return to Doom by making certain battles easier, such as being able to decapitate demons with your fists

The redesign of the demons is just AMAZING. Many of them look and sound creepy as hell (especially the lost souls) and can definitely kill you very quickly if you are not paying attention, especially those pinky demons. The boss fights are not that easy but aren't extremely hard either, its just as simple as shooting at it until it dies and trying not to get killed, like the rest of the gameplay in DOOM 4.

Nobody should care about the story (*its a doom game for crying out loud) as it just disrupts the flow whenever there is a story segment with lots of talking.

The weapons look awesome and feel very satifying to use, except for the starting pistol. There is also a system where you can purchase and upgrade alt-fire modes on certain weapons, such as a triple shotgun burst, or a micro-missile launcher attached to a Machine Gun, which makes the weapons even more fun to use. The Chainsaw is of limited use at times but my god, it is so much fun to use as each evisceration spawns all this ammo and health everywhere. The BFG just destroys everything as it usually does, need I say more?

The level design returns to the exploration based maze like labryinth of sorts where you are constantly navigating a non-linear path. The game also places an emphasis on finding secrets so you can get the bigger weapons earlier, or getting such goodies like suit upgrades for doomguy or increases to health capacity.  The HUD also includes a compass so you can't really get lost.

The only qualms I really had with this game was a lack of quicksave function (annoying when finding dangerous secrets) and the music was a bit.. ehh... for my taste.

Despite my rig just barely scraping past the minium requirements, performance was good enough for me to enjoy this beast of a game from start to finish.

All in all I highly recommend this game to pretty much any FPS nut as it is a wonderful return to form for the Doom franchise after what happened with Doom 3.

reviewText:
I played the game now for around two hours and I must say, I'm super impressed. I know the game will be good. But so far it reached beyond my expectations.

Gameplay:
The games runs smooth and the combat is fast and fluid, it just feels right. As soon as a fight starts you're into a flow. It's a ton of fun to jump in the demon horde and decimate them with your weapons and meele attacks. The fights are also very gory, what is perfect for this game. The melee attacks are also fast and matches the combat style of the game, you wont get stopped or loose your flow when you finish of your enemies with a glory kill. (name of the melee attacks)

Graphic:
In short: AWESOME.
In longer: The game looks absolutly fantastic. I'm not playing with everything on max and I was totaly stunned by the magnificence grafic. One of the best looking games I played so far. You will love it. And so far, I had absolutly no stutters or anything like that.
The animations of your character and the enemies are absoluty smooth and stunning. The world, the weapons, your enemies and everything else just matches each other perfectly. What is also important, it looks and feels like Doom. If you had no idea what game you are going to play, after the first 5-10 seconds you would know that you are in Doom.

Sound:
Great! The weapons are sounding powerfull like they are. You will hear and feel every hit on your enemies or on yourself. The music pushed you, and alone trough their noise you will know what enemies you are up to.
Beside that, the world itself has the right sound, if some machine is working near you, when metal breaks or you are in an elevator. If you are on the surface of Mars or on the station or listen to some npc. There is nothing so far I could complain about. It fits perfectly together.
-----

I can totaly recommend DOOM to everyone that likes fast paced shooters with an awesome atmosphere. You won't find anything better at the moment.

I can't say anything about the Multiplayer so far, since I didnt played it yet.

I'm torn apart. The gameplay is great but the game is literally unplayable (right now).

I really like the game itself. It's fun and engaging. I was just recently talking to a friend about games nowadays not having real secret areas like games had 20 years ago. And now D°°M (re)introduced them eventually. Also the weapons upgrades, the whole leveling and powerup-mechanics are really nice. And there are no IAPs (yes, one really has to state that nowadays). There's no in-game currency you can buy outside of the game. Everything needs to be earned by yourself and is not taken from you again.

But: The game crashes. Not just for me but for a lot (!) of people (just search the web). And it crashes in the badest way possible: Without any error message. Just puts you right back to the desktop. The first three levels where fine but now I'm stuck in the fourth level, having to play from my last save game over and over because the game crashes out of nowhere.

So what finally has become the most scariest thing of the game are not the enemies but the constant fear of doing something that will make the game crash. This is the worst that could happen to a game and it fully ruined it for me. I've been playing so many games and none of them crashed. I honestly can't remeber the last game that crashed on my system. And this from the company that owned PC game programming.

That's why I tell my colleagues not to buy Doom and that's why I don't recommend this game. At least not yet. When this is fixed I definitely will return to play it. But until then it's stays literally unplayable.

Currently this review is being written from a preliminary view at the games campaign ONLY and not with any influence from the multiplayer and the beta.

reviewText:
Well, I am about 9 hours in on PC and about 15 hours in on my PS4, giving me around 24 hours of gameplay time in both the campaign and multiplayer. What can I say? DOOM is BACK!!!

First off... I'd like to start by saying my opinion of the MP in the game: IT IS GREAT!!!
I seriously DO NOT understand all of the negative comments towards the MP. It is super competitive and feels like it was made for tournament style matches. Aka - serious gamers! It gets your blood pumping, and it satisfies so much more than the last several popular franchises' FPS games that have been released that are just garbage. The fact that your health doesn't regenerate and you can actually run out of ammo (picking up health, armour, and ammo packs from pickups on the map) gives it such a new and fresh edge while also feeling very classic like DOOM should feel. I don't know... I absolutely love it, and so does everyone that I have talked to, except for, apparently, people on Steam...

So enough about the divide of folks with the MP... Let's touch on the campaign a bit. Again I will say... DOOM IS BACK!!!

I honeslty can't believe they did it... but DOOM has been rebooted, and it delivers something fierce. The graphics, mechanics, customization, and even the story are all spectacular. I don't want to spoil anything, but I can easily say that this is the best SP campaign of any FPS I have played in years, especially since the release of the next-gen" of gaming. Another aspect of the game that just puts the icing on the cake is the music... METAL AF!!! There are fight scenes/levels that literally got me so pumped that I started screaming with happiness as I mowed down my foes and sent them back to Hell with my chainsaw and arsenal of weapons! You can't stop moving

reviewText:
No need to say what many others have already said, but I will add one thing. This will sound outlandish--far from conciliatory--but it is true for me (even as someone that grew up playing the original Doom as shareware):

This feels more like Doom than the original does.

This release incorporates the essence of what defined the original, and works out a personality so strong that makes it feel like this is what Doom was meant for all along.  The design is smart and masterful, and the movement and gunplay is so smooth and interesting--all without weighing down what made Doom so great in the first place.  It's just so naturally fun, there's no room to even think about it.  The campaign just gets better and better the further in... it's really impressive, and has no right to be this great, but here we are.  So relieved. :)

reviewText:
*Gnome Seal of Approval*
So far, I'm enjoying this more than I expected. I feared id would continue down the path they took in Doom 3 with dark rooms and corridors, jump scares and a game not in line with the previous installments regarding atmosphere. I didn't mind the darkness so much in Doom 3, I just didn't think it was the right way to go with a Doom game.

In this new Doom game, the levels a brightly lit, the action is fast paced and fluid and your adrenaline is flowing.

This is what Doom 3 should have been!

The level design is fairly non-linear (at least compared to other shooters out there), but with some of the same backtracking we used to do in the original Doom and Doom 2.

The enemies are fun, diverse and nicely modelled and animated.

The weapon and suit upgrading system is fun and encourages exploration and experimentation. The map challenges are some minor goals you can do to earn a few extra upgrading points, but your main source comes from clearing the maps for enemies. This means that casual players can just run through the campaign, yet still earn upgrades. The Rune trials you eventually encounter are yet another way of customizing playstyle and upgrading your character.

The soundtrack also helps to make combat fun and engaging.

So, there's a lot to explore and fun stuff to do! I like it!

There's even classic Doom maps to unlock and play with the new enemies and weapons, but with the classic graphics everywhere else.

My only minor complaint so far is regarding secrets. In early levels, the game lets you backtrack to all areas so you can explore and search for secrets in peace. However, soon enough you will encounter doors that lock the way behind you so you can't go back and look for missed secrets until you finish the level. I've never been a fan of this in any game. If a game have secrets and collectibles, please enable the player to go back and search for them if he/she missed some.

I have not played multiplayer. This is purely a singleplayer review.

reviewText:
+ Fantastic optimization (single 980 Ti, maxed out at 2560x1440 gives 60-90fps constantly)
+ Uncapped framerate! It's the first game on this engine to support more than 60fps. WOO!
+ FOV Slider!
+ Incredible graphics, audio, music, animation and particle effects.
+ Production quality is brilliant with a very cinematic and polished campaign.
+ Very satisfying combat, with fluid controls, dynamic kills and brilliant damage modelling.
+ Detailed and satisfying gore.
+ Faithful to the original, classic Doom. Enemy designs, weapons, satanic stuff.
+ Nice responsive movement, with intuitive climbing mechanics, double-jumps, etc. Makes platforming fun and simple.
+ Lots of upgrades, weapon mods, and customization to suit playstyles and add a sense of progression.
+ Lots of hidden collectibles, secrets, log-books and in-game challenges to keep completionists busy.

Side notes:

- This is a much faster paced game than Doom 3. Personally, I preferred the slower, more linear Doom 3 experience, but this fast pace is also tense and fun. It's simply different.
- I also really liked the touch-screen interfaces and keypads in Doom 3, it's a shame nothing like that is present here. It's very much a 'run'n'gun' game this time around.

reviewText:
Hurt me plenty!

PROS:

+ blazing fast combat tempo
+ glory executions(melee finishers)
+ aggressive and heavy OST
+ single player campaign level design
+ simplicity and easter eggs
+ MP is quick and fun
+ SnapMap feature paves the way for the creative

CONS:

- I hear some players are experiencing performance issues, despite sporting top-notch rigs
- may be too shallow gameplaywise for some

I had no expectations whatsoever for DOOM.
Initially, it seemed to be a cashgrab attempt at reanimating yet another legendary title of the days long past.
I was so wrong.
DOOM doesn't try to be a trailblazer, it doesn't strive for state of the art game mechanics and it sure as hell doesn't get innovative.
It doesn't need to.
The premises are pretty simple- rip and tear, progress to the next level segment, rip and tear, collect health, ammo and new gear, rip and tear, rip and tear.
And this is why it's so damn great.
DOOM has been visually custom tailored to live up to today's standards while retaining its infernal soul.
I was pleasantly surprised by the single player campaign's maps, which reward inquisitve minds with plenty of hidden collectibles and upgrade points.
The latter can be spent on improving your arsenal and the Doom Marine's combat proficiency.
As for multiplayer- apparently, many people dislike it. IMHO, it's awesome, offering you 10-15 minute long bursts of adrenaline while you butcher your way to victory through other players.
Stunning graphics, hellish beats, buckets of blood and knee-deep in the dead.
What the hell are you waiting for?

Until we see each other again.""

reviewText:
I've been a long-time DOOM fan and am really enjoying this release. Wasn't a fan of DOOM 3, but this version takes a lot of calls from DOOM 1 & 2 - it's more fast paced, sillier, and the multiplayer is actually extremely fun. The lack of variety in enemies is kinda eh, but otherwise this has been a really good purchase.

Pros:
- it 'feels' like a member of the franchise, if that makes sense - more than the third game did
- the flow of play is really good - you can clamber around, climb most scenery, combat is fluid and super fast like the old games
- multiplayer is fun & has a lot of customisation options
- the map editor (snapmap) is REALLY awesome and employs a super cool visual scripting function
- A+ multiplayer taunts
- throwbacks to the other games in the franchise
- really good sound design (apart from the repetitive moaning of enemies if you're above them)

Cons:
- the campaign can get a little repetitive, chalking this down to lack of variety of enemies and sometimes glory kill can be OP
- a bit slow to load, but it is a new release
- exiting the game to switch modes is kinda tiresome b/c of aforementioned loading times
- no matchmaking in multiplayer really

reviewText:
Doom 2016 is very much a 2 part experience:

Singleplayer
=============

Singleplayer is great. It feels right, it has the right atmosphere and gameplay, it's Doom, in the sense of Doom 1/2, with a touch of Doom 3.

Weapons look and feel powerful, player movement suits the singleplayer experience fine, despite being mostly identical to the multiplayer movement. (More on movement later.)
Like previous Doom games, you can carry and switch between your full arsenal of weapons in a moment, as suits the situation you find yourself in.

Melee glorykills are a bit forced; you can't really practically avoid them as gameplay is balanced heavily around them(they cause ammo and health drops as well as offer momentary invulnerability that you often need. You also warp instantly from your lockon point to your glorykill point, making it the fastest means of moving between two nearby places in a map. The game could have done just fine without them. That said, they suit the Berserk powerup perfectly.

The monster designs are all well done, stylistically. Everything is either heavily inspired by Doom 1/2 in a good way, or redesigned well.

The game doesn't pull punches with difficulty; I'm a long time Doom player, and I've died several times going through on Ultra Violence difficulty.

There are a lot of upgrades, for weapons, armour, and abilities.  They work well for what the game is.

Multiplayer
=============

Now, multiplayer is another story... Google how the Multiplayer Open Beta was received on Steam. (One of the worst games ever made by Id/Bethesda" will probably come up.) The release version of multiplayer is functionally unchanged from the open beta. It's awful

reviewText:
This is definitely one of the best titles i have ever experienced, i was originally a cod player but since that franchise has gone to hell, as we all know, *cough* cod infinite warfare *cough* anyways,  right off the bat you are thrown into combat during the first 10 seconds. Which is always nice to see unlike other games where you are sitting at a cinematic for half an hour.

The most prominent factor of this game is the gore, if you love heads exploding horns being torn off and just in general making demons punching bags then this is the game for you. Throughout the whole of the game you are thrown into thrilling battles with only one goal, to kill everything you see, also there's no denying that the music is freaking awesome, during every battle you will be bombarded with heavy metal music which adds to the adrenaline of the fights. There's nothing like using a chainsaw and ripping apart your enemies while there's some amazing soundtracks in the background.

In this title you can clearly see the effort the devs have put in to make all of the guns look like killing machines which adds to the excitement and thrill of the game, all of the models have a neat finish and have the feel of sheer awesomness.

The campaign in my opinion was very good and i enjoyed it alot, but the multiplayer i feel has alot more potential, at the minute there's not a big variety of weapons that players are able to pick from, the result of this you get people who run around with rocket launchers and shotguns, although that is a downfall of the game i can't deny that being the baron of hell and running around tearing people in half isn't fun.

So even though this game has some multiplayer flaws i would highly advise getting this title, when i first got this game i had really high expectations and DOOM most certainly smashed straight through those expectations and went over and beyond. Basically if you love killing demons listening to intense music and finding easter eggs this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Been a fan of the Doom franchise since the 90s and I have to give thanks to the guys and gals over at ID who made this game possible.

Game is gorgeous - I have a gtx 970, the game auto set everything at a medium setting, and it is still one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. I had trouble shooting at the varying demons on their first appearances because I was, more often than not, taken by how damn awesome their new designs were. Again, the developers stayed true to the original dooms.

Game is bug free - I LITERALLY HAD ZERO BUGS! I beat the game in just over 12 hours and never, not once, did I experience anything close to a freaking GLITCH. No graphical errors, no clipping issues. NOTHING. Even when creatures die they stay plugged into the physics of the game until their corpses turn to ash and blow away. I just couldnt believe I didnt find anything and I explored EVERYTHING.

Game is FUN! - I remember reading an article that Bethesda put out talking about how they want people to play agressively and that the game awards a gameplay style that is mobile and in the enemies face. If you sit behind a corner and camp, or try to play like its a Call of Duty fps, you will die. This game is all about moving, using the terrain, and all the tools the game gives you to bring the demons of hell to their KNEES.

The Game and gameplay make you feel like a BAMF - The game literally FEEDS your ego by talking you up and basically reinforcing the idea that YOU, THE DOOM MARINE, are the demon that the denizens of hell tell scary stories about around campfires. Unfortunately for them, you are very real! The glory killing system has you literally wade through your enemies pulling them apart and just leaving you looking for the next demon to tear apart with your bare hands! (sometimes your hands are all you need!)

THE GAME IS A REWARDING CHALLENGE! - The boss fights were AWESOME. The game constantly pits you against waves upon waves of demons as you get further into the game. It also seems like the game scaled my exposure to the waves quite well. It never felt like i was in an impossible situation. The entire combat arena could be swarming, and i mean like 20-25 guys staring at me trying to kill me and the only thing going through my mind was...Im killing that one first" and then you charge!

Item collection was a pleasure! - Alot of times you get games that basically give you the "option" of finding little treasure troves around the various levels with usually an achievement or a journal notation to reward you with. How does Doom award you for doing this? IT TRIES TO KILL YOU OF COURSE! You want to find every little secret on the map? Squeeze every upgrade you can? Get ready for puzzles
recommended:
get ready for challenges! How exactly are you rewarded? Well you become a far more capable killing machine of course! Going for all the unlocks in the game takes time but they are all interconnected with various "completion" based sub-objectives that further reward you for your diligence. Ultimately allowing you to stay ahead of the game with the best equipment and upgrades you could possibly have which you ARE GOING TO NEED!

I havent touched the multiplayer or snapmap yet because im probably gonna amp the difficulty up to its max setting and give it a go.

I highly recommend this game - the last time I felt this good about an fps game
hoursPlayed: I was on the Pillar of Autumn and my rank was Master chief.\n"

reviewText: This is Doom alright :D Imagine taking original Doom 1 and 2, breath in HD graphics, give them actual 3rd dimension and again back it up with amazing jaw dropping graphics engine which runs absurdly fast thanks to Vulkan. I have a powerful system, but I didn't expect a brand new game that looks so amazing to run so incredibly fast. And it's not just bells and whistles, the game is stupendously fun. Monsters are really challenging and it again feels like old Doom games. No more individual demons here and there like in Doom 3, they are still there, but most of the time it's crazy battle within a map segment filled with demons. You have to constantly move and kill. It's the only way not to die. Especially if you play on Nightmare like I am. Incredibly unforgiving but still fun. Combat is really engaging and amazing, especially thanks to tons of weapons and what's new and unexpected in a Doom game, Preator suit and weapons upgrades with rune powers. By playing, killing and finding secrets you upgrade yourself and weapons to be a better killing machine. And while most would think such thing just wouldn't work in a Doom game, it totally does. It's brilliant and most upgrades for weapons are designed to deliver more boom, only few are sort of tactical oriented like scoped railgun and scoped heavy machinegun (both optional, you can opt for more firepower mods). Suit upgrades are more for movement and world awareness. But it's all so well designed it's really awesome.\n\nAnyway, I could go on and on how awesome it is, but it's really one of the best games this year. It really is. It looks great, it's incredibly fun and captures that Doom feel from the 90's, but in new refreshing form. A proper franchise reboot, something we don't often see with floods of crappy reboots. This one is properly badass like Doom should be. I can only recommend it!

I expected this game to be as gripping as the Bethesda walkthrough, and very hellish (of course.) I was  skeptical after seeing beta reactions, but I bit the bullet.

I was first blown away by the visuals. This is definitely a top-notch game for 2016. We know that it has Vulcun support coming, which will be amazing. reviewText:
In this review I'll just write about the singleplayer campaign, since I don't play multiplayer a lot.

Perfect combination of old and new elements, like on one hand the fast paced gameplay with a variety of guns for different situations, varied enemy types and some open levels which can be explored non-linearly (including secrets!) and on the other hand the weapon and character upgrade system which lets you pick your preferred playstyle. The graphics are a mix of mostly Doom 3's dark atmosphere and a few of the old Doom's colourful enemies. The only thing I didn't like as much as the rest was the design of a few of the enemies, like the cyberdemon which looks like it comes straight out of a Blizzard title, but that's just a very minor flaw.

Technically, the game is also very good. The environments look great, indoor as well as outdoor. The enemies are extremely detailed and wonderfully animated. The framerate is stable at 60 (GTX 970, 16GB RAM, i5-4690K) and the loading times are not even noticable on my SSD. The only flaw is that the game crashed 2 times so far.

I can recommend this to old and new FPS fans alike, it's just great.

reviewText:
So i got to say, they actually made a doom game that feels like the old school doom we all love. The singleplayer is SUPER strong. Fun, fast, brutal, loads of guns and a decent story telling with big rewards if you explore. You're a badass, go kill some monsters. The storyline wont tell you everything, but you'll collect info while playing and decide for yourself if you want to read the story in detail. I like that, give the player a choice to read it all or leave it be. The game is also remarkable well optimized. I was amazed at how good the game looked with 8gb ram, a bad graphic card (GeForce GTX 560Ti) and no SSD hdd. It still runs smooth on 30-60fps after the loading, witch is nothing more than amazing.

Over to multiplayer. It's not that great imo. It's fast, but messy and it just don't give me the same awesome feeling of being a badass. It looks a lot like a version of unreal tournament tbh, with the twist. And some of the modes was not that fun. The melee instant kill range also seems to be really long. It's possible to do a finish move from far away.

Anyway, to sum it up. If you want a singleplayer shoot'em up game that's made of awesomeness, buy this. It will be worth it if you enjoy the old school doom style. If you want a multiplayer game, this will probably be a dissapointment.

reviewText:
I wasn't expecting much, but god dammit they've did it, a game that does Doom justice.

I'm blown away but how good the gameplay, graphics, smooth/responsive controls, enemies, weapons, speed, and most of all level design is.

Everything feels streamlined. The game knows it's an over-the-top action shooter about demons from hell, and it has FUN with it. You're constantly moving, as are the enemies, and it's the closest singleplayer FPS has ever come to reminding me of the old Quakeworld days of frantic movement, jumping around, shooting in mid-air, and so on.

The levels are full of hidden stuff, and generally there are very few points-of-no-return in each level (with the end-of-level being an obvious thing you have to explicitly trigger), meaning you can search for secrets through the level until you find them. The map and optional upgrades (in a light RPG system) can also help you locate secrets, or most of them at least.

I was sceptical about adding things like execution moves, double-jump and ledge-grabbing to Doom but having now played it, it all works and fits into the mechanics surprisngly well. (Executions are useful as they give you a little bonus health and ammo, for the small risk of having to get close to the enemy in time, although you need not get _that_ close. They're over very quickly, and if you really don't like them then you simply never push the button that does them and you'll never do them.)

SnapMap looks interesting, in terms of providing various types of extra maps and game modes you (and other players if you wish) can drop into, and make yourself. I haven't played with it much though, and it's early days in terms of seeing what other people can create.

I have no idea what the multiplayer is like as I have not tried that yet. After years of playing nothing but Quakeworld and then Counter-Strike, and later CoD:MW2, I try to avoid multiplayer as it can end up eating up so much time, and never ends. This was all about single-player fo rme, and the game has delivered well beyond expectations.

Highly recommended if you enjoy shooting demons in the face and searching multi-level, intricate levels for hidden stuff.

Runs and looks great on Ultra/1080p on my lowly GTX 960 (4GB). While it cannot quite maintain 60fps all the time, it's pretty close to it, and the adaptive v-sync means I rarely even notice. (Maybe the really well done motion blur helps as well? I don't consciously notice it is there, but it's very visible in still screenshots.)

reviewText:
Ladies and gentlemen, the King of First Person Shooters has finally returned to us!

In a world where the genre has been oversaturated with bland, dumbed down, tutorial-infested garbage, it makes my heart swell with pride to play a proper sequel to the game that got me into the FPS genre in the first place.  Sure, I played Wolf 3D.  Sure, I played other ripoffs like Lethal Tender.  Of course I played Duke 3D, as well.  Hell, I even played all these games in school, instead of doing my school work!  That's how dedicated I was to the genre!

This game is a no-nonsense action game.  Just like the first game, you run around shooting things in the face, chest, arm, head, legs....wherever you like.  You kill demons, and you pick up items.
Where the game expands on the formula established by the beloved Doom and Doom 2 is this:
-More violence.
-Collectibles that serve a purpose(you get points to spend on weapons and the like for finding them).
-Finishing moves that serve a purpose(sure, Brutal Doom is awesome, but in this game, it's more than just for show-you get health for melee executions, and ammo from chainsaw executions).
-Absolutely gorgeous graphics.
-A small expansion/reimagining of the original story(yeah, we don't play this game for the story, but I'll take it).

I'm only about 3-4 hours in, and I am having a blast!

I had hoped that this game was at least good.

As it turns out, this game is f***ing METAL.

reviewText:
I was playing DOOM II while waiting for Steam to finish setting up the game. As soon as it was ready, I went for it.

First playthrough on Ultra-Violence, no tutorials, no compass or objective markers, simple crosshair, minimal HUD (only health and ammo), no overlays, weapon changes only with keyboard shortcuts.

Let's just say this: the transition from DOOM II couldn't have been smoother and more positively surprising.

In the first 5 minutes you'll be already knee deep in it, blasting away at demons like in the old ones.  Each demon has its own character and combat style: Imps are fiercer and faster than ever, and they come at you from all sides. Hell Knights are agile, fast and deliver some serious blows... and wait 'till you get to the Baron.

Level design is maze-like, combining linear corridors and sections with open ground arenas where most of the action will happen. Playing without markers and compass felt much more like an old school experience: exploring only by relying on visual clues is extremely satisfactory especially when searching for secrets, though the automap is still very useful.

The only complaints I have are related to relatively minor things: one is the presence of two or three story-related scenes that lock you in place for a brief amount of time and they cannot be skipped.
The second one that I noticed is that there are no running speed upgrades apart from the temporary Haste powerup, only combat speed upgrades (weapon and mod switching, faster glory kills, faster mantling) which do improve the pace somewhat, although I would still love to be able to speedup things a bit more, especially when comparing the pace to the old DOOMs.

It does feel like a DOOM with some Quake mechanics thrown in (platforming, air control), but I think those same mechanics have actually helped the game to step into more modern ground and at the same time feel like a unique, original game in its own right. In my opinion they did something that feels so good to play it's almost unbelievable. It's not about franchise purity"
date: it's about fun.\n\nAll in all I think the game feels just right: pace
recommended: power and enemy behaviour all combined to give an awesome "old-school meets new" feeling that hasn't been part of an FPS in a very long time.\n\nThanks id

reviewText:
Ok, ok. Having spend a significant amount of time with the new DOOM, I can say that it is one of my favourite games of all time now.

Here the cliffnotes:

Pros
beautiful audio-visual design. Looks and sounds as you would expect a modern DOOM to look and sound
Fantastic single player campaign. Very straight forward fun. Non-linear maps. Lots of secrets. Weapon upgrades etc.
High-speed combat in kill rooms. The game will funnel you into these open areas with tons of enemies. If you want to survive you have to keep moving. Awesome fun.
SNAPMAP - Ok, this is great. It will give the game infinite replayability. It is like Portal2's steam workshop support. Basically, like a Doom version of MarioMaker. Plus it is fun and easy to use and you can play with your friends in COOP. Brilliant.
Performance. The game runs like butter and you have a gazillion settings to manipulate. On a single 980ti the game runs in Ultra/Nightmare settings at 3440x1440 (21:9) almost always at a 100+ fps, with occasional dips into the high 70s. Good stuff, considering we are not even playing the Vulkan version yet.

Cons

The competitive multiplayer may be a con for you, if you expect a full Quake 3 Arena or Unreal Tournament type game. Personally, I love the multiplayer. It feels fresh for Doom. It is like a mix between Quake 3 and Halo multiplayer. For me it works, but if you are going to buy the game just for the multiplayer. Understand what you are getting.


Overall, I am extremely happy about how the game turned out. If you are a fan of DOOM, you will at the very least love the campaign and SNAPMAP mode.

reviewText:
This game is a fantastic homage to the old Doom while being a beast in its own right. It does well to return to the roots of the Doom nightmare with a new polish and smooth gameplay. Play this game on the highest difficulty you can manage so you can get back into the old habits of strafe and destruction that you needed back in the glory days. Everything about this game wants you to move and never stop. No reloading, no regeneration of health. You want to live? Earn it. Be as brutal as possible to rip health out of your enemies.

Campaign is fast paced, there are secrets, keycards, upgrades, weapons and collectibles galore. It does everything right to punish you when you mess up while making you feel like a beast when you deserve it. Don't stop moving and don't stop shooting. If you're concerned about secrets the game will slow down significatntly as you will backtrack like crazy because they really wanted to hide them from you. I would recommend looking up a guide to unlock the extra content and classic Doom throwback levels. The secrets are not false walls or secret doors, it's exploration of a 3d environment. All in all the experience is very rewarding when you really get your momentum rolling so either gather secrets in your second playthrough or grab a nice guide. That's my personal recommendation because I personally didn't want to totally kill the pacing. Something to consider.

The Multiplayer is even more fast paced as a player vs. player setting will always challenge you more. The game returns to the classic pick up standard. Given, you have loadouts for weapons so you don't need to gather weapons. You do, however, need to pick up health as there is no health regeneration. This incentivizes players to keep moving around the map to kill each other while keeping themselves alive while discouraging players from holing up in corners waiting for the red blood spatter border to fade. You will find 75 kill deathmatches to go very quickly with this classic doom philosophy. This game rewards boldness.

It's a great installment for an aged series and breathes new life into the look and feel of the game. If you played the Brutal Doom mod in the classic games then you will feel right at home.

Rip and tear!

DOOM feels like a game for fans, from fans. It's fast paced, chaotic, bloody, and loud. Everything a DOOM game needs to be. The environments are stunning, colorful, and every bit as sinister. This is far from DOOM 3, it's better in every way and a great new beginning to the series. This time around a story is actually intact, and interesting.  Like DOOM original, this game is about staying on the move, exploring, and destroying stuff with epic weapons. And it delivers every bit of it without mercy.

This is not Halo, this is sure as hell not Call of Duty, you explore beautiful and grotesque environments in search of power-ups while surviving onslaughts of enemies and monster closets to make your inner psycho squee with joy at all the bloodshed. DOOM runs a very simple gaming formula, but does so with grace: Explore > Power up > Monster closet > Boss. It begins easy but later on, as the monsters evolve, so too does the challenge. Evolving from a simple shooter to a fight for survival at each encounter. Enclosed rooms become bloodbaths and open paths become drive-by arenas.

The graphics this time around put tears to the eyes. Guns are sleek and shiny, environments range from beautiful to hellish, and demons look better and more sinister than ever before. All of this complimented by the high levels of gore to make even the likes of George Romero squirm. Not to mention you got yourself a sick soundtrack to rip apart demons to.

Weapon variety comes in the form of classics we know and love, with a little added something. Weapons can be buffed or upgraded, much like your armor, letting you play DOOM differently and to your unique style. Or you can forgo everything and just play this classic with no power-ups. Nothing is forced on the player, not even the routes you take. It's about freedom to express the insides of a demon on the wall any way you like. And it's damn fun to do it.

Multiplayer is not your usual Halo or COD. This is a shooter with guts. It's fast, chaotic, and bloodboiling. Say goodbye to quick one-shot kills and hello to group cooperation and outmaneuvering. If you can't move, you die. Best start developing those hand-eye coordinations because you'll need it as you pump lead or plasma into the enemy combatant trying to make your head into a pinata. The added toughness of each player, along with armor and health boosts, just adds to the fun of dogfighting your way through each kill. It becomes a race to see who can kill who first before a partner or new enemy jumps over to provide the handicap. And it works. DOOM never stops. You can't camp, you can't cheese. All you got here is skill, forget the patience. You're a hungry monster out to feed. As you play you progress levels and unlock swag armor to stylize, colors, and new weapons/gear. Win or lose, you are always rewarded handsomely for something enjoying yourself. So forget the pressure of getting them kills, enjoy yourself.... and kill a whole lot of people.

All in all, DOOM is the remake Duke Nukem wanted to be. Hell, it's the remake any game wants to be. It's beautiful, fast, violent, engaging, challenging, and, above all else, fun. I have yet to run into lag, yet to see my frame rate drop, and I'm running this monster on all Ultra settings. The only stops here are when I rip the head out a demon to shove down his throat, or when a demon beats me to death with my own legs.

DOOM fans NEED this game, shooter fans WANT this game, WHY HAVEN'T YOU ALREADY BOUGHT THIS GAME?!?!?!?
