reviewText:
You will be a Sinner 10/10

I played the second it came out and I will say it is bloody ♥♥♥♥ing fun to play. It is easily a very good successor to Doom 3 that we have been waiting for some years for. The core mechanics, graphics and gameplay is fluent and bloody brilliant. No doubt when you jump into the game after purchasing you won't be dissapointed. The multi-player is fun for what it is, and a good little side game to play with friends that acts like any other regular PvP shooter/arena style game. That be seeing said the real element to the game I honestly only play DOOM for is the main game, and it is really good. It has sort of a Halo meets Metroid Prime feel to the surroundings with secrets, passageways and areas of monsters to defeat, and nothing feels more satisfying than to break the neck or limbs off a monster while blowing everything away around it. That being said a well rounded game that definitely shows its trademark. That being said, I do have some problems with this game so far.

1. The Campaign is not as long as you may think. The main game does have a decent long storyplot that goes through several areas of the UAC installation and inevitably Hell. But I found the world to be smaller, somewhat linear unlike the older game of Doom 3, which always had you going through endless passageways, installations and areas and constantly discovering something new. In this DOOM however it is all pretty easy to travel and discover everything that game has to offer.

2. It is not Scary. Through my time playing it I have yet to be genuinely scared from the atmosphere, environmental elements or monsters themselves. Unlike the old Dooms and Doom3 where the game was abosultely scary, dark and grimy the new DOOM does not have this all that well. Most areas are bright, monster's are not scary and it is tough to be freightened when you are in big areas constantly blasting away at enemies left and right while ripping through them with a chainsaw. Which is not bad considering, but its tough to be scared when the action drowns it out.

3. The Multiplayer although fun is very bare, it is nothing new but the usual kill or be killed team up match battles. The unlockables are not all that great, and it's just your usual Player vs Player arena style junk that we see in hundreds of games now. It is fun for a while but it will get boring with the same stuff everytime. If have friends to play it is can be very enjoyable and that is about it.

4. No Main Game Co-Op or Co-Op Mods or Options at this point. This was somewhat a huge deal for me when waiting so many years for the next DOOM. I thought maybe finally developers of such great games would come to be aware how fun and successful main game co-op stuff could be. A big intricate main game with your friends is something many fans and my friends wanted to see. But instead there is no real co-op but little side mission/PVP Co-op junk that falls short of what we really wanted. When I first heard about this game and saw the Co-Op in its tags I was so hyped ans hoped for a real main game campaign of Doom filled with Co-op survival action, but it became a letdown and became just another Multiplayer action scroeboard game.

All in All the game is still worth its title and a great game overall that kept me entertained and still entertained with its time. So until than I am going to chainsaw some more monsters!

reviewText:
This is what I wished hard Doom 3 would be back in the day. And Quake 4.

Quake 4 did a silly thing in hamstringing the player down paths like other corridor shooters of the time while the multiplayer was Quake 3 arena at the core. This relaunch of Doom has done the polar opposite where the multiplayer of the beta was slow while the pace of the primary game is ferocious as they come and on the higher difficulties is up there with Doom's spiritual successors like Serious Sam.

Doom does borrow from a lot of modern game mechanics like grenade cooldowns, weapon/armour upgrades and the like. However, it seems to blend in well and isn't a main distraction for the player. The execute-stunned-enemy-to-recover-health mechanic works well as the kills only take a second compared to the slow times of Space Marine and Hatred and help keep the player running on the fast dance of death.

Just try to remember not to grenade yourself, DoomGuy. Rip and Tear.

reviewText:
Let's get something out of the way right now. Doom has never been about Multiplayer. It has always been the single player experience that has driven the game to it's heights.

While this is the fourth Iteration of Doom, it is not Doom 4. It is not a continuation of the jump scares that were used to great effect in Doom 3. Unfortunately the scene deformations are lacking this time around. So if you were hoping for a corridor shooter, You won't get that here.

What you do get are waves of enemies à la the original Doom 1 and Doom 2. Hordes of them. It's fast. It's frantic. It's a bloody good gorefest. Some people might hate the new Glory Kills, but I find them to be gratifying. All the weapoons have impact. If there is anything to be said about a game with great gunplay this has got to be it.

This is a game that is meant to be enjoyed for the sake of enjoyment. It looks gorgeous on my system running at 2560x1440 all settings maxed out, Motion Blur is turned off, on my GTX 980Ti. At these settings, I get a solid 90fps. 4k is somewhat playable at around 47fps all settings maxed out, but I'd take the higher frame rate any day.

I can appreciate that perhaps some people wouldn't like the metal soundtrack, but you know what. That's what DOOM is. It's Dungeons and Dragons, Heavy Metal, and Grit. It's tough as balls.

As far as the multiplayer...I'm not interested. It doesn't (yet) have Local LAN, so I couldn't care less about playing with Randos.

TL;DR
This game is extremely satisfying. Buy this game for a fantastic Single Player experience. Don't buy it just for the Multiplayer.

reviewText:
I was initially very sceptical about the game. A very long and troubled development cycle, no review copies sent out before release, a multiplayer that was poorly received and did not sound or look all that exciting.

I did end up getting it anyway (a good deal on greenmangaming), I had to see what id had done to make a follow-up to what was perhaps my two most favorite games ever.

About 5 seconds after the loadscreen is gone you have a gun in your hand and are shooting zombie guys. 30 seconds later you've violently destroyed a couple more in grotesquely violent melee animations and picked up a shotgun. Shortly you're off over the surface of Mars, through a bunch of sci-fi facilities in the sort of style that Doom 3 laid out, but far more open, expansive and brightly lit. The game looks great, even on medium settings (+85% res) that I was forced to run it at to get a performance that'd sit stable in the 45-60fps range. (2560x1440, 2gb 680gtx, i5 3570k, 16gb ram).

Melee finishing animations were a hotly debated topic, but they are so short they don't interrupt the flow of combat. In later levels they become sort of your in-combat health-regen and later on you can equip a powerup to shorten their duration further.

The gunplay is extremely enjoyable, every single gun has a distinct feel, good sound effects, nice visuals and all are upgradable with interesting alternate firemods that can be upgraded further to improve on their effect, ending up in a Mastery Unlock that buffs the alternate mode fully.

The enemy gallery is almost entirely the classic Doom lineup buffed with a few extra new monsters and new takes on former humans.

Absent from the game are the Arachnotron and the Archvile, the latter replaced by the Summoner the Summoner, a sort of new version of the Archvile. It doesn't feel as threatening, but it shares the agility and speed of all the other monsters in this game.

Which is something quite new and fresh in the FPS genre. The monsters literally jump and climb all over the environment, dodging and weaving to avoid your shots or position themselves to rain lasers down on you. You'll be doing the same, moving with speed up and down ledges, no fall damage is present, so your freedom to move is great. Later in the game you'll get a double-jump and a powerup that lets you move faster after performing melee kills, a powerup that lets you control yourself while in the air much like in Quake 1 and powerups that let you engage melee kills from farther away.
All this combines to a combat system that feels smooth, precise, extremely fun and very rewarding.

I find it to the game's credit that dying seems entirely my own fault for not taking good enough advantage of the options allowed me. And the options are many. You can carry all the game's weapons and you will be swapping between them often and you'll have many, many available approaches in every single fight.

The soundtrack is blazing modern industrial style metal in combat, out of combat there is a light ambient drone, all of it heavily inspired by the original Doom soundtrack. There are many, many eastereggs and little things paying homage to the original games in here and it's clear that it's been made by someone who obviously cared a lot.

With the snapmap editor allowing community creations and a robust replayability, I foresee Doom staying on my drive for quite a while. I hope to see more.

I have not had any experience with the multiplayer, but I'll probably take a look at some point, but it's not why I bought the game and not why you should either, I'd reckon.

Highly recommended.

reviewText: The cerebral slaughterhouse has been resurrected after 12 long years, and it's now morphed into a slicker beast. This time, the emphasis is more on pace & strafing than Doom 3, but in doing so sacrifices any proper narrative and removes the fear-factor it's predecessor had. Also, you no longer encounter any other survivors at the UAC facility, or get to wield the Crucible Artifact, making the whole experience feel a little hollow. None the less, hoards of Doom fans will still lap this up as it up's the brutal violence & Satanic sites, fusing it with thumping hardcore metal tunes. The new melee Glory Kills are a joy to execute when you're in a tight spot, and doesn't affect momentum. In it's current state, the single player campaign is a far more appealing experience over multiplayer.

reviewText:
This is what I wished hard Doom 3 would be back in the day. And Quake 4.

Quake 4 did a silly thing in hamstringing the player down paths like other corridor shooters of the time while the multiplayer was Quake 3 arena at the core. This relaunch of Doom has done the polar opposite where the multiplayer of the beta was slow while the pace of the primary game is ferocious as they come and on the higher difficulties is up there with Doom's spiritual successors like Serious Sam.

Doom does borrow from a lot of modern game mechanics like grenade cooldowns, weapon/armour upgrades and the like. However, it seems to blend in well and isn't a main distraction for the player. The execute-stunned-enemy-to-recover-health mechanic works well as the kills only take a second compared to the slow times of Space Marine and Hatred and help keep the player running on the fast dance of death.

Just try to remember not to grenade yourself, DoomGuy. Rip and Tear.

reviewText:
This game is a fantastic homage to the old Doom while being a beast in its own right. It does well to return to the roots of the Doom nightmare with a new polish and smooth gameplay. Play this game on the highest difficulty you can manage so you can get back into the old habits of strafe and destruction that you needed back in the glory days. Everything about this game wants you to move and never stop. No reloading, no regeneration of health. You want to live? Earn it. Be as brutal as possible to rip health out of your enemies.

Campaign is fast paced, there are secrets, keycards, upgrades, weapons and collectibles galore. It does everything right to punish you when you mess up while making you feel like a beast when you deserve it. Don't stop moving and don't stop shooting. If you're concerned about secrets the game will slow down significatntly as you will backtrack like crazy because they really wanted to hide them from you. I would recommend looking up a guide to unlock the extra content and classic Doom throwback levels. The secrets are not false walls or secret doors, it's exploration of a 3d environment. All in all the experience is very rewarding when you really get your momentum rolling so either gather secrets in your second playthrough or grab a nice guide. That's my personal recommendation because I personally didn't want to totally kill the pacing. Something to consider.

The Multiplayer is even more fast paced as a player vs. player setting will always challenge you more. The game returns to the classic pick up standard. Given, you have loadouts for weapons so you don't need to gather weapons. You do, however, need to pick up health as there is no health regeneration. This incentivizes players to keep moving around the map to kill each other while keeping themselves alive while discouraging players from holing up in corners waiting for the red blood spatter border to fade. You will find 75 kill deathmatches to go very quickly with this classic doom philosophy. This game rewards boldness.

It's a great installment for an aged series and breathes new life into the look and feel of the game. If you played the Brutal Doom mod in the classic games then you will feel right at home.

Rip and tear!

reviewText:
I was playing DOOM II while waiting for Steam to finish setting up the game. As soon as it was ready, I went for it.

First playthrough on Ultra-Violence, no tutorials, no compass or objective markers, simple crosshair, minimal HUD (only health and ammo), no overlays, weapon changes only with keyboard shortcuts.

Let's just say this: the transition from DOOM II couldn't have been smoother and more positively surprising.

In the first 5 minutes you'll be already knee deep in it, blasting away at demons like in the old ones.  Each demon has its own character and combat style: Imps are fiercer and faster than ever, and they come at you from all sides. Hell Knights are agile, fast and deliver some serious blows... and wait 'till you get to the Baron.

Level design is maze-like, combining linear corridors and sections with open ground arenas where most of the action will happen. Playing without markers and compass felt much more like an old school experience: exploring only by relying on visual clues is extremely satisfactory especially when searching for secrets, though the automap is still very useful.

The only complaints I have are related to relatively minor things: one is the presence of two or three story-related scenes that lock you in place for a brief amount of time and they cannot be skipped.
The second one that I noticed is that there are no running speed upgrades apart from the temporary Haste powerup, only combat speed upgrades (weapon and mod switching, faster glory kills, faster mantling) which do improve the pace somewhat, although I would still love to be able to speedup things a bit more, especially when comparing the pace to the old DOOMs.

It does feel like a DOOM with some Quake mechanics thrown in (platforming, air control), but I think those same mechanics have actually helped the game to step into more modern ground and at the same time feel like a unique, original game in its own right. In my opinion they did something that feels so good to play it's almost unbelievable. It's not about franchise purity"
date: it's about fun.\n\nAll in all I think the game feels just right: pace

reviewText:
It feels pure DOOM: 75% oldschool and 25% modern mechanics, also you can mod the Multiplayer all you want and made it more like Quake, Unreal, or Toxikk (fast competitive arena FPS games)

My score for this is 90/100. These are the good and the bad things imo:

Pros:

- Great production, technically excellent with amazing sound and graphics.
- Smooth, fast paced, bloody like hell.
- Level maps and boss designs.
- Metal music with some really good tunes, and a bit of electronic and classical music for each moment.
- The game is so fun and addictive for itself but add a lot of things to do for a better replay value such as secret levels, different paths, upgrades, challenges etc. Nice Easter eggs.
- Glory kills (Melee Fatalities) looks and feel really good and you can disable the visual effect that indicates when an enemy is staggered if you don't like it. With this, you can get bonus ammo and health.
- You can turn off the crosshair, the compass, the objectives... for a more hardcore experience.
- Definitely SnapMap (They key for the ones who are looking for a more competitive multiplayer experience)
- Casual but really fun multiplayer with tons of creative modes and a well designed online world with skins, new weapons and other stuff to unlock while you play.
- Perfect balanced difficulty (Nightmare, the harder one, is really hard) Also you have that same difficulty level but with Perma-death called ''Ultra-Nightmare'')
- Weapons beautifully designed with collectible modifications you can get through the game.
- Spoiler: Classic nostalgic levels hidden inside the campaign and you can play it later from the title menu.
- First time since 90's we see a real good FPS (I mean with an AAA production in the back) with no health/shields regeneration, no reload, tons of beautiful weapons, good maps, and fast combat speed and exploration.


Cons:

- Disappointment achievements, all of them so easy to get.
- The... Story? (I know, is DOOM)
- No coop.
- Expensive Multiplayer DLC.
- Limited Strafe Jump as default (Don't know if you can change that with SnapMap)
- No Rocket Jump and no Plasma Climbing. (SnapMap maybe?)
- It seems this is another PCGame victim of the cross-platform because textures have been downgraded a bit. I can feeling it.

Overall I'm happy with the new DOOM. Games evolve and change, 90's were great but we should accept and love the new era because it does good things too. Not everything is awful nowadays.

---------------------------------------

TL;DR: Good multiplayer (Outsourced) and a brutally gorgeous singleplayer thanks to ID.

reviewText:
Let's get something out of the way right now. Doom has never been about Multiplayer. It has always been the single player experience that has driven the game to it's heights.

While this is the fourth Iteration of Doom, it is not Doom 4. It is not a continuation of the jump scares that were used to great effect in Doom 3. Unfortunately the scene deformations are lacking this time around. So if you were hoping for a corridor shooter, You won't get that here.

What you do get are waves of enemies à la the original Doom 1 and Doom 2. Hordes of them. It's fast. It's frantic. It's a bloody good gorefest. Some people might hate the new Glory Kills, but I find them to be gratifying. All the weapoons have impact. If there is anything to be said about a game with great gunplay this has got to be it.

This is a game that is meant to be enjoyed for the sake of enjoyment. It looks gorgeous on my system running at 2560x1440 all settings maxed out, Motion Blur is turned off, on my GTX 980Ti. At these settings, I get a solid 90fps. 4k is somewhat playable at around 47fps all settings maxed out, but I'd take the higher frame rate any day.

I can appreciate that perhaps some people wouldn't like the metal soundtrack, but you know what. That's what DOOM is. It's Dungeons and Dragons, Heavy Metal, and Grit. It's tough as balls.

As far as the multiplayer...I'm not interested. It doesn't (yet) have Local LAN, so I couldn't care less about playing with Randos.

TL;DR
This game is extremely satisfying. Buy this game for a fantastic Single Player experience. Don't buy it just for the Multiplayer.

reviewText:
Doom is back, this time back as close as it can to its roots, while putting on new polish and new features. However, does it have enough to be the Doom folks have been wanting since the 90s? The answer is a definite 'Yes!', with a caveat or two. Doom delivers a solid singleplayer experience with plenty of love and attention to gameplay, bits of story, and speed. The multiplayer aspect feels like an afterthought, or worse, shoehorned in to try to grasp the old days of Doom multiplayer, while trying to keep it modern, which fails as the system is drastically different than what’s seen in the Singleplayer.

Overall, a must have to any FPS Enthusiast of the 90s, or those who definitely enjoy the frantic pace of the Doom series (not including Doom 3).

Graphics: 10/10
Id Software went out of their way to make some solid effort to bring back the foreboding atmosphere to abandoned facilities all the way to Hell's jagged mountains and corridors. Every sight is as foreboding as it is impressive to the eye, not once leaving the proper atmosphere of the invasion of Mars. Enemies themselves are painstakingly put together in great detail from the Possessed all the way to the Cyberdemon (something you can inspect in great detail later in the game in the gallery). Special effects and particles all play out well, leaving the game a beautiful sight.

Audio: 8/10
Music composed to this game is a nostalgic gamer's dream mixed into a new players love for intense song. Mixing in old classic tunes from the old games for remixes for a modern finish that will speak to old school gamers while still leaving the newcomers enjoying the throbbing tone of a fight in their ears. There are times when the music difference can in fact feel a little jarring, as the difference between fights and exploration ambiance music can be as different as night and day. This does happen a bit in Hell as music can come between hard techno, to suddenly the hellish chorus and orchestra echoing in your speakers. However, the real treat comes from the work put into the guns and the monsters. Almost every gun in the game has avoided the 'nerf gun' feel of firing, from the combat shotgun's ringing blast, all the way to the chaingun firing at full throttle. Only one gun in the collection feels a bit disappointing, the pistol, while only really necessary early game, it never feels like its got much impact in the sound of the shot, but this is minor.

Gameplay: 9/10
It's fast, its chaos, and its gory. The Devs really did listen to their fans this time around, trading the creeping and paranoid inducing feeling of Doom 3, and replacing it with fast run n' gun action that leaves it dangerous to stop at any point in the fight. Of course, there are small respites you can find here and there between fights that allow you to take a breath, but at the same time, while the game is fast paced and chaotic, it doesn't discourage exploration either. With secrets and badly needed supplies everywhere, you can always back track, as most of the time, it'll be rare a portion of the map will be gated off after a certain amount of progress. There are a few negative points, such as the over reliance of the Glory Kill system, especially in later levels where its not an option, its almost mandatory. (Details discussed below) However, every punch, every shot, ever messy take down brings a satisfying sense of speed and thrill that few FPS grasp these days.

Longevity / Replayability: 9/10
Contrary to rumors, DOOM is packed with content from start to finish, most of it all in the Singleplayer, which after my playthrough, lasted between 18-20 hours on the highest difficulty available right out of the box (Ultra-Violence). From secrets, challenges in every map, collectibles to obtain, weapon mods to add to your arsenal, its quite a bit to all get. Thankfully, all this is not locked away should you miss it on finishing a map. You can return to any map any time with all currently obtained equipment and upgrades, allowing you to use the advantage to take on a challenge, or get a leg up to finally reach that possible secret you were having trouble with. That said, all secrets and challenges can be done with the default gear you have during that part of the game. (Eg. No challenges / secrets that cannot be reached without double jump in maps prior to obtaining that skill). After completing the game, you still have time to challenge yourself with two new difficulty settings (Acting much like New Game+), Nightmare, and Ultra-Nightmare, where the latter throws the challenge of permadeath. SnapMap and Multiplayer also add to this, but we'll get into that next.

Multiplayer: 6.5/10
Regretfully, once you load the Multiplayer up, be it SnapMap or Standard Multiplayer, the game changes drastically from its fast paced Singeplayer counterpart. The multiplayer works on a loadout and leveling system, most of which rewards you with cosmetics. Gameplay-wise, the speed is taken down several notches, and the wild combat is somewhat muted, as the guns don't quite have the same impact, and since they are given in loadouts, guns like the Super Shotgun and Rocket Launcher don't quite have the impact folks would expect. There are options to run classical rules, but some of these matches seem devoid of players at this time. Sadly, this part of the game feels shoehorned, simply there to make multiplayer a 'thing' in Doom, which fails to quite grasp the feeling of urgency and intensity.

SnapMap, however, does add some creative credence to the idea of custom work and mod work, adhering to the idea that Doom is a mod friendly game. However, in that same stroke, actual mods of the games players could make are no longer viable. SnapMap replaces this by giving folks tools to make their own maps from between staged Multiplayer, deadly onslaught mode coop, to even missions of their very own to test other players. Including trials to test your modding skill to improve / complete a map, to letting you publish and share your work. More and more features in regards to cosmetics, textures, and objects. The downside is that the setup is rather simplistic, and scripts are rather dumbed down, making it easy for newcomers, but more advance map makers are left wanting more. Possible upgrades later, but for now, it feels like it could do much much more for what its promising.

OVERALL: 8.5/10

Disclaimer: Review was based off a full campaign run on Ultra-Violence difficulty. And 4 hours of Multiplayer and SnapMap

Intel i7
geForce 980 GTX
16Gb RAM DDR5
500 SSD

reviewText:
Doom 2016 is a reboot of the iconic Doom franchise that has us back to square one on Mars awaiting the start of the demon onslaught once again. Unlike the original game that has us be a normal space marine with nothing more than a pistol and the will to live we now start in a giant coffin as some kind of prophesied chosen one. We are then immediately given a robotic suit very similar to the Master Chief's armor from Halo. From waking up from cryogenic sleep to the enemy with the energy shield this whole game feels a lot to Halo with a dash of Painkiller more so than Doom. The levels are not intricate mazes with key card hunting, there is little real enemy placement as they just spawn out of thin air and the secrets are now for collectibles and upgrades instead of vital resources. It's not a critic but something I feel fans of the first two Dooms should be aware of since those games were not arena shooters such as this.

Your first weapon will be the pistol which is as useless as ever though what rather surprised me is how fast you are thrown into the action. Within the first moments of being able to move you are already shooting down foes which is rather unheard of these days. Story is kept to a minimum thankfully and there are no cut scenes though the game will take away control of your character making you listen to characters blather on about uninteresting stuff on occasion. It is rare enough to be a non-issue but when it does happen it is annoying and stops the game dead in its tracks while General Grievous explains backstory to why they opened the portal in the first place and the need to keep it open. Characters are bland, the story is completely predictable and honestly the Codex pages you find scattered around the levels would have been more than enough context to the invasion without slightly damaging the quality of the campaign.

Luckily it has a far heavier focus on pure gameplay where you are given little room to keep the adrenaline down as another wave of demons awaits your every step. It's the closest a Triple A game has been to the fast paced, balls to the walls action of yesteryear in a very long time. There is no hiding behind cover or hit-scan projectiles here instead you will always be on the move and surrounded on all sides while mowing down enemies with absurdly impractical yet glorious weaponry. Add to that the ability to double jump and very good AI and you have a recipe for a good time. All the Doom enemies minus the Elemental and the Arachnotron are back and ready to rip and tear you to pieces. Many of the monsters are pretty much unrecognizable from their previous appearances like the Summoner that represents the Arch-vile in this game and the Imp looking like a fleshy Halo Promethean. It's cool to see how they are  redesigned into the modern age and now appear far more threatening than their counterparts of the 90's.

They don't just appear more threatening but the enemies like the Imps and Pinkys are now far more capable of killing you than ever before. Imps are very agile and cling to walls while flinging projectiles while Pinkys are now the true tanks they were meant to be and an enemy you really don't want to face head on. The Barons of Hell are the stars of the show being giant charging beasts capable of sending you sailing across the sky by just punching the ground near you and throwing fast moving projectiles from a distance. There is just a ton of variety between the monsters and seeing how your childhood foes now fight with the power brought to you by over 20 years of technical progress is just amazing. One thing that bothered me was your movement speed being a bit too slow making it a bit harder to deal with shielded enemies among other things.

In single player you can carry all weapons at once meaning you always have the right tools for the job taking the luck out of carrying the right weapon at the right time very common in modern FPS games. There is no reloading either which really helps with the flow of combat since no one wants the needless realism of waiting for your gun to reload in game about killing demons with a chainsaw on Mars. All of your weapons have two alt fires you can switch between that really spice up the variety in your already vast arsenal of weapons. They are pretty wacky as well like an Assault Rifle firing mini rockets at your enemies and charging up your shotgun to fire three consecutive blasts to annihilate your foes. Causing your opponents to gib is a bloody satisfying feeling in this title.

Levels themselves have a ton of secrets scattered around the place and are pretty well hidden. You can easily go from arena to arena in a linear fashion but branching off the beaten path gets you some pretty nice rewards such as an orb that increases your overall health, armor or ammo limit to entire retro levels of the original Doom in all its low res'd texture goodness. It's an interesting process to finding the retro levels, first you must pull a random lever hidden somewhere in the level which in turn opens up a wall somewhere else. You can play these levels from the campaign menu though they feature Doom 2016 enemies, weapons and gameplay so these are mostly one of nostalgia extras. There are also challenge stones hidden about that unlock single player perks such as more control while in air but to unlock them is a challenge as you are always given a very short time limit to do whatever they ask of you.

Glory kills is in my opinion the greatest flaw in the combat. Killing wounded enemies in that matter makes them drop health for you which is weird but I can live with but the way it is implemented is terrible. When you shoot an enemy enough they have a very good chance of being stunned which in itself doesn't sound too bad but imagine being swarmed by enemies and shooting one point blank with a shotgun only for it to stagger a bit while you do the same to another enemy but that one explodes into bloody pieces. It feels very inconsistent and not killing them in time will have them recover to full health. So you either waste some more ammo to kill the stunned enemy or enter a cheesy animation that is far too zoomed in on the enemy making it very hard to see what's going on in the battlefield while manhandling that demon for a few seconds.

Snapmap is ID's replacement for proper modding and allows you to make preset rooms and place enemies as well as edit gameplay options such as movement speed, damage and game mode rules. You'll see stuff like survival modes, playing as demons and a weird Harvest Moon clone to name a few of the creative things you can do. It's pretty easy to use and maps are all shared between PS4, Xbx1 and PC which is going to lead to a massive amount of options for the fanbase. It is a double edged sword though. Since maps have to be playable on the hardware of the consoles there is a pretty small limit to the amount you can add to the maps. You and up to three strangers can play on multiplayer supported Snap maps. Multiplayer is where Doom 2016 falls on it's face. Perks, small uninteresting maps and taunts like a dudebro teabagging option make this portion of the game feel run of the mill. Not to mention the two weapon limit, loadouts where you can start with any weapon you want and the season pass that focuses entirely on multiplayer and will most likely split up the playerbase. Team Deathmatch's only unique feature is the ability to play as a demon. It's a pretty annoying feature that has a rune randomly spawn on the map with a few seconds of warning. It would have been better to announce it far ahead of its spawn arrival to cause players to fight over that area instead of blind luck to have it. When all is said and done Doom 2016's is a flawed yet fun overall package but its campaign is one of the best the FPS genre has had to offer in a very long time and one I'm itching to replay time and time again.

reviewText:
I was playing DOOM II while waiting for Steam to finish setting up the game. As soon as it was ready, I went for it.

First playthrough on Ultra-Violence, no tutorials, no compass or objective markers, simple crosshair, minimal HUD (only health and ammo), no overlays, weapon changes only with keyboard shortcuts.

Let's just say this: the transition from DOOM II couldn't have been smoother and more positively surprising.

In the first 5 minutes you'll be already knee deep in it, blasting away at demons like in the old ones.  Each demon has its own character and combat style: Imps are fiercer and faster than ever, and they come at you from all sides. Hell Knights are agile, fast and deliver some serious blows... and wait 'till you get to the Baron.

Level design is maze-like, combining linear corridors and sections with open ground arenas where most of the action will happen. Playing without markers and compass felt much more like an old school experience: exploring only by relying on visual clues is extremely satisfactory especially when searching for secrets, though the automap is still very useful.

The only complaints I have are related to relatively minor things: one is the presence of two or three story-related scenes that lock you in place for a brief amount of time and they cannot be skipped.
The second one that I noticed is that there are no running speed upgrades apart from the temporary Haste powerup, only combat speed upgrades (weapon and mod switching, faster glory kills, faster mantling) which do improve the pace somewhat, although I would still love to be able to speedup things a bit more, especially when comparing the pace to the old DOOMs.

It does feel like a DOOM with some Quake mechanics thrown in (platforming, air control), but I think those same mechanics have actually helped the game to step into more modern ground and at the same time feel like a unique, original game in its own right. In my opinion they did something that feels so good to play it's almost unbelievable. It's not about franchise purity"

reviewText:
Ok, ok. Having spend a significant amount of time with the new DOOM, I can say that it is one of my favourite games of all time now.

Here the cliffnotes:

Pros
beautiful audio-visual design. Looks and sounds as you would expect a modern DOOM to look and sound
Fantastic single player campaign. Very straight forward fun. Non-linear maps. Lots of secrets. Weapon upgrades etc.
High-speed combat in kill rooms. The game will funnel you into these open areas with tons of enemies. If you want to survive you have to keep moving. Awesome fun.
SNAPMAP - Ok, this is great. It will give the game infinite replayability. It is like Portal2's steam workshop support. Basically, like a Doom version of MarioMaker. Plus it is fun and easy to use and you can play with your friends in COOP. Brilliant.
Performance. The game runs like butter and you have a gazillion settings to manipulate. On a single 980ti the game runs in Ultra/Nightmare settings at 3440x1440 (21:9) almost always at a 100+ fps, with occasional dips into the high 70s. Good stuff, considering we are not even playing the Vulkan version yet.

Cons

The competitive multiplayer may be a con for you, if you expect a full Quake 3 Arena or Unreal Tournament type game. Personally, I love the multiplayer. It feels fresh for Doom. It is like a mix between Quake 3 and Halo multiplayer. For me it works, but if you are going to buy the game just for the multiplayer. Understand what you are getting.


Overall, I am extremely happy about how the game turned out. If you are a fan of DOOM, you will at the very least love the campaign and SNAPMAP mode.

reviewText:
This game is a fantastic homage to the old Doom while being a beast in its own right. It does well to return to the roots of the Doom nightmare with a new polish and smooth gameplay. Play this game on the highest difficulty you can manage so you can get back into the old habits of strafe and destruction that you needed back in the glory days. Everything about this game wants you to move and never stop. No reloading, no regeneration of health. You want to live? Earn it. Be as brutal as possible to rip health out of your enemies.

Campaign is fast paced, there are secrets, keycards, upgrades, weapons and collectibles galore. It does everything right to punish you when you mess up while making you feel like a beast when you deserve it. Don't stop moving and don't stop shooting. If you're concerned about secrets the game will slow down significatntly as you will backtrack like crazy because they really wanted to hide them from you. I would recommend looking up a guide to unlock the extra content and classic Doom throwback levels. The secrets are not false walls or secret doors, it's exploration of a 3d environment. All in all the experience is very rewarding when you really get your momentum rolling so either gather secrets in your second playthrough or grab a nice guide. That's my personal recommendation because I personally didn't want to totally kill the pacing. Something to consider.

The Multiplayer is even more fast paced as a player vs. player setting will always challenge you more. The game returns to the classic pick up standard. Given, you have loadouts for weapons so you don't need to gather weapons. You do, however, need to pick up health as there is no health regeneration. This incentivizes players to keep moving around the map to kill each other while keeping themselves alive while discouraging players from holing up in corners waiting for the red blood spatter border to fade. You will find 75 kill deathmatches to go very quickly with this classic doom philosophy. This game rewards boldness.

It's a great installment for an aged series and breathes new life into the look and feel of the game. If you played the Brutal Doom mod in the classic games then you will feel right at home.

Rip and tear!

reviewText:
For new players, Doom offers an interesting break from the usual first-person shooter style you might be familiar with (Call of Duty, Halo 5, etc.) and instead puts a focus on in-your-face, bloody combat. You'll be close with your enemies in this game, rather than picking them off from a longer distance. And it's this close-quarters focus that really brings out the game's intensity. It's constant, fast-paced action all the way through, with only occasional breaks from the carnage.

For classic Doom veterans, this game is not too far from the norm of a Doom game. It's fast-paced, visceral and brutal. You can feel like a true badass again, destroying anything in your path, but you're never shy of a challenge. The demons will mess you up if you don't keep yourself killing. And of course, just like any true Doom game, you should always be on the move.

The campaign has a nice story to it, but it rarely forces you to pay attention to it. You spend more time killing demons, which is a great thing. Most story segments you can actually just walk away from and continue killing.

Doom also introduces some new mechanics, such as glory kills - fully animated executions performed against your enemies, each one gory and...well, glorious. You have a variety of unique guns to choose from, just like any good first-person shooter, but in singleplayer, you get to modify your weapons with upgrades, new firemodes, and the like. You can also upgrade your suit abilities in singleplayer - anything from blast resistance, to a more intricate map. Further suit upgrades can be achieved through obtaining runes - gained by completing quick challenges. These runes let you get new benefits, such as armor-for-kills or increased mobility.

The multiplayer modes are, surprisingly, a really strong point of the game. Deathmatch game modes can get hectic and crazy, especially if you bring friends along. The demon rune" - a powerup that lets you turn into a demon for a short amount of time - can be a real game changer

If theres on very small issue I had with its the fact that some of the jumping puzzles in the early and mid game drag on for abit too long and are just kinda annoying.

Overall multiplayer is not worth bothering with, it hasnt really improved from the BETA and its not even by Id anyway. It was outsourced to a studio that does Halo and CoD stuff. Snap map on the other hand has some potential to be a really great tool for DOOM modders and level designers to make some really great stuff. I cant wait to play some of the levels by the community soon.

Finally If you dont have a 900+ plus card you can expect some preformance issues. reviewText:
Where to start?

The Campaign

Spent 12-15 hours on my first playthrough just exploring and admiring the fully fleshed out gameplay, enviornments, and not to mention the brutally amazing soundtrack. I did a second playthrough spending twice as much time just unlocking stuff and hunting for secrets and easter eggs. I guess I was a little obsessed, but damn. If the campaign doesn't pull you in to it then you must be playing the wrong game. For this alone I felt the game was well worth the purchase. The replay factor with Nightmare and Ultra-Nightmare is just icing on the cake.

Snap Map

I started Snap Map tutorials a while back and finished a day or two after. It's got me hooked. Sure, there are some limitations (IMO due to cross-platform modding being enabled), but it's pretty fun just messing around with its capabilites. Even in it's current state it potentially allows for longevity of the multiplayer community. The dozen or so featured maps should give you a good idea of it's potential.

Multiplayer

Checked out the Multiplayer. Feels incomplete and pretty sloppy by online FPS standards. Classic games such as FFA and CTF are missing. The TDM and Warpath modes seem to not cater to teamplay.  Hitboxes and network issues make it a pretty whacky experience. Leading shots with a hitscan sniper rifle (Vortex Rifle) and still hitting targets is a pretty bad sign. Demon runes being in almost every game mode may get annoying after a while (I'm already there).

My biggest gripe with the multiplayer is the mobility hamper. The jumping is floaty, but there is no air control like the campaign had. The gunplay rewards twitch shooting and good reactions, but the mobility factors don't allow any kind of evasive maneuvers. The double jump only lets you grab higher ledges, but in reality it just makes you a floating target for a longer period of time. I question why there are so many maps with high grabbable ledges and platforms when it feels like such a risk to jump in the first place.

Yeah I know. It was outsourced to different devs, but in it's current state I feel it needs major improvements to stand on its own.

reviewText:
Playing the new doom after waiting 12 long years is like a dream come true. The story is just sction packed and the multiplayer is fast paced and foreign to the FPS games that are currently available.

THE STORY:
Bhop is love. Bhop is life. You could literally run through the entire story bhopping all over the place. In the harder game modes (nightmare and above), it is key to keep moving and thus the bhop is great. I havent played any lower than hurt me plenty and i dont plan too. But i digress. Its action packed where it needs to be and the demon spawn is endless for the most part. It does on the other hand have a rpg element where i feel it shouldnt be. You can upgrade your weapons and armour which is great but then it makes the game easier turning a few shotgun shells into one. Having more than 100 health. You start off with 50 armour and i thought that was great but then found it can be pushed higher again. I love this game and runs perfect on ultra graphics on a 760 gtx.

MULTIPLAYER:
Again the bhop is king. TDM is fast paced where you need to make split second decisions to survive. Prepare to get anal fisted by your opponents until you get the hang of things and level up. Massive amounts of customisation on your armour and weapons from colours and symbols to different armour sets. Ultimately the multiplayer is a fantastic addition to the game and better yet runs on a seperate client to the single player. Matches may take a while to get organised for some reason. Possibly people are playing the campaign first. And those who have played the multiplayer can be high leveled with better weapons, which makes it more difficult.

VERDICT:
Singleplayer: 9/10
Multiplayer: 8/10

Overall:

BUY THIS GAME!!! GET ♥♥♥ RAPED BY DEMONS!!!

reviewText:
Doom is back with a big ♥♥♥♥ing BANG and plenty of demons for us to slaughter in unimaginable ways.

Performance & optimisation
The game looks stunning and plays like a charm I have only had one freeze since I bought it on it's release date. I am playing in max settings(ultra) in 1440p with a GTX980 4GB and an i7 4790k CPU and the optimisation is amazing throughout my 20+ hours of gameplay iv maintained 60+ FPS.

Single player campaign
The main story of the game takes roughly around 10-13 hours to complete depending on if your looking for collectibles/secrets. The story evolves around Mars and Mars installations and eventually takes you to hell where the entire game world such as textures, lighting etc look beautiful. Along with amazing heavy metal guitar music and hordes of demons to kill with plenty or weaponry and executions in the form of glory kill.

Mulitplayer
The multiplayer is fun and addicting with plenty of armor and weapons customisation to choose from. Their are multiple game modes to play and although fun for a short time on your own I can very easily play the PvP side of it all day long in a group of friends.  The multiplayer reminds me of Halo but on a smaller arena and old school based scale featuring health/ammo and armor pickups aswell as powerups and special weapons.

Buthowever Bethesda need to sort the servers out as I have noticed even though they are dedicated multiplayer servers a few players lagging or disconnecting due to poor connection. Hopefully they will let us select our region in a future update to ensure we aren't connecting with Americans when were in the EU and vice versa.

Snapmap
Snapmap from what I can tell is a custom editing mode for creating your own maps or game modes. I have no interest in playing this but if I do I will update my review on what I think of it.

Overall Verdict
Doom is a remarkable game full of carnage, blood and guts, amazing music and hordes of demons in a truly excellent single player and multiplayer experience.

BUY DOOM NOW!!

8/10 - Would be a 9 if they fix the connection issues in multiplayer.

Doom gets a big fat thumbs up from.

reviewText:
23 Hours with almost 100% completion:
- All secrets.
- All armor upgrades.
- All stat upgrades.
- All weapon upgrades except last one on rocket launcher (hit 3 with triggered rocket).
- All runes upgraded.
- All level challenges.

Boy was it an amazing 23 hours. The game has so much content in single player that it didn't disappoint. The boss battles were amazing. The Cyber Demon (Not a spoiler! Doom without Cyber Demon isn't Doom) fight dwarfs the one from Doom 3.

I enjoyed doing rune, weapon and level challenges while playing. They really made me vary my playstyle as I progressed. I almost never played the same way each level. I made good use of the weapon alternate firing styles. The models, weapons look amazing and the levels look great but I still believe Alien Isolation had the best space corridor levels ever, this can come second.

The story is actually really well done! It just fits. Don't expect amazing story but a story that works with this kind of game and setting; Not complex but flows well. The codex were fun to read. The BFG and Chainsaw implementation is the best so far!

The amount of enemies chasing you in tight places is amazing and the fact that they can jump ledges and chase you to almost anywhere is really scary. You need to keep on your toes to stay alive. I played on UV btw (I didn't notice that Nightmare was actually unlocked from the beginning ><).

I like that glory-kills can have so many different purposes and not just a gimmick. It just works.

Forget the MP and Snapmap is a possible oppertunity.

It is all in the SP and there is almost little to no downtime related to Story. You can just zoom in through the entire game, bar one instance, fighting. I was hoping for a NG+ with no focus on collecting or secrets, just action. But alas that isn't implemented.

Oh and for those who were dissappointed in Doom 3 (and RoE) because of a missing foe, be prepared to glee in glorious joy when you reach the end of this game

reviewText: The cerebral slaughterhouse has been resurrected after 12 long years, and it's now morphed into a slicker beast. This time, the emphasis is more on pace & strafing than Doom 3, but in doing so sacrifices any proper narrative and removes the fear-factor it's predecessor had. Also, you no longer encounter any other survivors at the UAC facility, or get to wield the Crucible Artifact, making the whole experience feel a little hollow. None the less, hoards of Doom fans will still lap this up as it up's the brutal violence & Satanic sites, fusing it with thumping hardcore metal tunes. The new melee Glory Kills are a joy to execute when you're in a tight spot, and doesn't affect momentum. In it's current state, the single player campaign is a far more appealing experience over multiplayer.

What an absolute gem this game is. id shows nobody can outdo them in the genre they invented.

First off this game is absolutely gooorgeous. No brown hallways here. Everything is super vibrant and the vast mars landscape views are really something. And it plays even better than it looks. Long gone are the dark hallways and spooky scares of the old games. They've been replaced with high octane encounters full of a variety of monsters requiring the player to think on their feet while blasting away.

Each gun and the player himself is also customizable in their mechanics, allowing the player to really tweak their experience to their play style.

It's just, a marvel. Seriously. I'm in love. Probably the best pure fps flow/ mechanics game ever made. Period.

Absolutely perfect 10/10.

reviewText:
+ Fast, fluid gameplay succesfully capturing most of the old school DooM feel
+ I love the fragmented metal-industrial-glitchy soundtrack. It's tight, modern, dynamic and brutal. It's not as rememberable als Doom 1 or 2, but it gets me in the mood all the time.
+ You know what I despise about modern shooters? The fact that you can't backtrack from start to end of a level. None of this in Doom 4. You can fully explore back and forwards at your own damn leisure just like old times.
- [edit:]...at least, that's what I thought. Unfortunately there are some too many points where the level designers thought it *would* be a good idea not to let the player backtrack all the way to the start. A weak, infuriating and ununderstandable design choice. [/edit]
+ And there's a lot to find and explore on the levels. I would recommend disabling the compass and using the map to a bare minimum because that makes it a bit too easy to discover everything, but on the other hand.. well, suit yourself.
-+ There are some very hard to find secrets, if you're set on discovering all of the classic maps. It's fun to actually discover one yourself without looking it up on the internet, but it's not likely to happen with every one of them.
+ I actually like the weapon and armor upgrade system. It's redundant, but at the same time fun enough to keep yourself occupied with so why not. Same goes for the challenge levels.
+- Enemies come in waves instead of placed thoughtfully throughout the levels. However these waves themselves have been orchestrated pretty well and are fun to beat, it's not too bad at all (one has got to love Painkiller after all).
+- There's still something left of the chunky, too shiny too clean too round environments that made me insta-dislike Doom 3 so much back then. But many improvements have been made over it, it does look and feels good this time around.
+- Also I'm not the biggest fan of the lighting used in this game. Sometimes it's perfectly fine, sometimes it gets very oversaturated and foggy. It's very nice and thoughtful that you can actually change the rendering to gritty or cinematic, although I find myself switching between the modes depending on where I am instead of just using one setting the whole time. It's a bit of a mixed bag to my taste.
- Still too much exposition. Why the hell do we need a boring generic seen-it-before-too-many-times storyline? This is not Doom 3 (thank god)
- This is Doom 4. Not Doom, not Doom 2016, Doom 4. Seriously, name your game properly guys.
- Just ignore the multiplayer. It's not Doom, it will never be Doom. Snap Map seems interesting though, but I yet have to dive into that at this point.

All in all this game actually turned out to be great. It was really hard to believe anything good would come out of this game after that very mediocre multiplayer open beta, but you better believe it: Doom 4 is awesome. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
This is it. The long-awaited 4th game in the DOOM series has finally arrived.

The Positives
General
Fast-paced 90's style action. No hiding to regenerate health!
Amazing graphics.
Large selection of weapons that don't need to reload.
Campaign
No distracting cutscenes, all action!
Great level design.
Hidden collectibles and levels from the classic DOOM games.
Multiplayer
The customization and taunts to show off the personality of your character.
SnapMap
Easy to use.
You can make custom gamemodes.
The Negatives
General
Very prone to crashes.
Campaign
Too focused on arena fights.
Multiplayer
Hackers are getting more and more common.
No server browser.
No Free-for-all gamemode.
Loadouts and hack modules.
DLC is overpriced. $40 for just a few maps?
SnapMap
Too many limits.
No hell theme.
12 monsters max active.
2 weapon limit.
No pistol and chainsaw.


What to improve on
Invent an anti-cheat system to eliminate hackers.
Add a server browser.
Add Free-for-all gamemode.
Add an option to disable loadouts and hack modules for servers.
Add more themes & modules for SnapMap.
Remove monster and weapon limits.


Rating: 9.5/10
The campaign alone totally deserves 10 points out of 10! Half a point off because the multiplayer mode is worthless and SnapMap is lacking.

reviewText:
The singel player is a fantastic game, but I can't say anything about the mp or snapmap since I haven't tested them yet. This is everything I wanted in a doom game and more! I really liked the emphasis on upgrading weapons and runes, the challenges and secrets to find in the levels. The nods to the old 90's doom games was great as well! So glad they decided to drop the old COD-like build of doom they presented a few years back, and develop this instead!

The only thing that I can think of that detracts from it, is that it's a little bit buggy, at least for me. It has hard crashed my pc two times, to the point where my pc was non-responsive and I had to do a hard reset. And one time where it just crashed to desktop. I didn't loose that much gameplay time since the checkpoints are rarely far between, but it's an annoyance none the less. There were a few bugs in-game as well, such as falling through the level, getting stuck in geometry and so on, but overall I'd say the game is pretty well polished!

I used 23.5 hours to get through the singel player on hurt me plenty difficulty, and I took my time to explore the levels, search for secrets, upgrade stuff, read the lore and so on. I think most people will use about 14 hours or so to just get through the game.

Pros:
Fantastic graphics
Really good level design
Top notch character and monster design
Top of it's class shooter
Rune and weapon upgrade system
Lots of secrets
Cons:
A bit buggy
My Grade: 9/10

reviewText: I'm far from completing Doom 4 but the campaign feels like the old Doom I remember. Its fast and frenetic. Bethseda also brought back the Cacodemons missing in Doom3 so I'm happy. I havn't tried the multiplayer yet which was disappointing in the beta release. The graphics on my MSI GTX 780 have been solid. If you access the Doom console you can check the FPS using com_showfps 1 and switch it off with com_showfps 0. I'm getting a steady 60fps with occasional dips but I've switched it off. There are also many other console commands with cheats like unlimited ammo, god mode etc but I'm not interested in those. There are secret areas which can be revealed. I'll probably try to find those on a separate play through. The melee works well and is important to use to preserve ammo in the harder settings. Bethseda did a decent job much better than Doom 3. Recommended.

reviewText:
This is DOOM 3.
Doom 3 never happened. Please, just trust me. Doom 3 literally does not exist. This game, however, is the actual DOOM 2 follow-up. Building on the spirit, speed and goregasm that made the original two the influential, industry significant and timeless games they are means this reboot needs to be celebrated.

Holy hell, this is beyond ultra-violence. There is so, so much blood. It's ridiculously fast. It's instantly fun. It's so sprawling in both its vertical and horizontal level design and best of all is that the single player campaign feels lovingly crafted. This is DOOM. This is DOOM 3. This is MY CHILDHOOD RELIVED.

Pure joy.

On a final note relating to performance; This PC release is easily the most optimised release I've experienced in a long time... and on a launch day. This too needs celebrating.

Here's my very mixed recommendation. I went with Yes" because I at least liked the game enough to finish it and Steam doesn't have a "Maybe" option. I beat the campaign on ultra violence in 9 hours.

Pros
------------------------------

reviewText:
No more than 10 seconds into the game, you're already fighting. Shortly after that, yo're tearing demons up with a shotgun. From there, it just get's more brutal.

THIS is the Doom that long time FPS fans have been waiting for. With all the same crap flooding the genre, Doom is a welcome return to what made FPS games great.

- Fast paced combat with tight controls.
- Fight and move in every angle. Demonds don't just come at you from the front.
- Primary/secondary weapons? Nope! An arsenal on your back ensures you have multiple ways to fight at any time.
- Great graphics yet keeps minimum specs low.
- Lots of gore accompanied by heavy metal.
- Actually earn the right to feel like a badass, and not just an artifical winner (*cough* COD *cough*)
- Explore each map to find secrets, collectibles, weapons and ammo.
- Locked door? Dead end? Tough ♥♥♥♥. Find a key or another way. Prepare to explore each map.
- This is no corridor shooter. There is no one way only.
- There's a story... I guess. But that's not what you're here for.

The FPS genre is sorely missing this kind of fun gameplay. Future shooters can learn A LOT from Doom. Hell, they could learn a lot from any of the Doom games.

Overall, an excellent game and looking to be the shooter of the year. Maybe even the decade. Hell, since the last Doom.

Welcome home Doomguy. We missed you.

(Played only single player)

Played lots of DOOM back in the days when I was young, remember playing it with a friend linking 2 PC's with a cross-cable. Great fun!

Nowadays the old DOOM feels a bit slow and bare. Sign of the times. This DOOM is a product of this age, and deliveres the goodies we expect, BUT with that same old run-and-shoot feeling like before. Damn, I really like this game and was having fun the first time I booted it up. Shoot, run, turn, dodge, jump, I like it. Love it! Sound(track) is also great, visuals are good, I like the mix of cell-shaded with the 'normal' visuals, mechanics are good (Jumps need to be good, not pixel perfect), weapons feel great most of the time.

All in all : instabuy imo

reviewText:
The best way I can sum up DOOM 4:
If old DOOM was a rebellious teenager with an attitude and very strong views on what is cool or not,
then DOOM 4 is a 5 year old hyperactive brat with ADHD who lives to break things, scream at his parents and smash his action figures together till they break.
His mother has forgotten to give him his ritalin, and he won't stop until the entire family home is nothing but chaos.

DOOM 4 does to DOOM 1+2 what Hotline Miami 2 did to Hotline Miami 1. (If you know what I mean).

After the events of DOOM 1+2, Doomguy became so annoyed at the UAC and Hell that he decided to destroy every incarnation of hell he could find (WADs). The demons couldn't kill this man. He was becoming more than simply human.
Unable to kill Doomguy, the demons decided to trap him inside a mystical tomb to keep Hell safe. So scared of Doomguy waking up infact, that they would kill anybody who got too close to the tomb.

The UAC managed to recover the sarcophagus Doomguy was held inside, taking him back to Mars. However, Doomguy is a light sleeper.
The UAC are messing with Hell portals again. Demons are running amok once more with nobody to teach them a lesson. Won't they ever learn?

It the midst of all this chaos, it seems an ancient evil has awakened.
It's you.

reviewText:
No more than 10 seconds into the game, you're already fighting. Shortly after that, yo're tearing demons up with a shotgun. From there, it just get's more brutal.

THIS is the Doom that long time FPS fans have been waiting for. With all the same crap flooding the genre, Doom is a welcome return to what made FPS games great.

- Fast paced combat with tight controls.
- Fight and move in every angle. Demonds don't just come at you from the front.
- Primary/secondary weapons? Nope! An arsenal on your back ensures you have multiple ways to fight at any time.
- Great graphics yet keeps minimum specs low.
- Lots of gore accompanied by heavy metal.
- Actually earn the right to feel like a badass, and not just an artifical winner (*cough* COD *cough*)
- Explore each map to find secrets, collectibles, weapons and ammo.
- Locked door? Dead end? Tough ♥♥♥♥. Find a key or another way. Prepare to explore each map.
- This is no corridor shooter. There is no one way only.
- There's a story... I guess. But that's not what you're here for.

The FPS genre is sorely missing this kind of fun gameplay. Future shooters can learn A LOT from Doom. Hell, they could learn a lot from any of the Doom games.

Overall, an excellent game and looking to be the shooter of the year. Maybe even the decade. Hell, since the last Doom.

Welcome home Doomguy. We missed you.

reviewText:
Note: I'm only marking this game as recommended pertaining to the single player, NOT THE MULTIPLAYER, WHICH IS TERRIBAD.
As of this writing I have completed the single player route on ultra violence and played enough multiplayer to reach level 20-something (after putting 8+ hours into the open beta, and being very little different from that, I didn't feel like playing multiplayer anymore.)

The good (SP):
The music KICKS MAJOR DEMON BACKSIDE. (even the menu music is amazing.)
The guns are nice and varied, but each one has its strong and weak situations.
The game isn't EZ-mode walkabout like some big-name FPS games, and it doesn't hold your hand TOO much.
The audio (aside from the music) is VERY good, very punchy and visceral, it makes the game sound alive and ..well, DOOM-y.
The enemy AI isn't scripted. It's also not stupid. They can do just about any move you can, and then some. Some are combat closers, some rush, some hang back and shoot from range, but they also change their roles depending on what you are doing to their fellow bad guys. In short, VERY well done.
The glory-kill system is fun, and varied enough that you don't get sick of using it.
The maps, look, amazing. The DEMONIC maps even more so, there are varied details everywhere, the overall feel of the maps change as you get further toward key places, giving a solid feel of progression through the world and into the pits of hell, and then back again.
The animations all across the board are some of the best I have ever seen in an action title.
The character design going WITH those animations is also top notch.
The writing and world building entries are thick and plenty, clearly showing that Bethesda does in fact care about game lore and whatnot even if its DOOM. I enjoyed reading every thing I unlocked/encountered.
The bad (SP):
There is a little too much micromanagement, upgrades to your suit and weapons and whatnot. It's not really what a DOOM game needs, but its not done poorly either.
Periodically the glory-kill system will put your camera thru a wall or map object for a few moments (however, never getting stuck when this happens is nice),but its also very rare.
Strange bug when loading a map/restarting a map. Might be driver related.. game will choke down to exceedingly low FPS and stay there until you alt-enter the game to a window and then alt-enter it full screen again. (this also happened in RAGE as well, and was later fixed.), but again, this happens rarely, and only at the very start of a area, so its fairly minor.
A few CTD's here and there. (Crash to desktop) Only had about 4 the entire play through, showing this is very much a Bethesda game... :) This will likely be fixed.
OVERALL:
I highly recommend the crap out of this game for the single player, its as good if not WAY better than Bethesda's work on Wolfenstien, and I'm looking forward to more playthroughs and secret finding and unlocking of all the goodies. I might even make some stuff in snap-map.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If your interest in this game is single player, stop reading, from here on in things get nasty, mean, and ugly REAL fast.

I had a scathing review of all the problems in the multiplayer beta, it sat on the front page of the beta review for four days and had a %87+ ratio at the time the beta was taken down. I pointed out the blatent halo-ism of the multiplayer, the problems with the audio, netcode, the weapons balance and the, frankly, lack of effort put into making the multipayer. Now that the game is released, I have gone back and re-evaluated all my previous points of concern and..well, here you have it.

The good? (MP):
It looks nice, being as all the game assets are from the single player, that is to be expected.
You can unlock stuff that looks neat. (It even looks like they yanked some of the halo-lookalikes and replaced them with variants that fit the new-doom-lore better.)
It has guns..?
The pings seem to be better, but that doesn't mean a whole lot since the servers are all entirtely hosted by Bethesda and ID, they just added more capacity on their end.
The bad..(MP):
NO CO-OP? WHAT THE EVER LOVING HELL BETHESDA? No, really. Which one of you guys-in-ties thought that was a good design choice? Because you need to be slapped upside the head with the north end of a southbound pinkie demon.
Every game mode is basically team deathmatch. No, really. In this game mode you chase and guard a circle! In this game mode there are more than one circle and they sit still! In THIS one you are playing team deathmatch and you just have to pick up an extra thing people drop when they die! And in THIS one.. Well, you get the idea. Do you LOVE team deathmatch? Because Certain Affinity sure as ♥♥♥♥ does, and NOTHING ELSE. This is DOOM.. and there is no straight up ♥♥♥♥ing deathmatch anywhere. And I couldn't even test Clan arena because *no players were found*.. just a few days after launch.
The Audio is even *more ♥♥♥♥ed than the beta*.. Before, you could hear firefights clear across the map.. but not rockets exploding on your back or in your face. Now you can't hear really anything. No, really, you can't hear a rocket explode 2 inches on the ground behind you. But you can hear this... really strange.. pitter patter sound that I think is supposed to be.. bullets hitting things? In the far far distance like somebody was tapping away at the nearest wall with a BB-gun. It literally makes no sense.
Weapon balance is still completely hosed. They basically didn't change anything from the beta they just unlocked the rest of the weapons you can use. Combined with the fact you can't /hear weapon fire around you/ for beans, the super shotgun is pretty much an instant kill gun. Supershotgun+glorykill-button-spam=win. That's how to multiplayer.
Explosions still basically do nothing, nothing has knock back in this game.
The little numbers that pop off players when you shoot them.. seem to be calculated client side, and therefor sometimes highly inaccurate. (When I hit a guy for 25-25-25-25-25-25-25-15.. and he kills me, and the post-kill screen shows him as having 85 health left at the time he killed me, I call ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t on your game code skillz, K?)

I could go on, but frankly.. I don't care anymore.


Multiplayer Roundup:
This is not the next 'doom multiplayer' or even the next 'Action FPS multiplayer' experience, its just 'generic multiplayer FPS with a doom skin and a demon spawn', its not even a contender for competitive FPS play, its strictly casual nonsense and frankly its not even really that fun after the first hour or two.


Remember all that 'feedback' they were gathering from the multiplayer beta for 'development reasons'? Remember how I warned you it was all a big fat marketing lie? Yeah, it was. They changed one thing, the stupid audio bias, and they didn't even fix it, they fudged it even more. That is it. The weapons are still jacked, the game modes people all asked for are not there, nobody can host a dedicated server. Yep, that's the list. So the console kids who think this is as good as FPS multiplayer can get are gobbling it up, and will abandon the game as soon as the next shiny thing rolls past. The multiplayer is more or less as forgettable as I feared after the beta.

I give it 6 months and it'll be a ghost town unless there is some severe intervention by the developers. (which IS possible, and if that happens, I'll update this review!)

reviewText:
As a singleplayer game, I love the new DOOM and would definitely recommend it. The campaign is very fun and doesn't waste your time with too much exposition, it thrusts you into the action right away. However, if you're looking for a multiplayer game, look elsewhere. While it isn't bad per se, it feels a bit generic, especially compared to the campaign.

Pros:
-Fast paced, challenging gameplay
-Feels like a modernized version of the classic (in a good way)
-Looks amazing, even on the lowest settings
-Tons of secrets
-Minimal cutscenes/story
-Good variety of weapons, both classic and new
-Great mix of exploration and combat
-Pacing feels almost perfect
-SnapMap works great, and there's already some pretty awesome fan-created levels

Cons:
-Multiplayer is mediocre and feels a bit generic
-SnapMap has some unnecessary limitations (such as only being able to carry 2 weapons)
-Regular deathmatch can only be done through SnapMap (which is limited to 4 players)
-The ending is kinda lame (not that it really matters)

reviewText:
I ordered the new DOOM off of cdkeys for 38 dollars, you should check them out, recieved my key yesterday.

So far, the Singleplayer campaign is fanominal. The map design, the effort put in to make each map vast and exciting, Hell, I spent a good hour trying to find secrets on E1M2. The story (so far) seems to be well enough put together, and I like that it isn't (really) the focus of the Campaign. Overall, the Singleplayer is what I mainly came for.

Now for the Multiplayer,

Suprisingly, the beta recieved many Negative reviews, but once DOOM was released today, It seems they made some improvements. A beta is a beta, its may or may not be the final product. I love the customization of weapons and armor. The demon powerup still seems overpowered to me, but its extremely fun to player as the Baron of Hell or the Mancubus, etc. I'm not really into the Hack modules, I don't use them. The six modes are very diverse, and are each fun in their own ways. If you were one who was disappointed by the beta, you should check out the multiplayer again. Overall, better multiplayer than expected.

Finally, DOOM SnapMap.

I haven't explored DOOM SnapMap much yet, but from I've experienced, and seen elsewhere, its very impressive. There are almost endless possibilities to make things, ranging from story maps to a functioning keyboard. I plan on making a map, just for the fun of it.

To sum it up,

Singleplayer - 9.5/10 Overall Amazing, but maybe a little short.
Multiplayer - 9/10 Much better than expected, but still lacking in balancing, etc.
SnapMap - 10/10 Fanominal maker with so many possibilities and a lot of customization
Graphics - 10/10 They really outdid themselves, most likely one of the prettiest games I've seen.
Balancing - 9/10 Great for the most part, Multiplayer needs work.
Truely DOOM - 9/10 closer to the original dooms than doom 3, but the multiplayer is more like halo than doom.

This is worthy of being a DOOM game, and I recommend you buy it (off cdkeys for 38 dollars).

reviewText:
This game is just gread overall and it accomplishes what it set out to do, reviving a true classic and introducing it to the current generation of games by boldly blending the old with the new with great success.
Doom is finally here!

The story isn't much to talk about, but hey, this is a reboot of a game that didn't rely on story at all, the single player campaign is more about running, jumping, finding secrets, getting bigger better guns, shooting and punching demons in the face while avoiding getting your own face smashed in, Just pure fun.

The gameplay is great, a smart well balanced mix between features seen in most modern first person shooters and the classic old school arena shooter type of play. Really fast paced action that requires you to always be on the move.

The graphics.
The game looks and performs great, but, i did notice that this iD Tech 6 engine shares some of the downsides of iD's previous engine (iD Tech 5), enviroment textures sometimes look really bland and in my opinion not on par with the rest of the game's graphical qualities, also, texture streaming issues while far less noticeable when compared to iD Tech 5 games, it still exists here. Those aside, the lighting and shadows are fantastic, gun and demon models are very detailed, decals and effects look great, but most importantly it performs really well, smooth at all times, probably the most optimized game to come out on PC this year, no bugs, no crashes, excellent performance even with all graphic options set to maximum. Great job iD Software.
(At the time of this review there was still no proper SLI support, iD has promised to fix this in the coming days)

The sound is great as well, just listen to those heavy metal riffs while you cut an Imp in half with your chainsaw!

That's it, now i have to go back to kill more demons and finish the campaign.

Buy this game and have fun!

reviewText:
DOOM is amazing.

DOOM is a game with a big legacy and it certainly does exceed my expectations by far.
True to its 1993 incarnation, the story is interesting but not forced down your throat. You can ignore it nearly completly, if you want.
The gunplay is very solid and a nice throwback to times when FPS-Games were more about crosshair-control than aming down sights.
The graphics are more than impressive, it looks beatiful while still having the same asthetics as the original. Every demon and monster is recognizable and even sometimes even more threatening.

The multiplayer part of the game is also pretty solid in my opinion. It isn't a Quake Live but it does it's job well in my opinion.

Last but no least is the Snapmap feature. Which is in my opinion a welcome addition to DOOM. It allows for creativity in the community, even people who are not that into modding can create.

Final Verdict: 666/10 Go to Hell! It will be a pleasant trip. ^^
