reviewText:
THE DOOM WE HAVE ALL WAITED FOR, THE SEASON PASS WE HAVE NOT

The single player campaign so far has honestly been the most refreshing immersive gameplay and the balance between plot and classic deathmatch style killing is perfect. Not only has this release featured throwback gameplay combat elements, it has completely out shown the recent trend of monotonous red screen duck and wait shooters that have become a fps genre norm.

Bringing back the classic health and armor pickups was genius, but I was not looking forward the the issues this classic system brought with limited item availability per level, the search this involved, and limitations it made. With this release ID has completely revamped the mechanic and has incorporated them into a driving force to live and push the player to take increasingly higher risks to succeed and excel in combat.

A problem with many classic run and gun shooters was in many ways the monotonous non stop action. There were rarely moments for the player to stop and be immersed in the story or environment. The constant push to continue moving the entire game caused in a large part a haze over the experience. Going through a level would often simply involve mashing keys and constantly clicking the mouse until the next loading screen. It even popularized buying a mouse with auto-fire button so you would not tire your finger and hardware.

With this release of doom it has not only brought back the positives of that classic gameplay but has remastered it in a way that brought a balance to combat, plot, unlockables, secrets, and character progression that is a evolution in a lot of ways doom 3 was with it's unique 2 way lighting engine that inspired a more reserved horror survival style incorporating the ability to choose between seeing the horror that befell UAC Mars and actually being able to combat it to survive.

I am 12 hours into DOOM and constantly remarking how impressed I have been so far and continue to be.

THIS IS THE DOOM WE HAVE ALL WAITED FOR.

Unfortunately, the season pass is not. At this point it is shown as only featuring content for online combative multiplayer and snap map features.

As a classic DOOM fan, I am not interested a COD online rehash or Halo reach style unlockable armor skin dress up features.

I am here for the campaign. The continuation of a world I have grown up with and continue to want to learn more about. The one that I am consistently learning more about every time I replay Doom 3 and re-live emails, audio logs, video training sessions, and immersive plot elements.

This recent release of DOOM brought back the classic gameplay I loved with the originals and paid respect to Doom 3 and continuation of the revolution in immersive content and gameplay.

The Season pass does not, but there is hope.

As doom 3 had a full game expansion, and wolfenstein the new order also has a full game expansion bad blood" I am hoping that if there is not going to be included either several small dlc levels
date: expanded single player content included campain levels or secrets

So often with new pc releases in the past couple years we have not only had sub par performance with console ports

ID delivered on it's promise to the doom community and brought a sequel we can stand by and continue to play for many years to come. They brought the PC gaming community a stable release including everything we need and continue to lack from most recent releases.

All I am asking for is the same I have been asking for many years now. I WANT MORE DOOM."

reviewText:
Single player? Absolutely spot on.  No, it's ♥♥♥♥ing PERFECT.  You'll be tearing the map inside out looking for those last damned secrets, the fights just get better and better the more enemy types they throw at you (and the more firepower you throw back) and the Nightmare difficulty is actually a challenge.  I'm frankly amazed that they translated the gameplay so well to a modern game, from essentially a 2D topology (and gameplay) to 3D as well.

Multiplayer? Meh.  Needs some more work.  The weapons are inherently unbalanced and the guns are not satisfying.  The speed is okay but feels slower than it actually is because too many of the wrong weapons are weak e.g. rocket launcher, and the game is very unhappily married with this horrendous two-weapon loadout system.  Why did they have to introduce THAT element, especially when the single player game does not, thank God?  Also the announcer sounds like he's a centuries-old wizard with just as much understanding of the game.  Bad, bad.  Tragic thing is the finishing-touch work to make multiplayer as evil and nosebleed-inducing as it ought to be is a couple of hours work, if that.  Except for new VA work, obviously.

Overall get it today for the satisfying single player, if you're a Doom fan.  Don't bother with multiplayer until it's actually worked on a bit more.  The multiplayer would probably be a bit more okay if the single player wasn't such a glorious masterpiece right alongside it, making the multiplayer look even more of an afterthought.

Snapmap is more of the same as multiplayer sadly, the tool itself is pretty darned cool but for all of its options it is limited by the imposed limits set to keep the framerate up on consoles and minimum spec PCs.  Come on guys... the best part of the game is the part you refused to advertise.

reviewText:
DOOM is back with a vengeance.

Pros:
-Insanely good Single-Player campaign
-Lots of guns that can all be held at the same time (BFG, Rocket launcher, Chainsaw, you name it)
-Almost every weapon has 2 upgrades that can be swapped in and out at any time
-Weapon upgrades and Suit upgrades let you enhance your combat abilities
-Tons of secret areas to find, all hiding armor, collectibles, mega-health, and you can even get certain weapons early on
-High speed combat
-Lots of verticality
-Large enemy variety all with different attacks and abilities
-You can rip a demon's arm off and then smash their head off with said arm
-Lots of hilarious player death animations for when you inevitably get taken down by the forces of Hell
-Good challenge, even on medium difficulty
-The level editor, SnapMap, is really easy to use and user friendly, but is incredibly powerful if used correctly
Cons:
-Multiplayer is kind of eh but it works
-Multiplayer and Snapmap are limited to 2-weapon systems :(
-No current announcement of singleplayer expansion pack(s) (Come on, we all want more!)
-No options for texture quality. Highest quality textures are loaded in reguardless of what settings you have.

I reccomend DOOM for any Single-player FPS fan who wants to rip and tear to their heart's content.

The campaign story is pretty good IMO, but it's all about the gameplay! Guns feel great, great feedback, enemies are dangerous and fun to play against and the game is super fast. Something that surprised me about the game is how vertical it gets: you can jump up on ledges and platforms to rain fire down on your enemies below, but be aware that your enemies will do the same to you!

Overal, great gameplay and feels like a real DOOM game! 8/10

PS: skip the multiplayer

Do you like to sight-see the hellish landscape known as mars? If you said yes any of these this is the game for you.

So go ahead, add DOOM to your cart, become a Space Marine and punish demons.

reviewText:
I have just finished Doom single-player campaign. It took me approximately 18 hours to complete on Hurt Me Plenty difficulty--I have explored a lot and tried to get as much secrets and upgrades as possible but I did not replayed any missions.

I enjoyed the campaign tramendously. This is certainly different experience as moder story-driven shooters I was playing lately. Gameplay was fast and action packed. Gory kills proven to be integral part of the gameplay as they allow you good sustainability. Chainsaw is another great element that allows you play strategicaly. The game also offers a lot of exploration and properly rewards you for it.

Visuals and audio are great. The game looks stunning and plays butter smooth without single hicup on my GTX970 at medium to high details. Audio was powerful, both weapons and music, and perfectly matched franctic action this game offers.

I have not tried Snap-map or Multiplayer so far. Singleplayer campaign was great and refreshing experience. I'm looking forward to compare this to Homefront: The Revolution -- undoubtly both games are very different but it will be interesting to see how these games compare and where is their main strength.

My rating for Doom is 9/10 (single-player campaign only, no MP rating).

reviewText:
Been here since the closed alpha and boy am I glad I did not miss out on any test session!

Bethesda really outdid themselfes again, this game will easily get in my top 3 games for 2016 and I think for many other peoples aswell.

As for Doom itself... I still got the original xbox version here next to me and this game doesn't disappoint. It is so fast paced, in all honesty, you can call this Doom 4 without ruining the franchise.

The game gives you acces to 3 game modes; campaign, multiplayer and snapmap.


Campaign:
This is actually a fun story! I've laughed several times to the bad puns and also to some glorious kill moments (yes I might be a bit sadistic...). Demons have invaded and it is your job to shoot every single one of them down.. or ya know, snap their necks and bash their heads in. The campaign consist out of several chapters, each covering their own unique levels with collectibles, free upgrades, enemies, goals and ofcourse some story progress. Compared to the Doom I had on the xbox the scary part got kinda removed (but hey I was a small kid back then so it might've been scary due the creatures), but it is so lovely to just massacre everything. You're an overpowered agile entity that gives no ♥♥♥♥s, last time I've played with such a character was with prototype (played it later than crysis).

But once again, god ♥♥♥♥ing damnit, I never expected campaign to be this amazing!!!! I mean it has been several years, how the hell can they pick up the doom feeling? Well they actually did and they improved it where it was needed and they squeezed out an amazing nuclear demonic baby with 2 other game modes. This stuff reader, if you purchase this make sure to have a holiday or so and no exams ahead or you'll be doomed.


Multiplayer:
Closed alpha; many flaws, much balancing to do; simple environment.
Closed beta; less flaws, 2 game modes, decently balanced, but bazooka fest, demons!
Open beta; minor bugs, 2 game modes, balanced; massacre.
Final product; no bugs, 6 game modes, more balanced than a 2 coloured pudding, fast paced killing spree.

After each session they took our feedback to the heart and implemented it. I've written long essays on their site for testers and I feel like it was read and used for a more balanced game. This leaves a customer like me with a good feeling. The improvements were noticeable and I absolutely can say that if things have to be improved, they will definitely do it with the given feedback!

Multiplayer now has 6 game modes. TDM, warpath, soul harvest, domination, freeze tag, clan arena.
TDM: basic team deathmatch with a goal of total kills to achieve.
Warpath: conquer the moving zone and keep defend it from enemies, or capture the one from the enemies. The zone gives points and you need an x amount of points to win/lose.
Soul Harvest: There is ALWAYS a demon, so no spawning rune, the first killer gets the demon rune as drop. Every kill drops 1 soul and you need to collect an x amount of enemy souls to win.
Domination: There are several non moving zones to capture now, each gives points over time and you need the most points to win.
Freeze tag: probably the funniest one, killing an enemy freezes the enemy. Freezing all enemy players results in victory. Standing next to a frozen ally will melt them. 3 ouf of 5 matches wins.
Clan arena: There is no such thing as clans in here, it is basically team deathmatch with only 1 life. 3 out of 5 matches wins.


Snapmap (level builder):
This tool will get me hooked for several days. I will start building maps after my final exam, or else I will be in trouble.... But! This tool is really nice, it kinda reminds me of trackmania canyon where you could build tracks. Here you allign several segments and you place some objects in them. Trust me the map builder is pretty advanced. From big ♥♥♥ mazes to tiny detailed spaces!


Optimizations:
A stable average of 125fps 1080p at the highest possible settings. My setup it a i7 4790k @ 4.8ghz, 32gb ddr3 ram @ 1866mhz, nvidia 980ti. Now not everyone can afford a high-end/enthousiast setup, but With this rig I've had several other AAA games running at the same preset achieving fps of less than 80. So lowering down the settings would allow you to play on a potato. The graphics are absolutely amazing though, even at low quality. Push your system if you can, it is worth it. But yeah this game is optimized and I can say for sure it runs great on any system. However make sure to have your drivers up to date, that goes for both amd and nvidia, otherwise you might experience some lag and stutter in during the cutscenes..

reviewText: This game runs on an engine that is a joy to experience. Optimized for speed, an expression of love for the pc gamer with keyboard in one hand and mouse in the other.  With much attention to detail on how the world looks when you move your mouse, or strafe, or pull that trigger.  I hadn't experienced such a glass smooth response engine since the days of quake.  We've become accustomed to inferior games with their instant hit mechanics, de-emphasized movement of projectiles in space, dumbed down 'trust me you hit something' hit markers.  Doom brings back something we've been missing and raises a bloody middle finger to all recent first person shooters that came before it.   Aim matters, weapon switching matters, distance matters, and you the player have become an artist.  At your disposal is an arsenal of destructive weapons.  It's up to you to paint that canvas with blood.  Doom is a jolting realization of what we've been missing out on.  Other games have taken shortcuts and denied us a pure visceral experience that our computers,  our internet connections, and our skills were capable of all along.  To hell with hide and cover mechanics, it's time again to kick some ♥♥♥.   I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
My first game i ever played was Doom, on my mom's old 486 pc. I learned Dos just to get in and play when she wasnt there.
I played it, finished it, and replayed it continuously, no need to say this was my favorite game for some time. I mean i still know the old cheat codes by heart.

When i saw this remake, i was scared i admit.... scared of all the COD, BF in your face scripted story, with michael bay effects they keep shoving down our throats for the past couple of years. Like i said i remember the cheat codes but playing this actually reminded me how good the gameplay felt.

Its quick paced, the enemies come from every angle, combining punching, shooting, jumping, throwing nades all at the same time, not even blinking until your eyes bleed. The soundtrack is killer, killing demons with this type of music is simply eargasmic. The graphics are gorgeous, the game runs great (STEADY 60FPS on ultra). I wont rate the multiplayer part because i really dont give a f about multiplayer here. Everything works well and his exactly what i could of hoped after all these years.

Other game companies should take note, this is fully functionnal on day 1, it has a steady engine, it is fully optimized and brings exactly what it sells on store page.

This is a breath of fresh air, a sign of hope for gamers.

ID i salute you.

reviewText:
DOOM is a surprise hit for a lot of people and one that I've been following and anticipating for a while. The singleplayer campaign is one of the best I've played in many years. It's a strong throwback to the old doom games, from the keycards to the fast paced action, to the secrets, this game deserves the name DOOM. The weapons feel beefy and powerful, the enemies explode into fountains of blood and gore, and the sound design to go with it is top notch. The level design is what really shines, always giving you plenty of chance to explore and find secrets and always leading you along without playing the game for you and telling you exactly what to do (ala CoD). The singleplayer for DOOM is a breath of fresh air in today's gaming climate.

The multiplayer isn't quite as strong. It's still good and has plenty of game modes, customization and progression to keep people busy. It isn't for everyone but it's still quite a bit of fun if you like arena shooters. I should mention that the game uses a loadout system instead of weapon pickups (power weapons are still pickups).

Snapmap is a useful tool that people can use to make custom singleplayer and multiplayer levels. It's easy to use and powerful enough to make some fun, decently complex levels but not the same as having actual mod tools.

My only major gripe with DOOM is the lack of actual mod support and mod tools. It seems they made snapmap to fill that void but it's really not the same thing and especially with it being a DOOM game, that just doesn't feel right. Overall though DOOM is a fantastic entry into the series that surprised a lot of people by being unarguably one of the best games of the year.

reviewText:
I was more than likely one of those who actually bought the collectors edition from the store.

I never really got into Doom 3 but since installing and playing Doom I have been more than happy, especially with it's single player context of the game. I have always found fast paced fps multiplayer games, ever since Quake world to a bit of a minefield for knowing if a game is good or not. You can never trully say a game is good or bad just by playing multiplayer.

I urge for anyone thinking of getting this game to ask yourself, are you a single player or multiplayer person? SP is defintiely me and because of that, this is why I believe this game has done an awesome job.

With all my settings set to Ultra (There is one more step known as Nightmare but you need a 5GB GFX card to support it) it runs butter smooth at constant 60fps. I see no screen tearing, no lag, no nothing. The AI of hellspawn and depending on which difficulty you choose is on par, they all have their own way of coming for you.

As you play through the game there is so much to do for a SP FPS, but it does not hinder the game as most FPS's that try to add side projects to it. The upgrades for weapons, armour, runes etc are very well done and the mini games mixed in to get the runes just add to the flavour.

There is a very well put together overview of the environments, artifacts, weapons, monsters etc. that really give you the feel that you are part of something in that world and you are learning of why, what, where, who, when and how.

I am yet to play with Snapmap, but from what I've seen in terms of how it works, people out there who are not the best at creating extra content for a game can find it very easy and there is so much that can add in via the community. Definitely giving it a lot more playability rather than just straight up SP or Multi.

Overally if I was to rate this out of 10, it would definitely be a 9. The only reason it wouldn't be 10 is because it is missing the most memorable part of any old school game that is current, CO OP.

reviewText:
I only just about recommended this game because the gameplay is fun. It is Doom, there is lots of demon slaying and plenty of guns to slay said demons with. But after finishing the game in 13 hours, and because of how it ended, I am beginning to wonder if the game manufacturers aren't attempting a bit of a cash grab.

The game is pretty linear. Get from A to B while killing everything inbetween that is not you. There is a villian whom you're trying to catch and you also get to uncover pieces of the story as you go along. The story is pretty much a side to the main dish: shooting stuff. And here it is fun. If you stand still, you're going to have a bad time. There are some areas where it is difficult to move around and it can be frustrating trying to do the thing they want you to do but in little space to do it in. However, on the whole, strafing, jumping and shooting your way through an area is lots of fun.

The bad parts though? The game is repetitive to the point that is predictable. You walk into a round/oval shaped room with lots of ammo, armour and health which means a fight is about to go down. It is not scary at all - Doom 3 was a lot scarier - and you'll find yourself wandering from area to area barely taking anything in. Every now and then you'll come across a log or hologram explaining some of the demented stuff they did to summon demons, but again it's thrown in more as justification for doing what you do. They could have expanded on the story a whole lot more because it's easy to feel like you're just running around and shooting stuff for the sake of running around and shooting stuff.

Many of the reviews I've read praise it for getting back to its roots or being the real Doom, but they could have done more than just sprinkle a story inbetween shooting stuff, climbing on stuff and melee attacking stuff. The Glory Kills (melee finishers) are not a bad idea, but they are really just soft quick time events. Shoot the demon until it flashes then hit the melee button to finish it off. You're then rewarded with health, ammo and armour, which sprinkles about like a pinyata has blown it's load.

The developers have a good game on their hands, but it seems like it's missing some stuff. For example, there are like only 2 NPCs you interact with throughout the game. It's pretty much demon shooting all the way. The game looks nice but the levels are pretty much the same: walk down a corridor towards a room or area where you're going to shoot stuff then proceed to the next level.

Here are some pros and cons:

Pros:
- Shooting hordes of demons and fighting demon bosses is fun
- Power-ups help you lay the smack down that much harder on demons
- You can upgrade your weapons, armour and equipment. You can increase your maximum health, armour and ammo capacities, which is a nice touch.
- You're constantly moving when fighting, so it forces you to think about what the best weapons are for the environment, as well as for the specific demons you're facing.
- Melee finishers come in handy, especially when ammo and health start running low.
- The game is rather forgiving when you do, allowing you to just reload from the last checkpoint, which is usually not far from when you entered an area.

Cons:
- Combat is repetitive, especially during boss fights. I remember finding myself just circle strafing and shooting many times because it worked rather well.
- Not much of a story, which is a shame because Doom 3's PDA system made the game more immersive.
- Level design tends to be similar when entering areas where you're going to fight some demons.
- The ending is a bit of a let down. They're probably looking to profit from DLC later.
- The game feels" fast-paced only because demons are quick and you're constantly trying to avoid projectiles. Your character
recommended: can feel slow because he is set to one speed.\n\nI'd give the game a 7/10 because it is fun
hoursPlayed: but it hasn't got much in the way of substance."

reviewText:
I'll update this as I continue through the game, but here are my initial thoughts:

This game instantly feels more like DOOM than any game since 1996. Combat is extremely fast-paced, and by the second mission, even on the normal difficulty, you're circle-strafing around the room just trying to stay alive while you pick off anything you can. It feels like the most intense Ultra-Violent maps from the original games, with movement speed turned up beyond Nightmare! levels.

One of the major strengths of the originals' design was the weapon balance, in that every weapon was a tool for a specific job. That has returned in an even more pronounced way with the new DOOM. It's clear the developers understand, gameplay-wise, what made the originals so good. From what I can tell, they've captured and refined those qualities here.

UPDATE:

My initial review was written while I had something like ~7 hours in the game. At the time of this update, I've played about 40 hours, the vast majority of tha being the singleplayer campaign and maybe ~10% of it in team deathmatch.

I've completed the singleplayer campaign from scratch twice now, once on Ultra-Violence and once on Nightmare.

I'll elaborate on what I've already written. DOOM (2016) gets everything right that the first game did, and in fact, does it better. Aesthetics aside, what made the first game so cool was its gameplay elements consisting of harmonization between the weapon balance, player movement, and enemy types and what they brought to the table for you to work with.

The first game had enemies that caused you to use certain weapons depending on your position in relation to theirs, as well as affecting your movement. Dodge projectiles by strafing, evade the demon by backpeddling, keep enemy positions in check by charging forward. Take cover against hitscan weapon enemies. This game features all of this and more. Well, actually I guess not hitscan enemies, but I digress.

Player movement is extremely fast, lack of bunnyhopping notwithstanding, and movement is absolutely essential to success. This is the only game I've ever played that kind of felt like the original DOOM's movement. The inertia isn't quite there, nor is wallrunning, but it feels right, and it feels good.

Combat is very hard until you have enough experience to understand what to upgrade and how to leverage your strengths. I recommend starting on Ultra-Violence and moving up. It will challenge you hard, and it's fun every second of the way.

The soundtrack is brutal and intense. The compression on the drums, especially, makes for some psychotic slams and it fits the combat very well. There are hints of old DOOM songs in there, too, so veterans that listen closely might be able to pick them out. Off the top of my head, I can think of four references that are present in varying degrees of completeness.

Commentary on game systems and multiplayer might be coming in the future with another update.

Bottom line is this: I've only fallen harder for this game after spending ~30 more hours playing since the initial write-up. I still highly recommend this. I believe this is probably the best singleplayer shooter ever created.

UPDATE 2: Multiplayer

I've spent the last three days or so playing a lot of team deathmatch. I've managed to level up to Echelon 3 rank 20-something (that means level to 50, then level to 50 again, and again, and then 20-something more levels) (updated: I've since leveled to echelon 6 and I might get to 8 before I sleep tonight). Somewhere between 15-20 hours of play I think (now over 30).

DOOM TDM is the best Halo game ever for PC. Why do I (and others) compare the game to Halo? There is an unmistakable influence found in everything from the announcer's tone, to the game design, down to the player models and maps. Everything in the MP game's design has been touched by the influence of Halo. Let me elaborate before rambling on random multiplayer thoughts.

Let's start by pointing out that it just doesn't feel like id deathmatch. Two-weapon loadouts. Power weapons. There are only team modes. No duel modes. Only huge, extremely complex maps. The weapon set has been expanded with several new items that specifically feel very Halo. There's not only one sniper weapon (the vortex rifle). There are like three. That's very Halo. There's even one called the BR that shoots in bursts of three, which ought to remind any Halo veteran of a certain infamous weapon from the past. While there are (thankfully) no vehicles, there are demon powerups, which are a kind of analog to Halo's vehicles. The person controlling the demon can absolutely dominate unless the opposing team coordinates a focused attack. Nevertheless, the inclusion of explicit demons from the campaign (baron, revenant, mancubus) is one of the only distinctly DOOM things in the multiplayer. Hell, they can't even bring themselves to use the word frags
date: something found in every id Software deathmatch game since the original DOOM. Until now. Now, they're just kills
recommended:
just like Halo.

Is this a bad thing? It's not bad, per se. It's very fun. But I have to warn you, if you're looking for the next installment of classic id Software multiplayer, this is not it. But again, it's very fun and addictive. So whatever issues I raise from here on out, keep that in mind. And keep in mind that I'm nowhere near done playing it; I plan to level to Echelon 10 level 50 (the current cap). It should probably take 1.5-2 weeks if I play every day. So look, it's cool. Now onto some commentary about mechanics.

This is where my thoughts get weird. This is a video game, so does anything matter other than the fun factor? The game's MP is fun. But I have to say, it's like the junk food of game design. What I mean is, it's a team-based shooter (no duel mode in sight), just like Halo. But the rewards systems are all about your individual performance. It hardly matters if your team wins. Hell, it doesn't really matter that much if you die a lot, provided you get roughly as many kills as deaths. You get bonuses on top of bonuses when you kill with the absurdly overpowered power weapons

reviewText:
Welcome to DOOM, a lightning-fast virtual reality adventure where you are the toughest space trooper ever to suck vacuum.

When I first read those words many years ago, I knew this game was going to be something different. That's the intro to the original Doom manual circa 1993. And over two decades since those words were first printed, the legacy is still going strong.

DOOM (2016) is everything that I expect from a Doom game. Big guns, much bigger demons, and one lone tough-as-nails Marine using the first to obliterate the second. Rest assured that this is an epic and action-packed assault through Mars, and hell, and back to Mars, and back to hell. (Repeated many times over a 15 hour campaign, twice as long as most FPS these days.) DOOM is a fantastic return to a time when games were about fun gameplay, story was something you had to dig for (instead of being spoon fed to you), bosses were challenging, and protagonists knew when to shut the hell up instead of yapping through the whole campaign.

While most shooters today encourage you to move cautiously, keep a finger on the reload key, and kill maybe a dozen or so enemies in a mission, DOOM takes things a different route. In DOOM, speed and aggression is the only way to get things done. If you back down from a fight, if you try to camp your enemies, if you try to hide in cover, you will lose. Over and over again. Play offensively, and always be on the move. This applies equally to campaign and multiplayer.

In DOOM, you will be moving 99% of the time. To help keep you from having to stop, DOOM does away with sprint-keys and weapon reloading. Instead, your weapons never need to be reloaded. So long as you have ammo in your inventory, you can fire your weapons. Rather than a sprint-key, your default speed is running and you can hit a key if you (for some reason) wish to walk. Movement overall is much less restrictive than in most shooters. By jumping towards any ledge, you can grapple on and quickly pull yourself up. You can also rapidly climb railings and vault over low obstacles. These mechanics are very fluent and far more versatile than they seem on the surface. While some games have mechanics like this that feel gimmicky, in DOOM they feel natural and work exceptionally well. In addition to this, fairly early in the campaign you will acquire a set of boots that let you double-jump (double-jumping is standard in the multiplayer). This combined with the ledge-climbing enables you to reach new heights.

But you aren't the only creature that can traverse the world with ease, nearly all of the thousands (literally thousands) of demons you will fight are just as agile as you. They can, and will, chase you all throughout the combat zone with surprising intelligence. Killing these demons is frantic, hellish, and very satisfying. The ability to melee weakened enemies for a quick finishing move (called glory kill") is a welcome feature in DOOM. These glory kills might sound clunky and repetitive

reviewText:
I remember I ran a BBS back in the late 80's, early 90's.  I was a PC enthusiast and always was jealous that consoles had such really cool games -while the PC had some good ones, most were adventure style games like King's Quest or Ultima - great games of the day, but the PC was lacking high end action ga,es.   My BBS was the only local Apogee distribution site, and I remember when my modem spent hours downloading a game called Commander Keen at 2am from the distribution hub.   I woke up as the modem initiated its handshaking sequence.  And thought, what a stupid name for a game.

Then I played it.   Things changed on the PC from that day forward.   Thanks to the developers at id Software, the PC was no longer relegated to backwater gaming.  The consoles had direct competition - and the PC could be on the same footing.   Then Wolfenstein 3D came.  While not the first FPS game - it certainly took PC gaming to new heights.  Then came Doom - a game that forced many to upgrade from 286 or 386 to 486 machines - and that started the trend of PC Gaming driving new computer sales.   It was that important of  a game.  Many forayed into Networking, or Modding - a game that drove people to the IT industry.   Myself included.

Ok, sorry for the mind numbing nostalgia - but I'm sure a lot of people who grew up in that golden age of PC gaming get the same feeling playing the latest Carmack and company installment.  A feeling most didn't get with Doom 3.   But here is a game with an engine a cut above what's out there (as we should expect from id), and displaying what made early FPS so popular in the first place --- fast pace action, twitch reflexes, not a lot of thought above wow

reviewText:
Finally a Doom game capable of being both modern and true to form. This game brought back what was sorely lacking in Doom 3: Exploration, fast pace and butchering demons by the dozen. Gone are the cheap jumpscares that Doom 3 brought us at every corner, you're not some ♥♥♥♥♥ marine shooting at spiders or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ his pants in front of a Cyberdemon, you're the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Doom Marine and you kick major ♥♥♥ all the way.

Remember when someone at ID said the point was to feel like Bruce Lee roaming around on a skateboard with a shotgun? The pacing reflects exactly that, there's a sort of rythm to the game: Shoot, run in, Glory Kill their asses then do the same with the other fools snarling and throwing fireballs at you. This new Doom is all about movement, to stay still is to get killed. The Marine can easily climb ledges and jump around, especially once you get the Thrust Boots and the well-designed levels let you moce easily during arena combat. All in all, combat in this game is Brutal Doom in the ID Tech engine, very satisfying. The Glory Kills are quick enough to not break the pace and they are indeed very brutal and gory. So satisfying.

One of my biggest disappointment with the closed alpha was the impossibility of carrying all the weapons, the loadout system felt unnecessary since just about everybody spammed rockets during the game and it just feels like it was implemented to be more modern" ... but in the single-player campaing? You can carry all you find and there's a great slection including classic weapons from the earlier Doom games as well as some newcomers

reviewText:
First off. I had a doom shareware cd, I bought doom2 and quake new. So I'm old.

I've very very much enjoyed (new) Doom so far. It reminds me of the best parts of doom, but unrestrained by technology with a sprinkling of q3arena. Getting suddenly mobbed and blasting until it stops hurting is what doom 1&2 were about, and this offers that, the rate then seemed really fast (remember, doom gave birth to the FOS genre), now? It IS fast.

It also includes loot/leveling aspects that compliment rather than complicate the game. Do I need to shotgun blast 30 imps in the face? No, but I'll do it for the fun, and to get the weapon enhancement.

Which brings me to another interesting point. Many(but not all) characters are readily recognizable from doom I/II, but.. better. Which I really enjoyed.

The bad:
It ate my HD6870. The framerate hovered around 24 with passable, but not good graphics, the rendering engine really isn't meant to cater to older hardware. The game's combat engine copes well with lowered framerate, combat slows universally so you don't just get gibbed, but as you'd expect, it damages the pace. Some views were untenable, dropping to 10 or less FPS.

Had to overnight a new card from Amazon, which is pretty typical when a new id game comes out(The purchase, not the overnighting. id has driven much of my PC upgrade process).
With the new card I'm getting 100fps consistently and the old school doom 'feel' is0 100%.

Edit: It does not appear to require much CPU power, even with the 6870 it was only using around 20% cpu in a second gen i7.

reviewText:
Despite being bored with the MP Beta before release, the SP campaign for this game is fantastic.  After 12 years, this game was worth the wait.  Gone are the slow-moving, dark shadows of Doom 3: Where that game was a horror game with action elements, this is the complete opposite - This take on Doom is brutal, bloody, brightly-colored, and otherwise a chaotic gore-fest deluxe.

The Good:
1.  Awesome graphics - blood runs out of the walls, clouds of smoke rise from destructed building on the horizon, great glass and DOF effects, etc.
2.  Action, action, action, and more action - the game never stops moving.
3.  Glory Kills to finish off opponents in completely blood-drenched fashion
4.  All the classic Doom weapns make an appearance, are fully upgradable, and there are even a couple new ones
5.  The Demons have all been revamped, and are more aggressive and deadly.   Imps now climb walls and hurl fireballs at you from all sort of angles.  Hell Knights will jump up to ledges to pursue you, etc.  And there is no shortage of any of them.
6.  Secrets galore and areas to explore
7.  Minor RPG upgrading elements on gameplay and the marine's suit
8.  Double jumps and climbing allows for more expanded environments and movement
9.  Demons react when being damaged - they will stumble or step backward from machine gun fire, etc instead of just charging forward like a robot
10.  Smooth as silk on Ultra settings (GTX 980, i5 OC to 4.3 GHZ).

The Bad:
1.  Checkpoints....need I say more?
2.  The maps are somtimes confusing and it's difficult to figure out where you are at a lot of the time
3.  The music, while fitting to the game, is sometimes a little repetitive
4.  One type of Demon is missing from the game, but was replaced with another similar one - diehards might not like this.

The Ugly:
1.  For those who suffer from motion sickness, repeated Glory Kills will catch up to you.

In the same ways that the original Doom had minor aspects of Wolfentstein in it, this version reminds me of the more recent Wolfenstein games and has minor similarities to those also.

I couldn't put it down, I never lost interest, and it never got boring.

All in all, it's a killer game.
666/10
A+

reviewText:
DOOM is a surprise hit for a lot of people and one that I've been following and anticipating for a while. The singleplayer campaign is one of the best I've played in many years. It's a strong throwback to the old doom games, from the keycards to the fast paced action, to the secrets, this game deserves the name DOOM. The weapons feel beefy and powerful, the enemies explode into fountains of blood and gore, and the sound design to go with it is top notch. The level design is what really shines, always giving you plenty of chance to explore and find secrets and always leading you along without playing the game for you and telling you exactly what to do (ala CoD). The singleplayer for DOOM is a breath of fresh air in today's gaming climate.

The multiplayer isn't quite as strong. It's still good and has plenty of game modes, customization and progression to keep people busy. It isn't for everyone but it's still quite a bit of fun if you like arena shooters. I should mention that the game uses a loadout system instead of weapon pickups (power weapons are still pickups).

Snapmap is a useful tool that people can use to make custom singleplayer and multiplayer levels. It's easy to use and powerful enough to make some fun, decently complex levels but not the same as having actual mod tools.

My only major gripe with DOOM is the lack of actual mod support and mod tools. It seems they made snapmap to fill that void but it's really not the same thing and especially with it being a DOOM game, that just doesn't feel right. Overall though DOOM is a fantastic entry into the series that surprised a lot of people by being unarguably one of the best games of the year.

reviewText:
Honestly I didn't think much of this game at first, but I was not playing it on Nightmare difficulty.  Pro tip for playing this game: Play it on Nightmare otherwise it does not feel like DOOM.  Even with just 10 hours in I am enjoying this game greatly on the higher diffculty because it is absolutely the return of the classic DOOM, but this time you're able to move your head in all directions and your enemies like to jump on your head... to smash it.

If you're looking for a compelling story with compelling characters then keep looking because that is not DOOM.  There is some story but the main emphasis is on guts, gore, and fighting like hell.  Additionally do not pick this game up for Multiplayer, just don't.  DOOM has always been first and foremost a singleplayer game and it exceeds in that area significantly.  Finally the SnapMap is definitely worth checking out and will certainly add replayability to this game.  SnapMap missions even offer coop style gameplay so you rain body parts down with your friends!  Hooray!

Overall DOOM successfully fills the shoes of its classic predecessor's when it comes to singleplayer.  Multiplayer is weak, but you're not playing DOOM for Multiplayer.  The SnapMap will provides hours of entertainment for those who enjoy building content and those who enjoy playing user created content.

I'd like to preface this by saying that I have played Doom and other classic shooters for thousands of hours and for so many years I don't care to think about it, I've wasted more of my life on classic shooters than anything else. This game was bought for me by a friend and I played it on their insistence as I was skeptical ID without any of the original team would pull this off especially while under the wing of Bethesda who loves to dumb down their games. I had no intention of ever buying this but I've ended up glad that I was pushed into playing it as I have genuinely been surprised and I do recommend purchasing this.

Unlike most positive reviews I've seen on Steam I'm not going to say it's perfect or the best shooter I've ever played but it does hold up well and is just a lot of stupid fun and I do recommend this game to any fan of the oldschool shooters. It is fast, it is fun and it is violent with the late game especially feeling like I'm playing with that same great map design that the 90s and early 2000s was all about. The weapons feel punchy and have a role that they excel at and weaknesses that will require you swapping weapons quickly and thinking about your choices. The AI Actively hunts you down and comes from all sides, you can't just hug cover you have to move around both to stay alive and to keep grabbing pickups in the arenas they set up for the fights. The movement speed is fast, maybe not as fast as the old Doom games or Quake but it is a good pace and jumping and grabbing onto ledges doesn't slow you down, the glory kills don't slow down the pace of the game too much either I never felt like I was going slow while playing which is a good thing. The weapon unlocks are varied and I like the system of being able to change them around to suit both your playstyle or the situation at hand,l the armour unlock system could use a bit of work though because the majority of the unlocks border on useless. Exploration is encouraged although the majority of the secrets are a bit of a joke once you realize they show up on the automap, there are however some very cleverly hid secrets that only the most thorough players will find, or you're using a guide.

One of the biggest critiques I have for this game is that it can be a bit predictable, especially the early game and even the late game just throwing you into wide open arenas kind of like small multiplayer maps where it just sends wave after wave of enemy at you until you kill them all. You then move on through a series corridors into the next big arena that they have set up for you. It would have been nice for this to have been mixed up a bit with some more traditional exploration styled areas to go through between these arenas, there are a few cases of this but not nearly enough in my opinion. The monster count also seems very on the low side a lot of the time, even in the endgame you rarely see more than ten or so enemies to face off with at any one time with more enemies being spawned in as you've killed a few off, I imagine this is due to the limitations on console hardware but I would really love to see the monster count kicked up a notch. The boss fights are a complete and utter joke to beat on the Ultra Violence difficulty the cyberdemon especially was a huge let down even though there was a huge build up leading up to the fight.

Snap Map is just horrible, extremely limited and has a huge case of 'made for consoles' that makes the UI insufferably confusing to use on a PC. Give us a map editor or at the very least increase the spawn limits.

The Multiplayer is completely terrible and should be avoided, it doesn't even have anti-cheat which is a huge joke. I'm not surprised it was made by ex-Bungie developers because it just feels like fast Halo with worse weapon balance.

The lack of proper mapping and mod tools is a serious mark against this game too, while ID Tech 6 might be hugely complicated even just a proper map editor and not this joke of a substitute Snap Map will make this game go a lot further.

In conclusion it's pretty gr8 m8 I'd r8 it 8.8/8 no

reviewText:
Despite being bored with the MP Beta before release, the SP campaign for this game is fantastic.  After 12 years, this game was worth the wait.  Gone are the slow-moving, dark shadows of Doom 3: Where that game was a horror game with action elements, this is the complete opposite - This take on Doom is brutal, bloody, brightly-colored, and otherwise a chaotic gore-fest deluxe.

The Good:
1.  Awesome graphics - blood runs out of the walls, clouds of smoke rise from destructed building on the horizon, great glass and DOF effects, etc.
2.  Action, action, action, and more action - the game never stops moving.
3.  Glory Kills to finish off opponents in completely blood-drenched fashion
4.  All the classic Doom weapns make an appearance, are fully upgradable, and there are even a couple new ones
5.  The Demons have all been revamped, and are more aggressive and deadly.   Imps now climb walls and hurl fireballs at you from all sort of angles.  Hell Knights will jump up to ledges to pursue you, etc.  And there is no shortage of any of them.
6.  Secrets galore and areas to explore
7.  Minor RPG upgrading elements on gameplay and the marine's suit
8.  Double jumps and climbing allows for more expanded environments and movement
9.  Demons react when being damaged - they will stumble or step backward from machine gun fire, etc instead of just charging forward like a robot
10.  Smooth as silk on Ultra settings (GTX 980, i5 OC to 4.3 GHZ).

The Bad:
1.  Checkpoints....need I say more?
2.  The maps are somtimes confusing and it's difficult to figure out where you are at a lot of the time
3.  The music, while fitting to the game, is sometimes a little repetitive
4.  One type of Demon is missing from the game, but was replaced with another similar one - diehards might not like this.

The Ugly:
1.  For those who suffer from motion sickness, repeated Glory Kills will catch up to you.

In the same ways that the original Doom had minor aspects of Wolfentstein in it, this version reminds me of the more recent Wolfenstein games and has minor similarities to those also.

I couldn't put it down, I never lost interest, and it never got boring.

All in all, it's a killer game.
666/10

reviewText:
Alright. Doom.This is a spoiler-free, rather detailed DOOM review that should give you a basic idea of what this game offers.

Let's start right at the beginning.
My beginning is the DOOM Beta. We've all seen it.
Not being developed by id Software themselves, it was bound to be different than what we expected.
A popularized Doom-Quake. A modern day shooter, if you will.
Skins. Taunts. A pre-order-only multiplayer equipment pack.
A lot of people got worried: Was DOOM going to be modernized to please the average crowd instead of the old fans?
Was it going to lose everything that makes DOOM, well, DOOM?
No. No, it didn't. Not in the slightest.

In DOOM you control a very p!ssed-off guy who doesn't give two sh!ts about anything.
As him, you slaughter thousands of demons in the most satisfying ways possible, faster and with more flow than ever before.
Your arsenal consists of upgradeable, moddable badass weaponry, all useful in their own ways. A new system of Glory Kills" was introduced - gore-filled finishing moves that let you preserve ammunition
date: get rewards depending on your enabled in-game perks and get some sweet fist-to-face combat going (You can also turn them off if you find to dislike them; Perks are received by completing side-challenges
recommended: you don't have to use them).\nThe level design is a very well executed mix of arena-like battling grounds and every level has a great vertical aspect. With that neat package of extremely blood-thirsty gameplay come astonishing graphics and a surprisingly stable framerate on the suggested hardware.

reviewText:
Doom 3 was a good game. It was just really friggin' dark and a crappy Doom game. What I mean by that is the original Doom is very rarely about not being able to see, and jump scares. Rather, it's about intense action, strafing wildly, wielding heaps of cool weapons, and not taking it too seriously while having fun. Doom 3 has some of these elements, but tries much too hard to be mature and gritty in the wrong ways.

This 2016 version of Doom is Doom done right. It's a reboot that I expected to be garbage, but ended up having a lot of fun with. Each weapon has a job, each enemy is dealt with a different way, fast melee finishers which I didn't think I'd like surprised me and added a fun new element to the game, and although it feels weird at first, the further I got into the game, the more this felt like the original Doom games. It's a fun reimagining of the original with a story that you can pay as much or as little attention to as you like, with delays for exposition being very rare. The enemies are very detailed and redesigned, but some of them, such as the cacodemon, revenant, pinky, etc., while looking so new, also have that nostalgic look to them as well when you take in their overall shape, purpose, and aesthetic.

However, it's not just Doom with a shiny new coat of paint and melee finishers. Almost every weapon has upgrades, as does your Doom Marine suit. You are awarded upgrade points for finding various collectibles, killing large numbers of enemies, and completing challenges (such as kill X number of imps from behind in melee, etc.) on each level. Completing these challenges, finding the secrets, and upgrading your guns and suit are practically a mini-game in and of themselves, because I spent a rather large number of hours combing through levels looking for goodies. It's definitely worth it, though, because having better guns and such make clearing later areas much easier and give you more options.

That said, if you aren't the kind of gamer who has a lot of spare time, you may not want to spend a terribly large amount of time looking for the secrets. Although there's a really rewarding feeling about finding some of the tougher secrets on your own, Youtubing to find secrets you're missing isn't a bad idea if you really do need to cut back on how much time you're spending playing, and videos of that are already available from several users on the aforementioned site.

If you like games you can get all the achievements in, this one's doable but not super easy. I have 100% achievements now, and most of them are for finding all the secrets and upgrading everything. I got the competitive multiplayer achievements in under an hour easily, despite me being terrible at it, and the Snap Map achievements can be obtained within an hour or two depending on how much attention you pay to Snap Map's tutorials and playing legitimate maps to entertain or simply trying to finish maps fast to get achievements.

The competitive multiplayer seemed alright, but I'm hardly the person to ask. It's just not really my jam. The mode I played was a lot like Transformers War for Cybertron's mode where you try to hold command points,except I could turn into a jet on a whim whenever I felt like it in Transformers, so for me, Transformers all the way. ;)

Snap Map is surprisingly robust. Basically, you have an overhead view of an x-ray" of a room

reviewText:
*Updated after completing the game*

In many ways I think the release of this game mirrors the release of the original Doom in 1993. A game where you move fast, mow down demons, and don't look back. Something which at the time was brand new and nowadays is a breath of fresh air from the sea of generic military and slow paced shooters that have overtaken the genre. In addition the performance of the game is equally as impressive as it was back then, achieving incredible fidelity and smootheness on low powered hardware. This game is the perfect reboot, capturing the soul of the original games while improving on it for a modern audience.

I really have to rant about the performance here, it's so good it doesn't fully make sense to me. I'm running the game on a 980ti at 2560x1440 resolution, everything cranked up as high as it can go. My average framerate is in the 80-90 range, regularly jumping up into the 110-120 range during less intensive areas. The absolute lowest framerate I ever got was 58, and only in 2 isolated areas throughout the entire game. Id clearly knows something that other developers don't, considering that most other games would struggle to reach 60 with similar settings, let alone 90 or 120.

But you have a high-end rig!" I hear you say. Consider this: The game runs at full 1080p and 60fps ON BOTH CONSOLES. If an Xbox One can run a game that looks this good at 1080p/60

reviewText:
Guess it says a lot about me if I don't feel an ounce of sympathy for the demons DoomGuy brutally murders, yet feel absolutely horrible for those robots he punches in the face after they give him gun upgrades :(

For those of you who are kind of pulled one way and the other because of the reviews of the multiplayer beta: don't be alarmed. The campaign is definitely everything you asked for: the speed (definitely fast on 120 pov), the guns, the demons. All checked off, plus a few bonuses:

-The environments are GORGEOUS, even with medium settings (yes, my rig is modest).
-Secrets that get you looking all over the damn map, and are fun to look for
-The difficulty of Ultra-Violence (almost) matches Doom II's difficulty on the same level; safe to say, you will die a lot.

I do have nitpicks, of course. The upgrade system is definitely a bit cumbersome; I want cool guns, but having to pull off tricks to get their upgrades feels bleh. No, game, I really don't want to pull off 4 sweep-the-leg Glory Kills on ONE specific demon. Glory Kills in general, I'm very neutral about. The rune trials are weird and out of place, and I do feel a bit bleh about replaying one map twice (the second time, it's destroyed, which is dumb).

Still. They are nitpicks of a colossal, fast, brutal game that I can easily see myself sinking in ungodly amounts of time. I have yet to sink my teeth into Snapmap and Multiplayer outside of beta, but if it's the campaign you're here for, pick this one up. It's a worthy successor to the grandaddy of fps.

reviewText:
Play time: 20 hours: Single player campaign: +- 19 hours.
Should take far less time if you just run and don't take in the views. :)

So I just completed Doom's single player campaign after a 19 hour trip through hell that was like heaven. I played doom as a very young kid, then I played Doom 2 and I also loved playing the custom maps! Unlike most people I really enjoyed Doom 3 as well. Although it wasn't like Doom 1 or 2, it experimented with so much and geniunely frightened me with it's well designed monsters and frightening atmosphere! It also had DoomEd
and I spent countless hours making maps of my own. Now, on to Doom 4.

Holy mother of barons, what a game! The format is very simple, get into a simple area, and move! Run, use pickups, get health, destroy those demons, tear them apart, run, get powerups, eviscerate more demons, repeat! It seems like a repetitive formula but that is what Doom has always been! Running and gunning! And it was so much fun! Finally, finally,
they even brought back the Baron of Hell, my favorite demon from Doom! Man guys, the demons aren't lumping, drooling muscleheads like in Doom 3 either! They run, dodge climb up everything and come after you to rip you to shreds! Such an improvement over Doom 3! There was this one stage where I had little health left and I frantically tried to get away from a hellknight and jumped down a path and as I looked back in fear I saw him jump after me in all his glory,
trapping me. That's when I knew, well done Doom AI team, bravo.

The only disappointment perhaps was it's  lack of plot atmoshphere. Don't get me wrong, with Doom I'm not expecting much but I do feel that the voice recordings and videos of the PDA system in Doom 3 created a brilliant atmosphere. I feel they could have introduced all the cool sciency parts of the first UAC complex in a different way. The walls and walls of text the pda's provide you do feel kind of empty. I also feel the characters are extremely forgettable. Dr Betruger from Doom 3 genuinely frightened me in a 'This guy is satanic as hell'-way.

If the long single player campaign with secrets and battles abound isn't enough to satisfy you there's still the multiplayer and snapmaps! Especially the snapmaps, with it you can create your own multiplayer or single player missions, I can't wait!

9/10

TLDR version

An awesome old school shooter in 2016. That's NOT an easy task to pull off, well done DOOM team!

reviewText:
Right off bat, if there were 1 word for me to describe this game it would be: EPIC!

People may have been skeptical about rehashing old games just to jump the hype train but Bethesda Software does nothing short of delivering a software masterpiece that captures all the glory of the old games and invent new innovative ways to approach FPS.  To my knowledge they really set a new bar for FPS game standards.

STORY/SETTING:

You didn't buy Doom for a story as deep as Bioshock Infinite or Uncharted.  No excessive characters, no complicated story plot, very simple and to the point.  The environment and setting is vastly unknown to you and part of the enjoyment is to see what happens next after series of completing events.

GAMEPLAY:

Every encounter involves RUNNING and SHOOTING.  You won't be taking cover, you won't be sniping, there is no subtlety here as those will almost immediately get you killed.  Every fight is an unrelenting battle against insurmountable odds ranging from waves of small imps to multiple towering hell knights.  There are a great variety of monsters ranging from numerous but weak to few but nearly immortal, slow precise ranged to insanely fast melee, all of which requiring unique strategies with the weapons available.  This makes all of the weapons useful to the very end of the game as well.  Plasma rifles can be modified to stun monsters (great for stopping rushing melee enemies in their tracks), Rocket launchers with homing capabilities for tough medium ranged monsters, and rail guns for tough but slow long ranged monsters.

There is a spec" system for upgrading weapons
hoursPlayed: perks
voteText: etc.  I didn't calculate it precisely but I am pretty sure it is possible to max out all attributes by the last level of the game if you find all secrets in every level.  Missions can be replayed to recollect any missed secrets and gain additional upgrade points.  The upgrade system does seem a bit complicated though.\n\nI was also impressed with the double jump and climbing up cliffs function in the game.  Platforming has always been somewhat cumbersome in FPS games but with this new system
helpfulPercent:
it definitely allows significantly more control and agility of the character when running from enemies.  This greater control makes FPS games not feel so handicapped when moving and jumping around allowing for new enjoyable challenges that require running around.

SOUND:

The Music is quite fitting with the overall mood of the game.  In the base areas
votesHelpful: there is always some upbeat techno music and most of the encounters have some heavy metal type music.  It definitely adds mood and character to the game itself.  Each weapon has awesome sounds and it really feels like they hold a tremendous amount of power behind them.  Explosions
votesTotal: bullets whizzing
votesFunny:
laser blasts are all satisfying to constantly hear without feeling annoyed or repetitive.  The whizzing noise of rockets shooting out of the assault rifle and sticking to the enemies before exploding was one really memorable sound effect that stuck to me.

GRAPHICS:

The graphics are decent and on par with the most advanced games out there now.  I always felt DOOM was a game where you would fight off a tremendous amount of monsters at the same time

reviewText:
I only just about recommended this game because the gameplay is fun. It is Doom, there is lots of demon slaying and plenty of guns to slay said demons with. But after finishing the game in 13 hours, and because of how it ended, I am beginning to wonder if the game manufacturers aren't attempting a bit of a cash grab.

The game is pretty linear. Get from A to B while killing everything inbetween that is not you. There is a villian whom you're trying to catch and you also get to uncover pieces of the story as you go along. The story is pretty much a side to the main dish: shooting stuff. And here it is fun. If you stand still, you're going to have a bad time. There are some areas where it is difficult to move around and it can be frustrating trying to do the thing they want you to do but in little space to do it in. However, on the whole, strafing, jumping and shooting your way through an area is lots of fun.

The bad parts though? The game is repetitive to the point that is predictable. You walk into a round/oval shaped room with lots of ammo, armour and health which means a fight is about to go down. It is not scary at all - Doom 3 was a lot scarier - and you'll find yourself wandering from area to area barely taking anything in. Every now and then you'll come across a log or hologram explaining some of the demented stuff they did to summon demons, but again it's thrown in more as justification for doing what you do. They could have expanded on the story a whole lot more because it's easy to feel like you're just running around and shooting stuff for the sake of running around and shooting stuff.

Many of the reviews I've read praise it for getting back to its roots or being the real Doom, but they could have done more than just sprinkle a story inbetween shooting stuff, climbing on stuff and melee attacking stuff. The Glory Kills (melee finishers) are not a bad idea, but they are really just soft quick time events. Shoot the demon until it flashes then hit the melee button to finish it off. You're then rewarded with health, ammo and armour, which sprinkles about like a pinyata has blown it's load.

The developers have a good game on their hands, but it seems like it's missing some stuff. For example, there are like only 2 NPCs you interact with throughout the game. It's pretty much demon shooting all the way. The game looks nice but the levels are pretty much the same: walk down a corridor towards a room or area where you're going to shoot stuff then proceed to the next level.

Here are some pros and cons:

Pros:
- Shooting hordes of demons and fighting demon bosses is fun
- Power-ups help you lay the smack down that much harder on demons
- You can upgrade your weapons, armour and equipment. You can increase your maximum health, armour and ammo capacities, which is a nice touch.
- You're constantly moving when fighting, so it forces you to think about what the best weapons are for the environment, as well as for the specific demons you're facing.
- Melee finishers come in handy, especially when ammo and health start running low.
- The game is rather forgiving when you do, allowing you to just reload from the last checkpoint, which is usually not far from when you entered an area.

Cons:
- Combat is repetitive, especially during boss fights. I remember finding myself just circle strafing and shooting many times because it worked rather well.
- Not much of a story, which is a shame because Doom 3's PDA system made the game more immersive.
- Level design tends to be similar when entering areas where you're going to fight some demons.
- The ending is a bit of a let down. They're probably looking to profit from DLC later.
- The game feels" fast-paced only because demons are quick and you're constantly trying to avoid projectiles. Your character

hoursPlayed: but it hasn't got much in the way of substance."

reviewText: This game runs on an engine that is a joy to experience. Optimized for speed, an expression of love for the pc gamer with keyboard in one hand and mouse in the other.  With much attention to detail on how the world looks when you move your mouse, or strafe, or pull that trigger.  I hadn't experienced such a glass smooth response engine since the days of quake.  We've become accustomed to inferior games with their instant hit mechanics, de-emphasized movement of projectiles in space, dumbed down 'trust me you hit something' hit markers.  Doom brings back something we've been missing and raises a bloody middle finger to all recent first person shooters that came before it.   Aim matters, weapon switching matters, distance matters, and you the player have become an artist.  At your disposal is an arsenal of destructive weapons.  It's up to you to paint that canvas with blood.  Doom is a jolting realization of what we've been missing out on.  Other games have taken shortcuts and denied us a pure visceral experience that our computers,  our internet connections, and our skills were capable of all along.  To hell with hide and cover mechanics, it's time again to kick some ♥♥♥.   I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Single player? Absolutely spot on.  No, it's ♥♥♥♥ing PERFECT.  You'll be tearing the map inside out looking for those last damned secrets, the fights just get better and better the more enemy types they throw at you (and the more firepower you throw back) and the Nightmare difficulty is actually a challenge.  I'm frankly amazed that they translated the gameplay so well to a modern game, from essentially a 2D topology (and gameplay) to 3D as well.

Multiplayer? Meh.  Needs some more work.  The weapons are inherently unbalanced and the guns are not satisfying.  The speed is okay but feels slower than it actually is because too many of the wrong weapons are weak e.g. rocket launcher, and the game is very unhappily married with this horrendous two-weapon loadout system.  Why did they have to introduce THAT element, especially when the single player game does not, thank God?  Also the announcer sounds like he's a centuries-old wizard with just as much understanding of the game.  Bad, bad.  Tragic thing is the finishing-touch work to make multiplayer as evil and nosebleed-inducing as it ought to be is a couple of hours work, if that.  Except for new VA work, obviously.

Overall get it today for the satisfying single player, if you're a Doom fan.  Don't bother with multiplayer until it's actually worked on a bit more.  The multiplayer would probably be a bit more okay if the single player wasn't such a glorious masterpiece right alongside it, making the multiplayer look even more of an afterthought.

Snapmap is more of the same as multiplayer sadly, the tool itself is pretty darned cool but for all of its options it is limited by the imposed limits set to keep the framerate up on consoles and minimum spec PCs.  Come on guys... the best part of the game is the part you refused to advertise.

reviewText:
I was more than likely one of those who actually bought the collectors edition from the store.

I never really got into Doom 3 but since installing and playing Doom I have been more than happy, especially with it's single player context of the game. I have always found fast paced fps multiplayer games, ever since Quake world to a bit of a minefield for knowing if a game is good or not. You can never trully say a game is good or bad just by playing multiplayer.

I urge for anyone thinking of getting this game to ask yourself, are you a single player or multiplayer person? SP is defintiely me and because of that, this is why I believe this game has done an awesome job.

With all my settings set to Ultra (There is one more step known as Nightmare but you need a 5GB GFX card to support it) it runs butter smooth at constant 60fps. I see no screen tearing, no lag, no nothing. The AI of hellspawn and depending on which difficulty you choose is on par, they all have their own way of coming for you.

As you play through the game there is so much to do for a SP FPS, but it does not hinder the game as most FPS's that try to add side projects to it. The upgrades for weapons, armour, runes etc are very well done and the mini games mixed in to get the runes just add to the flavour.

There is a very well put together overview of the environments, artifacts, weapons, monsters etc. that really give you the feel that you are part of something in that world and you are learning of why, what, where, who, when and how.

I am yet to play with Snapmap, but from what I've seen in terms of how it works, people out there who are not the best at creating extra content for a game can find it very easy and there is so much that can add in via the community. Definitely giving it a lot more playability rather than just straight up SP or Multi.

Overally if I was to rate this out of 10, it would definitely be a 9. The only reason it wouldn't be 10 is because it is missing the most memorable part of any old school game that is current, CO OP.

reviewText:
I don't know where to start besides saying that I just love it. Calling it perfect would be absurd, but it's damn near close. The critiques I have are mostly too minor for me to really care about. Four things that stood out to me the most about the game are:

The Level Design

The levels are huge and full of secrets. They remind me very much of the original Doom levels in the sense that they can be full of twists and turns with little alcoves and corners hiding items that you need to sniff out. The verticality makes for a lot of interesting routes you can take. I love the fact that they included an automap and managed to make it completely readable and easy to use. I'm always tabbing in and out of it to look for secreat areas or places I might have overlooked, just like in the original games.

The maps are also very pretty. The Martian surface with the vast landscapes that you can look out over, seeing different parts of the UAC base that you eventually travel to almost strikes me as a callback to the intermission screen of Knee Deep in the Dead. My two favorite levels so far are probably Foundry and the Lazarus labs. Running around the gritty industrial facility with molten slag pouring out of the walls making everything glow bright orange. And later on, deep inside the Lazarus labs, you can see the extent of what the UAC have been up to with their experimenting and cult worship of Hell, which leads me to my next favorite bit.

The Story

Yeah Doom seems to actually have a halfway decent story so far. Well, I haven't finished the game yet so I still have to see what happens, but I love reading all of the tidbits you pick up along the way about the environments and the monsters. Each codex entry you find gives you some insight into the research and development behind the projects that UAC have been up to, as well as the indoctrination of their workers. Slowly brainwashing them from their low level positions until they eventually convince them that it's perfectly okay to kneel over and be ripped apart by a demon.

Another thing I like is that half the time the game simply lets you ignore things if you don't want to bother listening to what's going on. There are some forced cutscenes where you have to stop and look at a thing that's happening, but most of the time these only last about 5 seconds, with the exception of a few that may last quite a bit longer.

I want to keep this review mostly spoiler free, but the way they handled Doomguy is great. Reading about his backstory and seeing how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ he is with what the UAC is doing is a great way for them to let Doomguy speak without actually using his voice.

The Gameplay

The combat is just fun. You move very quickly, you jump around up onto ledges and over demons heads, smacking down on their chests and pulling their heads apart, blasting them with rocket launchers and slicing them in half with chainsaws. It's so fast, fluid, bloody and fun. Everytime I reach a room that I can tell is going to be a fight I get excited, I think to myself  hell yeah
date: let's do it " and then the monsters pour in and the music kicks in and you just start dancing around the room fragging one demon after another.\n\nWhen it's over with you get a breather to look around the level and stock up on health and ammo
